His family history reveals that his father had a myocardial infarction in his 80s  and his elder brother has a history of coronary artery disease. No allergies have been reported.  Social History: Mr. Smith is a retired mechanical engineer. He quit smoking 20 years ago but continues to consume alcohol in moderation. He is physically active and tries to exercise regularly. However  he admits that his dietary habits can improve as he frequently consumes high-calorie  high-fat foods. He lives with his wife  who is his primary caregiver.  Examination: On examination  his irregular and rapid heart rhythm was noted  chest auscultation confirmed irregular heartbeat  and his blood pressure observed to be 148/92 mm Hg. Other systems did not reveal any significant abnormality.  Investigations: An ECG confirmed atrial fibrillation with a ventricular rate of 128 beats per minute. Blood tests showed slightly elevated glucose and cholesterol levels.  Summary: A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  diabetes  and hypercholesterolemia presents with palpitations  fatigue  and shortness of breath. His symptoms and ECG findings are suggestive of atrial fibrillation  which might be antecedent to his prior TIA. His vital signs  particularly blood pressure  need to be closely monitored  and efforts to improve his diet and lifestyle should be reinforced to better manage his comorbidities. Appropriate anticoagulation therapy needs to be considered due to his elevated stroke risk. His progress and therapeutic regimen must be regularly followed up.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Atrial Fibrillation   Patient Overview: Patient Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 67 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian  Presenting Problem:  The patient presents with Atrial Fibrillation.  Symptoms: Mr. Doe reports experiencing extended periods of heart palpitations  occasional bouts of dizziness  and unexplained fatigue for the past month. He has also noticed shortness of breath  intermittent episodes of chest pain  and occasional lightheadedness.   Past Medical History: He has a documented history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which are under control with medication. He has been on Metformin (500mg twice daily) for his diabetes and Lisinopril (10mg once daily) for hypertension. He suffered a transient ischemic attack (TIA) five years ago. No documented history of cardiac issues before the current episode.   Social History: Mr. Doe is a retired engineer  has been a non-smoker for the past 15 years and drinks alcohol socially.   Family History: His father died at the age of 75 from myocardial infarction  while his mother died at 80 due to Alzheimer's disease. He has two siblings  a brother with documented coronary artery disease and a sister who is diabetic.  Review of Systems: Unremarkable  apart from the noted intermittent chest pain and associated symptoms of atrial fibrillation.   Physical Examination: Upon physical examination  irregular pulse was noticed. He looked alert but slightly anxious. Other vital signs were stable with a Blood Pressure of 135/85mmHg and SpO2 96% on room air. The cardiovascular examination showed irregularly irregular rhythm. Rest of the systemic examination was within normal limits.  Conclusion: Mr. Doe's symptoms along with clinical findings are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Given his past medical history and age  he is at an overall high risk for cardiovascular events. Thus  immediate management and long-term treatment plan are required to manage his condition and minimize future risks.   Plan:  Mr. Doe should be recommended for further diagnostic testing which may include ECG  echocardiogram  and blood tests. After diagnosis  appropriate therapy or procedure to manage atrial fibrillation  and modification of existing medication plan will need to be formulated considering his hypertension and diabetes.

Title: A Case Presentation on Atrial Fibrillation  Patient Profile: Mr. Robert Williams is a 68-year-old African-American male  retired engineer  currently residing in Baltimore  Maryland.   Chief Complaint: He presents at the cardiology clinic with complaints of heart palpitations and occasional shortness of breath  more so during moderate physical activities over the last two months. He also reports intermittent episodes of light-headedness and fatigue.  Past Medical History: - Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed eight years ago and managed with metformin. - Hypertension: Diagnosed fifteen years ago  controlled with losartan. - Hypercholesterolemia: Diagnosed ten years ago and managed by diet and statin medication. - No known drug allergies.  Family History: - Father died of a myocardial infarction at age 74. - Mother has severe osteoarthritis but is alive at age 92.  Lifestyle: - He quit smoking 10 years ago after a 25-year smoking history. - He admits to drinking alcohol socially but denies any illicit drug usage. - He is married with 2 children and is physically active  regularly engaging in walks and light exercises.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  Mr. Williams appears anxious. His blood pressure measures at 130/85 mm Hg  heart rate is irregular at 110 bpm  and respiratory rate is found to be 18 breaths per minute. Cardiovascular examination reveals an irregularly irregular pulse. No cyanosis  clubbing  or edema is present.  Initial Investigations:  An EKG is conducted revealing atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response.   Plan: Considering Mr. Williams clinical presentation and EKG results  he is diagnosed with atrial fibrillation. Considering his high risk of stroke due to his age and pre-existing conditions (hypertension  diabetes  and hypercholesterolemia)  anticoagulation therapy is required. He is also recommended beta-blockers to manage his heart rate. He is scheduled for a follow-up after one month and educated on lifestyle changes to manage his AFib and other comorbidities. Patient is also referred to a dietitian for guidance on diet modifications.

Title: Clinical Presentation of an Atrial Fibrillation Patient  Patient Profile: The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male known as John Doe. He is a retired engineer who resides in the suburb of Manhattan  New York with his wife. He is a non-smoker  but he admits to consuming alcoholic beverages on weekends.   Presenting Complaint: The patient presented with symptoms of persistent fatigue  palpitations  chest discomfort  and shortness of breath  which have been occurring intermittently over the past 3 months. Per Mr. Doe's account  the symptoms are more pronounced during mild exertion  such as climbing stairs.   Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a known history of Hypertension  which has been under control with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors. He was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus 10 years ago  which is managed by oral hypoglycemic agents. The patient also had a stroke 5 years ago  from which he fully recovered with residual mild right-sided weakness. He was subsequently placed on aspirin for secondary stroke prevention.   Physical Examination: On examination  the patient is afebrile  blood pressure 145/90 mmHg  pulse rate 110 beats/minute (irregular)  respiratory rate 20/min  and oxygen saturation 96% on room air. Visual inspection of jugular veins revealed no distention  but mild bilateral pedal edema was noted.   Cardiovascular Examination: Upon auscultation  his heartbeat was irregularly irregular with no heart murmurs  suggesting possible atrial fibrillation.   Given his symptoms and clinical findings  an electrocardiogram (ECG) was requested  which confirmed the suspicion of Atrial Fibrillation. The patient was immediately referred to a cardiologist to finalize the treatment plan.

Presentation:  Good evening  I'll be presenting Mr. Mark Anderson  a 65-year-old Caucasian male with newly diagnosed atrial fibrillation. Mr. Anderson  a retired schoolteacher  lives alone in New York City. He's an ex-smoker  quit 15 years ago after a 30-year habit  and is a social drinker.   He presented to the ER with complaints of palpitations and shortness of breath of one-week duration. Upon arrival  his initial vital signs were as follows - Blood Pressure: 130/85 mmHg  Heart Rate: irregularly irregular at 100 to 140 BPM  Respiratory Rate: 18 breaths per minute  Oxygen saturation: 97% on room air  Temperature: 37.2°C. ECG findings confirmed atrial fibrillation.  His past medical history includes controlled hypertension  for which he has been on Lisinopril 10mg daily for the last 5 years. He also has early-stage chronic kidney disease - which was diagnosed 2 years ago and is being managed with diet and lifestyle changes. Mr. Anderson does not have any history of heart disease  diabetes  or stroke. His family history is significant for a brother with heart disease and a mother who died from a stroke.  He has no known drug allergies. His current medication list includes Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension. He reports no recent changes in his medication or their dosages.  For now  it appears the new onset atrial fibrillation is the primary problem that needs to be further investigated and managed. The goal would be to control his heart rate  manage his symptoms and consider anticoagulation therapy to prevent potential thromboembolic events  given his age and existing comorbidities.   That concludes my presentation of Mr. Anderson's case. Any questions or comments are welcome.

Patient Presentation  Our patient is a 67-year-old African-American male named Mr. John Smith. His primary complaint is of experiencing rapid palpitations  bouts of lightheadedness  and occasional shortness of breath anew. He has been a resident of Orlando  Florida  for the past 35 years. He is a retired engineer and has been living a fairly active lifestyle.  Mr. Smith has a known medical history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus  both of which have been well managed with diet modifications and oral antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications for the past 10 years. He has no known allergies to drugs or food. There's no past history of hospitalization or surgery. He has recently been complaining about increasing fatigue and limited capacity for physical activity.  Family history indicates his father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 70 and his mother was diagnosed with hypothyroidism. He has one sibling  a brother  who was diagnosed with early-onset Parkinson's disease.   In terms of lifestyle  Mr. Smith quit smoking a decade ago  and currently consumes alcohol moderately and prefers a diet high in fruits  vegetables  and lean meats. He has been physically active throughout his life  enjoying regular morning walks  and golfing on weekends.  Upon examination  irregular heartbeat patterns were detected leading to the suspicion of Atrial Fibrillation. It has been recommended that Mr. Smith must undergo further testing that may include EKG  Holter monitoring  and possibly an echocardiogram to confirm the diagnosis and identify the severity of the condition. Initial discussion has been made with him regarding potential treatment plans including medication  cardioversion  or surgical procedures if the atrial fibrillation is confirmed.  The key focus  in this case  is to ensure precise identification of the arrhythmia type  prompt control of rate and rhythm  and execution of a multifold treatment plan involving lifestyle modification  pharmacological strategy  and possible invasive therapies.

Patient Presentation: Mr. John Smith is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of palpitations  occasional chest discomfort  fatigue  and shortness of breath on exertion which has progressively worsened over the past several weeks. He adds that he has begun to feel intermittent rapid  irregular heartbeats.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medications (lisinopril and atorvastatin  respectively). He quit smoking 10 years ago after a 30-pack year history. Additionally  the patient’s family history is significant for cardiovascular disease; both his father and brother had myocardial infarctions in their 60s.   Mr. Smith denies any recent fever  weight changes  or changes in diet or exercise. He admits to a moderate intake of alcohol (1-2 drinks per day).  On physical examination  irregularly irregular heart rhythms are noted on auscultation. His BP is 140/90  pulse rate is 98 bpm  and respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute. No signs of congestive heart failure or thyrotoxicosis are observed.  The clinical history and examination raise suspicion for atrial fibrillation which will need to be confirmed through further investigations.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and prior myocardial infarction. He presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of palpitations and shortness of breath that has been worsening over the past week. He also endorses intermittent chest tightness and fatigue. He denies any syncope  dizziness  or significant changes in diet or physical activity levels.  His home medications include lisinopril  metformin  and aspirin. He has a 40-pack year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially and denies any recreational drug use. His father had a history of ischemic heart disease and passed away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 75.   On examination  he appears mildly distressed due to breathlessness. His blood pressure is 156/92 mmHg  pulse is irregularly irregular at 110 bpm  the respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 95% on room air. The cardiac examination reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm. There are no murmurs  gallops  or rubs. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  A preliminary EKG indicates atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. The rest of his lab results including complete blood count  electrolytes  kidney function  and liver function tests are pending.

Patient Presentation:   A 72-year-old African American male presented to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and shortness of breath. His symptoms began a few days ago and have been progressively worsening. He denies chest pain  dizziness  or syncope.  Past Medical History:  His past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which are being managed with medications. He quit smoking about 5 years ago but had a 30-pack-year history before quitting. He drinks alcohol on occasionally and has no known drug allergies. He is currently on metformin for diabetes  lisinopril for hypertension  as well as a low-dose aspirin regimen. The patient's family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases; both his father and a brother died from myocardial infarctions. His mother had a stroke.   Physical Examination:  On examination  his blood pressure reading was 150/95 mmHg and the heart rate was irregularly irregular at around 117 beats per minute. The rest of the examination was unremarkable except for the cardiac auscultation  which revealed an irregular rhythm without any murmurs or gallops.  Based on history and physical examination  a preliminary diagnosis of atrial fibrillation was considered. The patient was admitted for further testing and management including ECG  cardiac biomarkers  chest x-ray  and anticoagulation therapy initiation.

Patient Information: A 68-year-old Caucasian female presents to the clinic.  Chief Complaint: Intermittent racing heart for the past two months.   History of Present Illness: The patient reports occasional periods of a racing  irregular heartbeat  accompanied by light-headedness and fatigue. These episodes last anywhere from a few minutes to a few hours. She has no chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncope.   Past Medical History: She has a known history of Hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  both well-controlled with medication. She had a cholecystectomy 10 years ago.   Family History: Her mother had a stroke at age 72. The patient has no known family history of heart disease.   Medication: The patient is taking Metformin 500mg BID for diabetes  and Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension.  Lifestyle: She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally.   Physical Exam: Blood pressure: 128/82 mm Hg  Pulse rate: irregular at 105 bpm  Respiratory rate: 16 breaths per minute  Temperature: 98.6 °F  Oxygen saturation: 98% on room air. Heart exam revealed an irregular rhythm  no murmurs  rubs  or gallops.   Preliminary Assessment: The history  symptoms  and physical examination findings are suggestive of Atrial Fibrillation. The next step would be to confirm the diagnosis with an electrocardiogram (ECG)  initiate anticoagulation if necessary  and consider medications or procedures for rate or rhythm control. Referral to a cardiologist may be considered.

Patient Information: Mr. Johnson  a 76-year-old male  retired civil engineer  a moderate smoker for the past 40 years.   Chief Complaint: He presents with complaints of recurrent episodes of palpitations and shortness of breath on mild exertion  occurred over the past two-months.  History of Present Illness: Mr. Johnson describes his palpitations as a fast and irregular heartbeat. They occur sporadically  approximately twice a week  lasting anywhere from a few minutes to a few hours. Accompanying his palpitations  he experiences light headedness  shortness of breath  and occasionally  he noted mild chest pain. His symptoms are relieved with rest. He denies fainting episodes or sudden onset of severe chest pain.   Past Medical History: Significant for hypertension for which he is on Lisinopril  Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus controlled with Metformin and simvastatin for high cholesterol levels.   Family History: His father had a history of stroke; his mother and two siblings have hypertension. No known family history of heart disease or sudden cardiac death.  Review of Systems: He reports recent fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance. He denies any sick contacts or recent illnesses. He reports maintaining good glycemic control. He denies any changes in appetite or weight  any fevers  chills  or any other systemic symptoms.  Social History: He lives with his wife  who is his primary caregiver. Moderate smoker for about 40 years  averaging about 10 cigarettes a day. Denies alcohol or illicit drug use. He was a civil engineer and his work did not involve any exposure to toxins or chemicals.   Physical Exam: Afebrile  blood pressure 150/90  irregularly irregular heart rate in the 90s  respiratory rate 16  and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. Cardiovascular exam was significant for irregularly irregular rhythm. No murmurs  rubs  or gallops were appreciated. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable.

Patient Profile: Mr. James Miller  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  residing in the suburbs of Boston with his wife since the past 35 years. He is a non-smoker and social drinker. Mr. Miller has a significant past medical history of hypertension for the past 10 years  controlled with antihypertensive medication and has been recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus. He also has a family history of cardiovascular diseases with his father passing away from a heart attack at the age of 65.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Miller presents to the clinic with intermittent palpitations which he says has been occurring for the past two months. These episodes last for a few minutes to a few hours. He also reports that he has been feeling increasingly tired and breathless upon exertion over these past weeks. On occasion  he has experienced dizziness during these bouts of palpitations.  Current Medications: 1. Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension 2. Metformin 500mg twice a day for type 2 diabetes  On examination  his irregular pulse confirms an irregularly irregular rhythms suggesting atrial fibrillation. Further lab tests and an ECG are suggested to confirm the diagnosis and assess any potential complications.

Patient Information: Mr. Jones  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired teacher  non-smoker  moderate alcohol consumer  presenting with complaints of fatigue and intermittent heart palpitations over the past two weeks.  Chief Complaint: Fatigue  intermittent palpitations.  History of Present Illness: The patient states that he has been experiencing increasing episodes of fatigue and a feeling of “heart fluttering” for the last two weeks. Describes palpitations as ""fast and irregular"". Denies chest pain  shortness of breath  syncope  or presyncope.   Past Medical History: Hypertension diagnosed at age 48  well-controlled with Lisinopril. Diagnosed with type II diabetes at age 55  currently managed with Metformin. No prior history of heart disease or stroke.   Family History: Father passed away from a stroke at age 75  and mother has a history of atrial fibrillation.   Social History: Retired teacher  lives with his wife. He denies smoking  but admits to a history of moderate alcohol consumption.   Review of Systems: Denied fever  cough  wheezing  chest pain. No recent weight loss  changes in appetite or bowel habits. Reports occasional night sweats.   Medications: Lisinopril 20mg daily  Metformin 1000mg twice daily.   Physical Exam: Blood pressure 150/85 mmHg  heart rate irregular at 110 bpm  afebrile  respiratory rate 16/min  oxygen saturation 98%. Cardiovascular: irregularly irregular heart rhythm. No murmur  rub  or gallop noted. No lower limbs edema. Rest of the physical exam normal.    Lab results: Blood glucose levels slightly elevated. All other blood work  including thyroid function tests  within normal limits.   ECG: Atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Johnson is a 75-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of palpitations  occasional shortness of breath  and unexplained fatigue for the past three weeks. The patient noticed an irregular rhythm of his heartbeat and episodes of light-headedness prompting him to seek medical attention. Mr. Johnson has a medical history significant for hypertension under control with amlodipine and type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with metformin. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally in social events.  The patient has no known drug allergy. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases; his father succumbed to a myocardial infarction at the age of 72. Examination revealed the patient is alert  oriented  and in no apparent distress. Vitals include a pulse of 112 beats per minute irregularly irregular  blood pressure on 135/80 mmHg  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  temperature of 98.6°F  and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. A resting EKG was performed  which revealed atrial fibrillation.  Mr. Johnson represents a typical elderly patient with risk factors for atrial fibrillation  including age  hypertension  and a family history of cardiovascular diseases. His symptoms also coincide with common clinical manifestations of the condition.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 68-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the clinic today with complaints of intermittent palpitations  shortness of breath  and fatigue which started about a week ago. He describes the palpitations as ""fluttering"" in his chest.  Past Medical History:  His medical history includes hypertension and type II diabetes  both well controlled with medication. He had a myocardial infarction in his early sixties but made a full recovery with stenting and cardiac rehabilitation. His current medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Aspirin.  Social history reveals that he is a retired industrial engineer  a former smoker with a 20-pack year history but quit 10 years ago. He consumes alcohol socially  approximately 1-2 drinks per week.  On examination  his pulse is irregularly irregular  and an EKG confirms atrial fibrillation. All other physical examinations such as lung  heart sounds  and peripheral pulse are unremarkable. He denies any chest pain  syncope  orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.   Family history reveals his father had a stroke in his late 70s  and his mother had atrial fibrillation. His BMI is in the normal range  and he exercises regularly. He is now scheduled for a follow up echocardiogram to asses cardiac function and structure further. He was also being counseled about the potential need for anticoagulation therapy  based on his CHA2DS2-VASc score.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. James Cooper is a 75-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic today with complaints of intermittent heart palpitations  general fatigue  and shortness of breath over the past two weeks. Additionally  he mentions occasional light-headedness but denies syncope  chest pain  or swelling in his feet.    The patient has a known history of chronic hypertension  diagnosed 15 years ago  currently well-controlled on amlodipine. He also reports a previous transient ischemic attack (TIA) five years ago  which has left him relatively asymptomatic post adequate management.    Mr. Cooper leads a sedentary lifestyle with occasional alcohol consumption. He smokes about 5 cigarettes per day  a habit he's had for around 50 years. His family history shows that his father had a heart attack at the age of 68 and his mother has a history of congestive heart failure.   The review of other systems revealed increased urinary frequency  which he attributes to prostate enlargement  which he is due to have investigated shortly. No gastrointestinal or visual symptoms are reported.  Mr. Cooper has a history of poor compliance with anticoagulant medication (Coumadin)  admitting that he finds the constant monitoring and blood tests tedious and inconvenient. His diet lacks fruits and vegetables  consisting mainly of meats and carbs.   Mr. Cooper is a retired engineer  living alone since his wife passed away a few years ago. His son visits him weekly and a community nurse visits on weekdays to help with his medication.

Patient Information: Mr. James  a 75-year-old Caucasian male retired school teacher  residing in Yorktown  Virginia.  Chief Complaint: He complains of erratic pounding sensations in his chest for the past several weeks  particularly noticeable when he climbs the stairs or does any strenuous activity. He also mentions occasional bouts of dizziness and unexplainable fatigue.   Relevant Medical History: He has a history of longstanding hypertension for the past 20 years  which is being managed with hydrochlorothiazide. He had an ischemic stroke five years ago  from which he fully recovered. Has also been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes which is managed with metformin. He is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago and occasionally drinks 1-2 beers on social occasions.  Family History: His father died from congestive heart failure and his mother has type 2 diabetes. His older sister suffered from a stroke.   Current Medications: He is currently taking hydrochlorothiazide 25mg daily for hypertension  metformin 1000mg twice daily for type 2 diabetes  and a daily aspirin.  Social History: He lives alone  his wife died 4 years ago. He has three daughters who visit him regularly. He does not engage in regular physical activity anymore. He has regular appointments with his cardiologist and follows the necessary care plan for his conditions.  History of Present Illness: The symptoms of palpitations  fatigue  and occasional dizziness have been increasing gradually over two months. Initially  he attributed these disturbances to old age or anxiety but it has started to significantly interfere with his daily routine.  This presentation is typical of a patient with Atrial Fibrillation (AFib). The symptoms and current health status support the suspicion of AFib. His background of hypertension  past stroke  and diabetes place him in a high-risk category for developing AFib. Given the chronicity and severity of the symptoms  further investigations and management should be pursued promptly.

A 68-year-old Hispanic male  Mr. Sanchez  presents with complaints of intermittent palpitations and fatigue for the past 3 weeks. Mr. Sanchez is a retired truck driver with a 30-year history of hypertension and a 5-year history of type II diabetes mellitus. He is a former smoker who quit ten years ago but admits to occasional alcohol consumption.   His medications include Metformin 1000mg twice daily and Lisinopril 10mg once daily. He reports sporadic chest discomfort over the past week  not worsened with exertion or relieved with rest. On physical examination  his pulse is irregularly irregular at 110 beats per minute  BP is 140/90 mmHg  respiratory rate is 18/min and he appears chronically ill. His BMI is 29 indicating he is overweight.  His EKG reveals irregular R-R intervals and absence of consistent P waves  consistent with atrial fibrillation. Labs reveal slightly elevated blood glucose and HbA1c levels and minimally raised troponin levels.   The patient is married  has three adult children  resides with his wife  and leads a fairly sedentary lifestyle. He admits that his diet could probably be improved and he doesn't exercise regularly. Mr. Sanchez reports no allergies  no recreational drug use  and his family history is notable for an older brother who had a heart attack at age 72.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 70-year-old Black Male  presenting to the cardiology office with symptoms of fatigue and dyspnea on exertion. The patient reports these symptoms began approximately 3 weeks ago and have gradually worsened  although denies any chest pain. The patient has a known medical history significant for hypertension and non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus. The patient's family history is significant for myocardial infarctions in both parents. He is a former smoker with a 20-pack year history  and reports moderate alcohol use.  On review of his symptoms  he reports irregular heartbeat and occasional dizziness. On examination  an irregularly irregular pulse is noted. The remainder of the cardiovascular exam is unremarkable with no signs of heart failure. His ECG reveals atrial fibrillation with a moderate ventricular response.  He lives with his wife and is a retired businessman. As per the patient's report  he is compliant with his hypertension and diabetes medications. He has no known drug allergies  and his current medications include Metformin 500mg twice a day and Amlodipine 10mg once daily. His only surgical history is a right knee replacement performed about 9 years prior due to osteoarthritis. He has no known history of clotting disorders or strokes.

Patient Information: 73-year-old Caucasian male aims to have his regular Check-up.  Chief Complaint: “I have been experiencing intermittent episodes of rapid and irregular heart rate.”  History of Present Illness: Episodes begin spontaneously and can last from a few minutes to several hours. They are sometimes accompanied by light-headedness  fatigue  and shortness of breath. No associated chest pain  nausea  or diaphoresis. No history of syncope.  Past Medical History: Hypertension for 15 years (controlled with lisinopril)  Type II Diabetes Mellitus for 18 years (controlled with metformin)  chronic kidney disease (stage 3). No known history of coronary artery disease or heart failure.  Social History: Ex-smoker (quit 20 years ago)  drinks alcohol socially  denies use of illicit drugs.  Review of Systems: No recent weight loss  fever  cough  or other constitutional symptoms.  Family History: Father had a stroke at age 76  mother has hypertension and type II diabetes.  Medication: Lisinopril and metformin.  Allergies: Penicillin – causes rash.  Physician assessment: Patient appears in no acute distress. Regular rate and rhythm during examination.  Plan: Considering symptoms and history  Atrial Fibrillation (AF) is suspected. Will proceed with EKG and Holter monitor for confirmation. Based on these results  further plan will be required for rate or rhythm control and stroke prevention  taking into account the patient’s age  kidney function  diabetes history  and anticoagulation options. Patient is being educated about dietary restriction  routine exercise  and lifestyle modifications.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 75-year-old Caucasian man presenting with complaints of palpitations and breathlessness upon exertion over the last two weeks. He describes the palpitations as irregular heartbeats which start and stop abruptly. He denies any chest pain  light-headedness  syncope  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.   Mr. Smith is a retired professor and lives with his wife.  He has a past medical history significant for hypertension controlled with Lisinopril 10mg daily for the past 10 years and hyperlipidemia managed on Atorvastatin 20mg daily. He is a former smoker with a 30-pack year history but quit 15 years ago. He occasionally consumes alcohol  around 2-3 drinks per week.   He has no known drug allergies. His father had a history of stroke in his seventies. Mr. Smith has had no surgical interventions in the past. He is up-to-date on his vaccinations  and his last annual check-up was six months ago.   On physical examination  his blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg  heart rate is irregularly irregular  and respiratory rate is stable at 16 breaths per minute with an oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Lungs are clear on auscultation  and cardiovascular examination reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm  with no murmurs or abnormal heart sounds.    Based on the symptom description and initial examination  a clinical suspicion of atrial fibrillation is made  subject to further investigations such as EKG and echocardiogram for confirmation.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Doe is a 63-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic with complaints of palpitations and feeling of fatigue for the past two weeks. He describes the palpitations as a 'fluttering' sensation in his chest which occurs unpredictably and lasts for several minutes to hours. He also reports experiencing periods of lightheadedness and mild shortness of breath. He denies chest pain  syncope  dyspnea at rest  or lower limb swelling.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension which has been well-controlled with Lisinopril for the past 10 years. He was also diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 7 years ago and he has been on Metformin and maintaining adequate blood sugar control. He does not have any prior history of cardiac diseases. Mr. doe is a former smoker (20-pack year history  quit 15 years ago) and denies alcohol or illicit drug use.  Family history reveals that his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 70  and his elder sister has a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension.   On physical examination vital signs are blood pressure of 140/85 mmHg  pulse irregularly irregular at 120 beats/min  respiration rate of 16 breaths/min  and BMI of 28. Cardiovascular examination reveals irregularly irregular rhythm with no murmurs or gallops. The rest of the systemic examination is within normal limits. His baseline EKG reveals atrial fibrillation with a controlled ventricular response. The patient's symptoms and physical findings are suggestive of atrial fibrillation  for which he is referred for further cardiological evaluation and management.

Patient Information: A 70-year-old Caucasian female.  Chief Complaint: Patient is experiencing palpitations  occasional shortness of breath  and mild fatigue.   Present Symptoms: The patient reports a feeling of the heart fluttering rapidly in her chest  intermittent periods of breathlessness especially on exertion  reduced stamina  and occasional light-headedness over the past 3 months. No symptoms of chest pain  syncope  lower extremity edema  or excessive urination at night.  Past Medical History: Hypertension controlled on medication  high cholesterol for 10 years  a previous transient ischemic attack 3 years ago  and no known history of cardiac disease. She is a non-smoker and does not consume any alcohol.  Medication History: She is on Amlodipine 5mg daily for hypertension and Atorvastatin 20mg at night for hyperlipidemia. No known drug allergies.  Family History: She reports her father had myocardial infarction at age 72  her mother had hypertension and stroke in her later life  and her older sister has type 2 diabetes mellitus.  Physical Examination: She appears generally healthy. Vitals reveal an irregularly-irregular pulse rate of 95 bpm  blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per min  and oxygen saturation of 96% in room air. Extra heart sounds were noted in cardiovascular assessment. No peripheral edema seen on physical examination.  Given the clinical history and presentation  the patient is suspected to have atrial fibrillation. Further echocardiography and EKG tests are advised for definitive diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 70-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the outpatient cardiology clinic with a complaint of intermittent “fluttering” in his chest that last started 4 days ago. He further explains that each episode lasts for several minutes and has been associated with mild shortness of breath  lightheadedness  and moderate fatigue. He denies any associated chest pain  palpitations  sweating  edema  or recent weight gain.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia which are controlled with hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin respectively. He has no known history of any heart diseases or prior episodes of similar symptoms. He denies having diabetes  asthma  or thyroid diseases. He smokes half a pack of cigarettes a day for the past 30 years and drinks alcohol socially.   Family history reveals that his father died of a stroke at an age of 73  and his mother had a history of arrhythmia. Mr. Doe is a retired banker  lives with his wife  and maintains an active lifestyle. He has no past surgical history and is not allergic to any known substance or drug.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of palpitations and general fatigue  which he has been experiencing for the past three weeks. He reports a decreased exercise tolerance and shortness of breath during his daily walks. He denies chest pain  lightheadedness  or syncope.   Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a documented history of hypertension  marked by an elevated systolic blood pressure consistently greater than 140mmHg over the past 10 years. He has been on Lisinopril and Hydrochlorothiazide to manage his hypertension. He does not have any history of diabetes or hyperlipidemia.  He has a history of ischemic stroke 2 years ago  from which he had a complete neurological recovery. Since the stroke  he has remained on low-dose aspirin therapy as recommended by his neurologist. He also has a 10-year history of stable chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) maintained on inhaled corticosteroids.  Mr. Smith quit smoking 5 years ago after a 35-year pack/day history. He drinks alcohol socially and has no known drug allergies.  Family History:  His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 65  and his mother had a stroke in her late seventies.   On examination  he is afebrile  blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg  heart rate is irregularly irregular and rapid (110 bpm)  and respiratory rate is 18 breaths/min. The rest of his physical examination is within normal limits.   In conclusion  Mr. Smith  with a past history of hypertension  stroke  and COPD  presents with symptoms of palpitations and fatigue  which are consistent with a potential diagnosis of atrial fibrillation and require further investigation.

Patient Information: Mrs. Katherine James  a 75-year-old white female  presents to the outpatient cardiology department.  Chief Complaint: Shortness of breath and occasional heart palpitations for the past two weeks.  History of Present Illness: Mrs. James reports experiencing intermittent episodes of rapid  irregular heartbeats. She also describes feeling fatigued easily lately and notes shortness of breath with minor exertion  previously tolerable to her such as walking up the stairs to her apartment. She denies syncope  chest pain  cough  or swelling of limbs. She hasn't noticed any particular triggers for these episodes.  Past Medical History: She has a known medical history of hypertension and diabetes  both are controlled with medications. She also states that she previously underwent a cholecystectomy 15 years ago. No history of smoking or alcohol use.  Family History: Her father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 67 and her sister was just recently diagnosed with atrial fibrillation. No history of sudden cardiac deaths in the family.  Medications: She is currently taking Metformin for her diabetes and Lisinopril for her hypertension.  Review of Systems: General health fair  EENT normal  Chest pain negative  Palpitations positive  Shortness of breath positive  Musculoskeletal normal  No changes in bowel or urinary patterns.  Physical exam: Blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg  pulse is irregularly irregular at 98 bpm  respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute and room air saturation is 95%. Cardiovascular exam reveals a regular rate and rhythm without murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Respiratory exam shows clear breath sounds bilaterally.  Recommendations: Given her symptoms along with physical examination findings  her family history  and a history of hypertension  atrial fibrillation is a possibility. An EKG and echocardiogram along with laboratory tests including thyroid function tests will help confirm the diagnosis. Formulation of a treatment plan would be contingent on the results.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 68-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the clinic today with chief complaints of palpitations  fatigue  and mild dyspnea on exertion for the last one week. He describes his heart rate as being ""irregular"" and ""fast "" estimated to average around 110-120 beats per minute. He also reports an episodic feeling of light-headedness but denied any syncope.  Regarding his past medical history  he has a 10-year history of hypertension which is well controlled on lisinopril. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago and is managing it with metformin and dietary changes. He has a history of coronary artery disease for which he had an angioplasty done three years ago. He quit smoking ten years ago but has a 30-pack year history prior. He does not consume alcohol or use any illicit substances. There is no known history of clotting disorders or stroke in his personal or family history.  He lives with his wife and is a retired engineer. He is fairly active and usually goes for a walk daily. Besides the aforementioned medications  he takes low-dose aspirin daily  atorvastatin for cholesterol control and over-the-counter multivitamins. He is allergic to sulfa drugs.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Caucasian male presented at the clinic complaining of palpitations  shortness of breath  fatigue  lightheadedness  and occasional chest discomfort for the last few weeks. The symptoms have progressively worsened  interfering with his daily activities.   The patient has a known history of hypertension  diagnosed five years ago  well-controlled with amlodipine. He also has type 2 diabetes managed with metformin. He used to smoke but quit ten years ago. He consumes alcohol only socially. He also mentioned his father suffered from a 'heart rhythm problem'  but was not specific.  On physical examination  uneven pulse rate was noted. He was otherwise hemodynamically stable. His BMI was calculated to be 29  suggesting overweight status. Preliminary ECG suggested irregular heart rhythms consistent with atrial fibrillation. Further investigations were planned to confirm the diagnosis and identify any possible underlying predisposing factor.

Mr. Johnson  a 68-year-old African American male  presents to the clinic today with complaints of palpitations that have been occurring over the last month. He describes the sensation in his chest as ""fluttering or skipping beats"".  He also mentions experiencing episodes of unexplained fatigue  even with minimal physical exertion  and occasional light-headedness for the past 3 weeks. No chest pain  shortness of breath  or fainting episodes are reported. He denies any recent fevers  coughs or urinary symptoms.  In terms of past medical history  Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with hypertension 7 years ago and is currently on Lisinopril. He also has a history of Type II diabetes mellitus  which is well-controlled on metformin. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 71. He stopped smoking 10 years ago and drinks occasionally during social events. His last routine check-up with lab work was approximately 8 months ago.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Richardson is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  a retired businessman. He presents to the clinic complaining of intermittent episodes of palpitations  racing heart beats  feeling of fatigue and mild shortness of breath for the past few weeks.  Past Medical History: His past medical history reveals that he has been hypertensive  well-controlled on medication (Lisinopril) for the past 10 years. He also has type II Diabetes Mellitus  well-controlled on Metformin for the past 7 years. He has a history of hypercholesterolemia managed with statins. There is no known history of coronary artery disease  previous heart attack  valve disease  or stroke. He denies smoking  excessive alcohol  or any illicit drug use. His only previous surgery was an appendectomy 30 years ago.   Family history indicates that his father passed away at the age of 80 due to a massive stroke  his mother is alive and has Hypertension and his only sibling  a younger sister also has Hypertension and type II Diabetes Mellitus.  On physical examination  irregularly irregular pulse is noted. Electrocardiogram (ECG) done confirms the presence of atrial fibrillation.   He's been referred to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management of atrial fibrillation.

Patient Profile: Mr. Thompson  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  5'11""  weighing 200 pounds  retired lawyer.  Presenting Issue: Mr. Thompson presents with complaint of recurrent ""fluttering"" sensation in his chest over the past two months and feeling fatigued more often than usual. Additionally  he reports occasional shortness of breath and feeling lightheaded during his golf games.   Past Medical History: He has a history of high blood pressure controlled on medication (Losartan 50mg daily)  for which he has been under treatment since the past 20 years. He was diagnosed with Type II diabetes mellitus 10 years ago. His most recent HbA1c  1 month ago  was 7.2%. He has chronic lower back pain because of a slipped disc in the lumbar vertebra years ago. Also  he has hyperlipidemia managed with diet modification and Atorvastatin 20mg daily. There is no history of heart disease or strokes. History of one episode of right lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT) post-operatively (after back surgery) around 5 years ago  which was treated with Warfarin for six months.  Social History: Mr. Thompson drinks an occasional glass of wine  has smoked half-a-pack of cigarettes per day from his 20s until he quit 15 years ago. There is no history of illicit drug use. He is married  lives with his wife  and enjoys his regular games of golf.  Family History: His father died of a heart attack at the age of 80 and his mother has a history of hypertension and Alzheimer's disease. His younger brother had a pacemaker implanted at age 65 due to a slow heart rate (bradycardia).  Medication Reviews: Mr. Thompson is on Losartan 50mg for hypertension  Atorvastatin 20mg for hyperlipidemia  Metformin 1g twice daily for diabetes  and Tylenol for back pain. He also takes a multivitamin. He is adherent to all his medications.   Allergies: Mr. Thompson reports allergy to Penicillins (causes a rash).

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Anna Luther  a 75-year-old Caucasian female  presents to the clinic with a complaint of a sudden onset of heart palpitations that have been occurring for two days. She describes the palpitations as strangely irregular and sometimes very fast. Alongside this  she also reports intermittent episodes of mild chest discomfort  lightheadedness  and unusual fatigue.  Past Medical History reveals a long-standing issue of hypertension for which she takes Amlodipine 10mg daily  as well as type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with Metformin. She also had a surgical repair of a hip fracture 2 years ago. She has a no known drug allergies. She is a former smoker and quit 10 years ago. She consumes alcohol only on rare occasions.   Her family history is significant for heart disease  her father had a myocardial infarction at age 55. Her maternal grandmother had a stroke in her sixties.   She lives alone and is fairly independent with the support of her adult children who live nearby. She follows a balanced diet and does light exercises like walking daily.    Overall  she appears anxious due to her irregular heart rhythms. Her vitals reveal a blood pressure of 140/90  temperature of 98.6 Fahrenheit  respiration rate of 16 breaths per minute and irregularly irregular tachycardic heart rhythms at 110 beats per minute.

Patient Presentation:  I. Demographics: Mr. Perez  a 78-year-old Hispanic man  presents to the clinic with complaints of palpitations and occasional shortness of breath. He also mentions intermittent spells of fatigue.  II. History of Present Illness: The palpitations started approximately 6 months ago  gradually increasing in frequency and severity. He’s recently encountered multiple instances of feeling unusually tired after light physical activities  like gardening. He denies any chest pain  syncope  dizziness  or orthopnea.  III. Past Medical History: Mr. Perez was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia about 10 years ago. Consistently  he's adhering to his prescribed antihypertensive and lipid-lowering therapies. His hypertension has been moderately controlled. Also  he underwent an appendectomy 30 years ago.  IV. Family History: His father died of a stroke at the age of 81. His mother had diabetes and passed away from complications related to it. His sister living is healthy  but his younger brother was diagnosed with coronary artery disease five years back.  V. Social History: He’s a retired school teacher  married with 3 grown-up children. He used to smoke in his youth but quit 20 years ago. Only consumes alcohol occasionally  during social gatherings.  VI. Review of Systems: Mr. Perez has had a decrease in appetite and unintentional weight loss in the last few months  but denies fever  night sweats  or frequent urinations. There is no history of any neurologic  gastrointestinal  musculoskeletal  or dermatologic complaints. He further denies any issues related to vision  hearing  or memory.

Patient Presentation:  A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic reporting recent episodes of irregular and sometimes rapid heartbeats. The patient complains of associated symptoms including shortness of breath  intermittent dizziness  fatigue  and a sensation of pounding in his chest.  He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  controlled with lisinopril 10mg daily  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed with metformin 500mg twice daily. He also reports a prior diagnosis of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) and has been a smoker for over 50 years.  The patient lives alone  is able to perform all activities of daily living  and reports moderate alcohol consumption. The patient's family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  with his father suffering from a myocardial infarction at the age of 65. The patient adheres to a poor diet with low levels of physical activity and admits to lack of compliance with medications due to forgetfulness.  On examination  his blood pressure is noted to be 150/90 mmHg  pulse irregularly irregular  and a rate of 90 beats per minute. His respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. Cardiovascular examination reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm with no murmur  rub  or gallop. His breath sounds are diminished bilaterally with occasional wheezes.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Paul McDonald is a 63-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of palpitations and occasional fatigue for the last several days. He mentions that the palpitations are mostly irregular and continuous  and are associated with lightheadedness  especially after physical exertion.   The patient’s past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which are well controlled with medication. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. His father had a stroke at the age of 73  and his mother had heart disease. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  syncope  lower extremity swelling or recent weight gain.  His list of current medications includes Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Simvastatin for hypercholesterolemia. He is allergic to Penicillin  which causes him to have a rash.  Upon examination  his vital signs are within normal limits  and his BMI falls under overweight. His heart rhythm is irregularly irregular without murmurs. Physical exam is otherwise unremarkable.   Previous blood work-up done six months ago showed good glycemic control and optimal lipid profile. ECG at that time was normal. Assessment raises suspicion for atrial fibrillation  and follow up investigations including repeat ECG and echocardiography are planned.   He has no existing diagnosis of thyroid diseases  renal diseases or obstructive sleep apnea which are common comorbid conditions with Atrial Fibrillation. He will also be screened for these potential risk factors.

Patient Demographic Information:  Name: Mrs. Jones Sex: Female Age: 78 years Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired school teacher  Presenting Complaint:  Mrs. Jones presents with complaints of palpitations  fatigue  and occasional shortness of breath  especially on exertion  over the past 3 weeks.  Past Medical History:  Mrs. Jones has a known history of hypertension for which she has been on Lisinopril 10mg daily for the past 10 years. She was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago  which is being managed with metformin. She has been previously hospitalised for a transient ischemic attack 2 years ago. Her father died from a stroke at 85  and her mother died from heart failure at 84.  Social History:  She is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol. She lives with her son and his family. She enjoys gardening but has recently found it more difficult due to the fatigue and shortness of breath.  Current medications:   Lisinopril 10mg daily  Metformin 500mg twice daily.  Examination:  Upon examination  her pulse is irregularly irregular  and her blood pressure is 142/85. Her cardiovascular exam is otherwise unremarkable.   Preliminary Diagnosis:  The clinical presentation alongside her past medical history suggests new-onset Atrial Fibrillation. Further diagnostic tests  including an electrocardiogram (ECG)  will be needed to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male named Thomas presents to the clinic complaining of an intermittent rapid heartbeat  palpitations  and occasional mild shortness of breath for the last three weeks. These symptoms occur erratically  sometimes while resting  and they tend to self-resolve after a few minutes. Thomas describes his episodes as his heart suddenly starting to ""race and flutter"".  He has a known history of hypertension for 10 years  well-controlled on Losartan 50mg daily. Thomas was also diagnosed with Type II diabetes 8 years ago  managed with Metformin. The patient has an extensive smoking history  with an estimate of 40 pack-years. He quit smoking about 5 years ago. He has a familial history of cardiac diseases with his father suffering from a heart attack at the age of 70.  Thomas complains of occasional tiredness but denies any chest pain  dizziness  or syncope. He admits to occasional alcohol consumption but denies any illicit drug use. He was compliant with his medications but admits poor dietary habits and a sedentary lifestyle.  This combination of symptoms  combined with Thomas's age  hypertension  diabetes  smoking history  and family history of cardiac diseases  raises suspicion for atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation:  A 72-year-old  Caucasian  retired teacher  Mrs. A  presenting to the office with complaints of rapid  irregular heart palpitations and fatigue. These symptoms have been occurring intermittently for the last two months.  Past Medical History:   Mrs. A is a non-smoker  moderate alcohol drinker  has a BMI of 28 and she lives an active lifestyle. She has a significant past medical history of hypertension diagnosis 10 years ago  currently being treated with Lisinopril. She also has a history of hyperlipidemia for which she hasn't been compliant with her prescribed Statins. She has had no prior surgeries and her immunizations are up to date. Her mother died at the age of 80 due to congestive heart failure and her father died at the age of 85 due to stroke. She has a brother aged 70 who recently had bypass surgery. There is no known family history of any genetic disorders.   Concerning medications  she is currently only on Lisinopril 10mg daily  but admits non-compliance to prescribed Statins for her hyperlipidemia. Also  she takes multivitamins daily. She has no known drug allergies.

Patient Profile: Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. C  living in a suburban setting  retired from his career as a university professor.   Chief complaint: He presents with complaints of occasional palpitations and shortness of breath during his daily walks that has been progressively worsening over the past 3 weeks.   History of presenting illness: According to him  the episodes of palpitations are sudden  last for a few hours  usually stop on their own  but have been happening more frequently. The shortness of breath has been more frequent during his walks and he's had to cut his walks short due to tiredness. He mentions a7-lb unintentional weight loss in the past few months and has been feeling increasingly fatigued.   Past Medical History: He has a history of high blood pressure for the past 10 years and is currently taking medication (Lisinopril 20mg daily). He has also been a type II diabetic for the past 5 years  with HbA1c results consistently around 7.2%. He is not a smoker but admits to drinking a glass of wine daily with dinner. He has no history of heart disease in his family.  Physical Examination: On examination  the heart rhythm seems to be rapid and irregular; heart rate measured at 102 beats/min and blood pressure at 132/88 mmHg. No elevated JVP or ankle edema is identified.   This patient's presentation is suggestive of atrial fibrillation (AFib)  most likely due to high BP and type II diabetes  both of which he has had for several years: A Holter monitor to capture episodes of AFib  EKG  and echocardiogram for structural heart disease evaluation may be needed.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. J is a 70-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the clinic with a chief complaint of palpitations and intermittent shortness of breath for the past two weeks. The patient also mentions episodes of light-headedness and fatigue recently. He denies chest pain or syncope.  He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago but admits to occasional alcohol use. The patient's father had a history of stroke in his late 70s.   His current medications include Losartan 50mg daily  Metformin 500mg twice daily  and Atorvastatin 20mg at bedtime. He has been compliant with his medications and his blood pressure and sugar levels have been reasonably well controlled.  On examination  his blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg  pulse is irregularly irregular at 100 bpm  respirations 18 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. His body mass index is 29 kg/m^2.   Cardiovascular exam reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm without murmurs  rubs or gallops. Respiratory  abdominal  and neurological examinations are within normal limits.  Mr. J is alert and oriented  with no deficits in his cranial nerves  motor and sensory system. His recent blood tests show his kidney function and electrolytes are stable  and HbA1c is 7.1%.  This patient with significant cardiovascular risk factors presents with symptoms suggestive of atrial fibrillation including palpitations  irregular pulse  intermittent breathlessness  light-headedness  and fatigue. Further diagnostic testing including an EKG and possibly an echocardiogram is warranted.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 78-year-old Caucasian male  a retired accountant  who presents in the emergency department with a chief complaint of fatigue and palpitations that have been ongoing for the past two days. He has a background history of hypertension  for which he has been on a prescription medication for the last ten years; Lisinopril 20mg daily. He also has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed with Metformin 500mg twice daily for the past eight years.  Additionally  he mentions a recent rapid weight gain and shortness of breath on exertion. He complained of intermittent rapid heartbeats in the past month  which previously resolved on their own but this time persisted. He denies chest pain  discomfort or dizziness. Of note  he is a former smoker having quit ten years ago and denies any alcohol or illicit drug use. Family history includes a brother who had a myocardial infarction at the age of 65  and both parents had hypertension. He is married  lives with his wife  and they have two adult children. His immunizations are up-to-date.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith  a 76-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the cardiology clinic with chief complaints of recurrent palpitations  fatigue  and occasional shortness of breath that have grown progressively worse over the past few weeks. He reports waking up in the middle of the night due to a sensation of rapid  fluttering heartbeat  which he describes as ""unsettling"". He also mentions occasional lightheadedness but denies any incidences of syncope or chest discomfort.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension for more than 10 years  type 2 diabetes mellitus for over 8 years  and an episode of transient ischemic attack (TIA) 3 years ago. His last episode of atrial fibrillation was noted two years ago was managed with rate control and anticoagulation  but unfortunately  he has been non-compliant with his medication regimen. He has never smoked or consumed alcohol. His exercise capacity has gradually declined over the past few months. He has been under stress due to the recent death of his spouse.  Medications:  He takes metformin (500 mg twice daily) for his diabetes  amlodipine (10mg daily) for hypertension  and was formerly on warfarin for his past atrial fibrillation  but he admits to missing doses frequently over the past few months. His medication compliance has been poor due to multiple factors including forgetfulness and financial constraints.  Family History:  Withdrawn due to the patient being adopted  but he mentions that both of his adoptive parents had heart-related issues.   Social History:  The patient is a retired mail carrier  widowed  lives alone  and has two adult children who live out of state. He denies smoking  alcohol or drug abuse. He used to be very active  go for regular walks  and attend a local seniors' gym  but his recent symptoms have limited his activities.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired school teacher who presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations  shortness of breath  and fatigue. He reports that these symptoms started a few days ago and have gradually worsened. He describes the palpitations as ""my heart skipping beats"" and occasional rapid heart beats for the past four days. He denies any chest pain  dizziness  syncope  or recent illness.   He has a medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes for which he has been on Lisinopril 20mg daily and Metformin 850mg twice daily for the last 7 years. His blood glucose levels were optimally controlled. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially. He maintains a regular exercise regimen which involves light walking for 30 minutes every day. He also reports no significant allergy history.  His family medical history reveals that his father had a “heart condition  possibly atrial fibrillation”  but he is unsure. On cardiovascular examination  his pulse was irregularly irregular  the first heart sound varies in intensity and no murmurs were heard. The remainder of his physical examination was unremarkable. ECG performed confirmed atrial fibrillation.   An initial diagnosis of atrial fibrillation has been made based on his clinical presentation and diagnostic findings. He has been admitted for further investigations and management.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Carter is a 70-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the clinic with complaints of palpitations  shortness of breath  and occasional dizziness for the past two weeks.   Demographics Details:   He is a retired engineer  living in the suburbs with his wife. He is a non-smoker  moderate alcohol consumer (2 drinks per week)  and has no known drug allergies.  Past Medical History:   His past medical history is significant for hypertension  for which he is on Lisinopril 10mg daily  and hyperlipidemia managed by Atorvastatin 20mg daily. He also reveals that he had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) five years ago. His family history is notable for his father who had suffered from a stroke at the age of 75.   The patient does not report previous episodes of palpitations or similar symptoms. He also denies having chest pain  syncope  or swelling in the extremities. He admits to non-compliance with his medications occasionally.   On physical examination  the patient shows an irregularly irregular pulse but with no obvious signs of heart failure. His blood pressure readings in the clinic were marginally raised. A preliminary EKG on-site reveals atrial fibrillation. The rest of his physical examination is unremarkable.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 75-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the clinic with symptoms of irregular and rapid heartbeats  fatigue  shortness of breath  and mild dizziness. He also reported having occasional bout of mild chest discomfort. The symptoms have been occurring intermittently over the past two weeks.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both well-controlled with medications. He suffered a mild ischemic stroke three years ago with full recovery. He also has a history of occasional episodes of palpitations over the past five years  which were previously diagnosed as premature atrial contractions. He is a former smoker and quit about 10 years ago  and denies any recreational drug use. Family history is significant for cardiovascular disease; his father had a myocardial infarction in his 70s.  Current Medications:  1) Lisinopril 20mg daily for hypertension 2) Rosuvastatin 10mg at night for hyperlipidemia 3) Aspirin 81mg daily for stroke prophylaxis  Social History:  Mr. Doe is retired  lives with his wife  and has 2 grown children. He is independent with all activities of daily living. He consumes alcohol occasionally - one to two drinks per week. He has no known drug allergies.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 72-year-old Caucasian male presenting today with complaints of fluctuating  intermittent palpitations in his chest for the past one week. He also reports increasing shortness of breath on exertion as well as feeling lightheaded at times. He never experienced any severe chest pain or syncope. His symptoms are associated with mild fatigue.   Past medical history shows the patient has been hypertensive for the last 10 years controlled on Lisinopril 10 milligrams daily and has a history of type-2 diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin. He is a former smoker  quit 15 years ago  and drinks alcohol socially. He is not on anticoagulation. He has no known history of heart disease or arrhythmias or family history of early heart disease. The patient's father died of a stroke at the age of 80.   On examination  his heart rate was irregular  and blood pressure was slightly elevated at 145/85. On auscultation  an irregularly irregular rhythm was noted.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 75-year-old African American male  presents in the office with complaints of palpitations  shortness of breath  fatigue  and intermittent light-headedness over the last two weeks. He reports feeling an irregular heartbeat  which is causing him significant discomfort.   He has a significant past medical history including  hypertension controlled with Lisinopril and Metropolol  Type 2 diabetes managed with Metformin  previous transient ischemic attack (TIA) five years ago  and he underwent coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery seven years ago. There is no known history of any thyroid disease or alcoholism.   His social history reveals he is a former smoker  quit 10 years ago after a 30-year pack history. He drinks socially only occasionally. He is divorced  lives alone  and is a retired military officer.  On examination  he has irregularly irregular pulse and blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg. EKG reveals no acute ST/T wave changes but shows irregular rhythms suggesting atrial fibrillation. Chest X-ray  blood counts  thyroid function test  and renal function are ordered for further assessment.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Howard Mitchell is a 78-year-old African-American male  retired welder  who presents to the clinic complaining of increasing episodes of palpitations and shortness of breath on exertion for the past two weeks. He has also noticed fatigue and a mild decrease in exercise tolerance within the same period. He denies chest pain  lightheadedness  syncope  or orthopnea. His past medical history includes controlled hypertension for 10 years  coronary artery disease for which he underwent angioplasty 6 years ago  and type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin for 5 years. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history but quit smoking 10 years ago. He occasionally drinks alcohol  but denies illicit drug use. His father died of myocardial infarction at age 82 and his mother had a stroke at age 77. His medications include lisinopril  metformin  aspirin  and atorvastatin. He is up-to-date with his immunizations. He lives with his wife and has strong social and family support. He has no known drug allergies.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Allen Johnson is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  diabetes type II and hypercholesterolemia. He has presented today complaining of intermittent palpitations and fatigue that has gradually increased over the past few weeks. He also noticed that he is getting out of breath with exertion  which is unusual for him. He denied chest pain  nausea  vomiting or feeling faint. He is unsure when these symptoms started exactly but thinks it may have been around a month ago. Examination of Mr. Johnson reveals an irregularly irregular pulse. He has no history of smoking  and his father had a stroke at the age of 72.  Additional information:  He is retired from a career in sales  he is married  and has a stable living situation. His current medications are metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. He is allergic to penicillin causing a rash. He denies recent travel or any changes in his diet or alcohol intake  and denies any illicit drug use. He has never had surgery.   Family history is positive for heart disease  with his father dying from a heart attack at the age of 75 and his mother living with chronic heart failure. He is compliant with his medications and visits his primary care provider regularly for his chronic conditions but has not seen a cardiologist.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of ongoing intermittent palpitations and shortness of breath for the past couple of months. He also reports occasional dizziness and mild fatigue  but no chest pain  syncope  or episodes of loss of consciousness.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension for which he takes Lisinopril 5mg daily and type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with Metformin 500mg twice daily. He has no history of heart disease or stroke  but his father had a myocardial infarction in his early 70's. The patient's only surgical history is a left hip replacement 10 years ago.   He is a retired mechanic  has been married for 35 years  with two children. He is a former smoker having quit 15 years ago and reports moderate alcohol use (1-2 drinks per day). He does not use illicit drugs. He lives with his wife  has no known drug allergies  and his immunizations are up to date.  On a previous casual check-up six months back  his vital signs were within normal range  with a blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg and a regular heart rate of 70 beats per minute.  Today  his blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg  pulse 100 beats per minute with irregular rhythm  respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 98% on room air  and body mass index is 28 kg/m2.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic with complaints of intermittent palpitations  fatigue  and episodes of lightheadedness for the past 3 weeks. He also reports experiencing shortness of breath following moderate exertion. He denies chest pain  syncope  fever  or recent illnesses.  Demographics: The patient is a retired engineer and lives with his wife. He is a former smoker  quit 10 years ago  and reportedly drinks alcohol socially. He denies any illicit drug use. There are no known drug allergies. He follows a balanced diet and does mild exercise  but has a sedentary lifestyle overall.  Relevant Past Medical History: The patient has a history of Hypertension  and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  both being managed by medication for the past eight years. He also has a family history of heart diseases  with his father having a myocardial infarction at the age of 66. The patient's current medications include Metformin 1000 mg twice a day and Losartan 50 mg once daily.  The patient is up to date on all routine health maintenance measures. He had a negative colonoscopy at age 50 and again at age 60  and a normal lipid profile at a wellness check last year.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Doe  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic with complaints of intermittent palpitations  shortness of breath  and fatigue which have been worsening over the past month. Mr. Doe notes these symptoms are more prominent with exertion and alleviates with rest.  John is a retired lawyer  does moderate exercises thrice a week and doesn't take alcohol or smoke. He had a past medical history that is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes mellitus type 2  and heart failure with preserved ejection fraction  all of which are well controlled on his current medications (Lisinopril 10 mg OD  Metformin 500 mg BD  and Atorvastatin 10 mg OD). There is no known family history of early heart disease.   On physical examination  he has irregularly irregular cardiac rhythms on auscultation. His heart rate is 100 beats per minute  and blood pressure is 135/80 mmHg.  Given his age  symptomology  and medical history  atrial fibrillation was suspected.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 67-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the clinic with a chief complaint of ""feeling my heart race"" on and off for the past week. He notes episodes seem to last anywhere from a few minutes to several hours. Other symptoms he reports include fatigue and occasional dizziness. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncope.   Demographics: Mr. Smith is a retired mail carrier and lives at home with his wife. He quit smoking 15 years ago and consumes alcohol socially on weekends. He has a BMI of 28. He has no known drug allergies.  Past Medical History: Significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both diagnosed 5 years ago and have been managed with lifestyle modification and medication (amlodipine 5mg daily for hypertension and atorvastatin 20mg daily for hyperlipidemia). He also has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) which is managed with Omeprazole.  Family History: Mr. Smith's mother died at 76 years from ischemic heart disease. He has two older siblings; his sister had a stroke at age 68 and brother has type 2 diabetes mellitus.   Review of Systems: Mr. Smith reports occasional difficulty sleeping and occasional mild epigastric discomfort controlled by his GERD medication. He denies headache  fever  cough  or any genitourinary symptoms.  Physical Examination: Mr. Smith is alert and oriented with unlabored breathing. Vital signs show blood pressure of 143/88 mm Hg  heart rate of 98 bpm with irregular rhythm  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and normal oxygen saturation at room air. Cardiovascular exam shows an irregularly irregular rhythm without murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Rest of the examination is normal.  Plan: The clinical picture and physical examination are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Plan to obtain an ECG to confirm diagnosis. Consult cardiology for further management. The patient will be scheduled for anticoagulation therapy if diagnosis is confirmed  considering the presence of risk factors for stroke.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 65-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the ER with complaints of palpitations  mild shortness of breath  and a two-week history of intermittent light-headedness. He described an irregular  rapid heartbeat  often alternating with periods of normal rhythm. On cross-examination  he noted a gradual decrease in exercise capacity and fatigue over the past few months.   Despite these symptoms  Mr. Johnson denies any chest pain  syncope or presyncope. His past medical history is significant for hypertension  which has been under control with lisinopril for the past 15 years  and Type II Diabetes Mellitus managed with metformin for the past 10 years. He does not use tobacco  drinks alcohol socially  and has a low activity level due to retired status.  Review of systems has been largely negative except for the aforementioned symptoms. His family history is significant for cardiac disease  with his father passing away from myocardial infarction at an early age.  On examination  his pulse was irregular and rapid  blood pressure was 152/90 mmHg  and respiratory rate was 20 breaths/min. Auscultation revealed an irregularly irregular rhythm but no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Peripheral pulses were present and lung fields were clear. A 12 lead ECG demonstrated atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.
