The patient's presentation is consistent with symptomatic atrial fibrillation  and appropriate further diagnostic and therapeutic steps should be considered.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Davis is a 72-year old Caucasian male who presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of episodic palpitations and occasional shortness of breath for the past two months. The palpitations are irregular  and he describes them as his heart ""fluttering"" in his chest. He notes that they occur without any clear precipitating factors and may last from a few minutes up to a couple of hours. During these episodes  he sometimes feels light-headed but has not lost consciousness. He denies chest pain  nausea  vomiting  or sweating.  He has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he takes Lisinopril 10mg daily and Atorvastatin 20mg daily. He also reports occasional use of Aspirin 81mg for occasional headaches. He is a former smoker with a 30-pack-year history  but quit 10 years ago. He consumes alcohol socially  about 1-2 drinks per week. He has no known drug allergies.  The patient's family history is notable for cardiovascular diseases  with both his father and elder brother having suffered from myocardial infarctions in their 60s. His mother had a stroke at the age of 70. The patient has not had any surgeries previously.  On physical exam  his blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg  heart rate is irregularly irregular at 98 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. His BMI is 28. Upon auscultation  irregular heart rhythm with no murmur was noted. Lungs were clear. Rest of the examination was unremarkable.  The symptoms  coupled with his past medical and family history  are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. This needs to be confirmed with an electrocardiogram (ECG) and further management should be planned according to the results of ECG and other relevant investigations.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Carlos Gomez is a 68-year-old high school principal  born and raised in Tucson  Arizona. He describes himself as a smoker who consumes alcohol occasionally and lives a fairly sedentary lifestyle due to his work. Mr. Gomez has a previous medical history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2. He also has a family history of cardiac issues  as his father suffered from heart disease and passed away due to myocardial infarction.  Three days ago  Mr. Gomez started experiencing intermittent palpitations  sensations of rapid fluttering in his chest  and mild breathlessness  which particularly exacerbated when he climbed the stairs to his apartment. Additionally  he reports having poor exercise tolerance  which has worsened over the past year  although he attributed it to age and work stress.  He has no history of chest pain  syncope  or edema in ankles but admits to feeling fatigued more often. He admits that he has been noncompliant with his antihypertensive and diabetes medication off and on due to forgetfulness and busy work schedule.  Upon examination  his pulse is found to be irregularly irregular  with mild hypertension. The rest of the cardiovascular and respiratory examination is unremarkable  a possible indicator of atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 72-year-old African-American male presenting today with complaints of intermittent palpitations  fatigue  and shortness of breath  with symptoms more noticeable over the last two weeks. His symptoms are exacerbated by physical activity but relieved by rest. He mentions that his palpitations are irregular and fast and often accompanied by mild light-headedness.  Mr. Smith has a known medical history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has been managing these conditions for approximately ten years with regular medications (metoprolol for hypertension and metformin for diabetes) and reports good compliance. Besides  he has been a smoker for around 20 years but quit ten years ago. He does not consume alcohol. His father had ischemic heart disease  and his mother had a stroke.  He is retired and lives with his wife. He has an active lifestyle and enjoys walking with his dog and swimming. However  his current symptoms limit his activities. He also reports difficulty in climbing the stairs at home due to recent dyspnea.   Overall  Mr. Smith's presenting symptoms and medical history suggest the possibility of a cardiac arrhythmia like atrial fibrillation. He might require investigations  including an ECG and possibly an echocardiogram  to confirm the diagnosis and guide the subsequent course of management.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of controlled hypertension who presents to the clinic today complaining of persistent heart palpitations since the last three days. He reports no chest pain  dyspnea  dizziness  or syncope. He has no known drug allergies. His only medication is ramipril for blood pressure control. He has a 30-pack year smoking history having quit 5 years ago and drinks socially. He is retired from his job as a school teacher and lives with his wife. There is no family history of any cardiac diseases. Review of systems is otherwise non-contributory. He admits compliance with his antihypertensive medication  diet  and exercise regimen.  On examination  his pulse is irregularly irregular  and his blood pressure is 142/86 mm Hg. He has no cardiac murmurs or extra heart sounds. His lungs are clear  and his abdomen is soft and non-tender. Electrocardiography reveals atrial fibrillation with an average heart rate of 76 beats per minute. Further workup  including echocardiography and thyroid function tests  are pending.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 68-year-old African-American male presenting to the office with reports of fatigue  episodic heart palpitations  and shortness of breath exacerbated during exertion. On further inquiry  Mr. Smith also mentions intermittent lightheadedness and occasional bouts of dizziness  especially while engaging in his daily walks. There were no instances of chest pain  syncopational episodes  or any symptoms suggestive of infection.   Past Medical History:  The patient was diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus approximately five years ago  for which he is prescribed Losartan and Metformin respectively. Additionally  he is regularly taking low-dose Aspirin as prophylaxis for cardiovascular disease  which he started after his brother was diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease. He quit smoking 10 years ago and reports moderate alcohol consumption. He has no report of surgical intervention.  Family History:  Mr. Smith’s mother had a stroke at age 87 and his elder brother was diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease at age 55. His father passed away at the age of 72 due to complications linked to COPD.  Social History:  Mr. Smith is a retired electrician and lives with his wife. He has quit smoking 10 years ago but consumed alcohol moderately. He is physically active  enjoys daily walking and playing golf.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Smith  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department complaining of palpitations  shortness of breath  and fatigue. He stated that these symptoms have persisted for the past 2 days and have progressively worsened. He denies chest pain and lightheadedness but reports occasional episodes of dizziness. He previously was very active but has stopped his daily walks due to these symptoms.   His past medical history includes hypertension  for which he takes Lisinopril  and type 2 diabetes under the control of oral metformin. He has no history of heart disease but admits to a past history of excessive alcohol consumption during his early adult years. He is a former smoker and quit 15 years ago. He has no known drug allergies.  On examination  his blood pressure is 145/88 mmHg  pulse rate is irregularly irregular at 110  and oxygen saturation is at 94% on room air. His lung fields are clear. Cardiac auscultation reveals a rapid irregular rhythm.   A 12-lead EKG confirms atrial fibrillation. Other lab reports including complete blood count  electrolytes  and cardiac enzymes are pending.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Peterson is a 68-year-old African American male with a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes. He has come to the clinic complaining of a two weeks history of increased fatigue  episodes of dizziness  and intermittent rapid heartbeats  which he describes as ""feeling his heart fluttering"" in his chest. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncope.   His hypertension and hyperlipidemia have been well controlled with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively and his blood sugars are usually within acceptable ranges with management via Metformin. In his family history  his father had a myocardial infarction at age 62.  Upon physical examination  he had irregularly irregular pulse and blood pressure was mildly elevated. EKG was ordered which confirmed atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 75-year-old Caucasian male who presents with complaints of palpitations and mild shortness of breath for the past two weeks. He also mentioned having intermittent bouts of dizziness. He reports no chest pain  but he does feel tired more frequently and has had difficulty completing his daily walks.  Past Medical History: Hypertension  Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  and Hyperlipidemia.  Family History: His father died of a heart attack at the age of 72  and his mother had a stroke at age 78.  Medications: Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Simvastatin for hyperlipidemia.  Allergies: None  Habits: He quit smoking 10 years ago but used to smoke a pack a day for 30 years prior to quitting. He admits to drinking two glasses of red wine every evening.  Upon physical examination  his heart rhythm was irregular  with a pulse rate fluctuating between 85-150 beats per minute. His blood pressure was 140/85 mm Hg. The patient also has an audible third heart sound on auscultation.    The patient was sent for an electrocardiogram (EKG) which demonstrated irregularly irregular rhythm  absent P waves  and variable ventricular response  consistent with atrial fibrillation. Further lab tests and management were planned accordingly.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 64 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Job: Retired engineer  Presenting complaint: Palpitations and shortness of breath that started a few hours ago.  History of presenting complaint:  Mr. Doe reports feeling an irregular beating sensation in his chest  accompanied by dyspnea on exertion since this morning. He denies chest pain  syncope or pre-syncope.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a medical history of hypertension  for which he takes Lisinopril 20mg daily. No known history of heart disease or stroke. No previous episodes of similar symptoms. He has no known drug allergies.   Family history: His father had atrial fibrillation and a stroke in his late 70s.   Lifestyle: He quit smoking two years ago; previously  he had been a pack-a-day smoker for 40 years. He drinks alcohol socially and infrequently. He does not use any illicit drugs. He exercises moderately.  Review of Systems: He denies any recent sickness or weight loss. He reports occasional erectile dysfunction and fatigue.  Current medications: Lisinopril 20mg once daily.  Summary: Mr. Doe  a 64-year-old Caucasian male with a past history of hypertension is presenting with new onset palpitations and exertional dyspnea. Given his symptoms and his family history  atrial fibrillation is suspected. An ECG and further cardiac evaluation will be required.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Joan Peters  a 67-year-old Caucasian female  presents to the clinic complaining of intermittent palpitations accompanied by occasional shortness of breath and light-headedness episodes for the past few weeks. She also reports a sensation of rapid  irregular heartbeats  primarily noticeable at night and during periods of rest.   Joan's past medical history is relevant for well-controlled hypertension on hydrochlorothiazide for 15 years  type 2 diabetes managed with metformin for 10 years  and hyperlipidemia controlled with atorvastatin for seven years. She is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol.   Her father had a history of heart disease (myocardial infarction at age 72). Joan has been post-menopausal for about 17 years and is typically physically active  walking around the neighborhood regularly and doing lightweight workouts thrice a week.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Thompson is a 72-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the clinic with complaints of palpitations  fatigue  and intermittent lightheadedness. He describes his heart as ""racing and skipping beats"" for the past several weeks. The episodes are sporadic  happening without any identifiable triggers  and may last for several minutes to a few hours.   He has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which are generally well-controlled with medications  i.e.  Lisinopril and Metformin  respectively. He also has a history of smoking for 45 years but quit a decade ago. Mr. Thompson admits to moderate alcohol consumption. He has no known drug allergies. He denies any chest pain  leg swelling  shortness of breath  or syncope.   His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 75  and his mother had a stroke at 82. He is retired  lives with his wife  and their lifestyle is moderately sedentary.   On examination  his irregular pulse and absence of heart murmur are noted. Further investigation  by EKG shows irregularly irregular rhythm with absence of distinct P waves  consistent with atrial fibrillation. Other clinical examinations were unremarkable.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 72 year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic with a three-day history of palpitations that he describes as an irregular ""fluttering"" in his chest. He additionally reports feeling fatigued and occasionally lightheaded  but denies experiencing chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncope. He does not report any recent changes in weight  appetite  or any other systemic symptoms.   He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  treated with Lisinopril  and a history of smoking for 25 years  but he quit 15 years ago. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father had a myocardial infarction at age 68 and his older brother was recently diagnosed with angina.  On physical examination  his blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg  heart rate is irregularly irregular  ranging from 80 to 115 bpm  respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute  and his oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. His BMI is 27 kg/m2. Cardiovascular exam reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm without murmurs  rubs  or gallops. His lung examination is unremarkable and other systems were within normal limits.   An ECG is performed which shows absence of p waves with irregular ventricular response  consistent with Atrial Fibrillation. The patient is admitted for further management and anticoagulation therapy is initiated. A cardiology consult is ordered for possible rhythm control strategies.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Gerald Thompson  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department complaining of heart palpitations and shortness of breath for the past three days. His palpitations are irregular and often rapid  which produce a sensation of his heart ""fluttering"" in his chest. Accompanied is a light-headed feeling and periodic bouts of mild fatigue. He denied experiencing chest pain  heavy sweating  nausea or syncope. Specifically stated that he is ""just not feeling right"".  Mr. Thompson is a former smoker who quit smoking 8 years ago  with a smoking history of 30 pack years. He drinks alcohol occasionally and denies recreational drug use. The patient has a significant past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years and hypertension. Daily medications include metformin 500 mg twice a day  lisinopril 10 mg once daily  and aspirin 81 mg once daily.  His last regular appointment with his primary care provider was 2 months ago  and at that time  there were no significant changes in his health status. There is no known history of cardiovascular disease in the family. However  his father had a type 2 diabetes mellitus and died from complications related to the disease. He lives alone and is widowed with 2 grown-up children.  The patient's history and presenting symptoms are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. A confirmatory diagnosis will require further investigation and diagnostic testing including an electrocardiogram (ECG).

Patient Information: Mr. Jones  a 68-year-old African-American male  presented to my office today complaining of new onset palpitations  occasional shortness of breath  and fatigue over the last week.   Past Medical History: Mr. Jones has a history of controlled hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. Family history reveals a father with heart disease (myocardial infarction at age 60).  Medication: Atenolol 50mg (for hypertension)  Metformin 1000mg (for diabetes).  Review of Systems: No other complaints apart from episodes of increased heart rate with an irregular rhythm  fatigue and shortness of breath. No history of chest pain  syncope  or sudden cardiac death in the family. A diet rich in high cholesterol and fatty food. Exercise levels minimal with mainly sedentary behavior.  Physical examination: On examination  blood pressure is 138/88 mm Hg. Irregular rhythm was noticed with a rate of approximately 96 bpm. Rest of the physical exam is unremarkable.  Prior Diagnostic Results: Last EKG done a year ago was normal  recent lab results reveal a controlled HbA1c of 7.1%. His serum total cholesterol was 200 mg/dL and LDL was 130 mg/dL.  Clinical Impression: The clinical picture is suggestive of atrial fibrillation and further investigations are needed for confirmation and management.

Patient Information: John Doe  68 year-old Hispanic male presents at the clinic.   Presenting Complaint: Patient complains about intermittent palpitations over the past 2 months  occasional dizziness  and shortness of breath following minimal physical exertion.  Past Medical History: Established diagnosis of hypertension for 10 years. History of myocardial infarction (confirming Coronary Artery Disease) 2 years ago and managed with lifestyle changes and medications (e.g.  statins  flopidogrel). Prior to this  he had been in a relatively good health  except for well-controlled asthma with inhaled corticosteroids. Non-smoker but has significant alcohol history of about 6-8 beers daily for roughly 20 years.  Current Medication: Taking daily doses of Amlodipine 10mg  Simvastatin 20mg  and Clopidogrel 75mg. Also takes Ventolin (Salbutamol) inhaler as needed for his asthma.  Physical Examination: Blood Pressure is 145/95 mmHg  irregular pulse rate around 110 BPM  respiration rate 18 breaths/min.   Tests and Evaluation: The ECG demonstrated Atrial Fibrillation (AF) with a ventricular rate of approximately 110 BPM. Chest X-ray  renal and thyroid function test results are pending.  Plan: Further diagnostic tests  specialist consultation  potential modification of management plan  and strict monitoring. Lifestyle and medication advice given to the patient.

Patient Presentation:  A 75-year-old African-American male presents to the outpatient clinic with a six-week history of palpitations  fatigue  and occasional shortness of breath. He denies chest pain  syncope  or dizziness.   Past medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  and hypertension  all of which have been well-controlled with metformin  atorvastatin  and lisinopril respectively. He has no history of smoking  alcohol consumption  or illicit drug use. No history of allergies or previous surgeries. His family history includes father who died from stroke  and mother with hypertension.  On physical examination  he appears to be in moderate distress due to his symptoms. Vital signs show a blood pressure of 140/85 mmHg  a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute  temperature within normal limit  but an irregular heart rate ranging from 78 to 113 beats/min. Cardiovascular examination reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm without any heart murmurs  gallops  or rubs.  An ECG confirms atrial fibrillation with a variable ventricular response. Subsequent echocardiogram shows mild left ventricular hypertrophy and minimal mitral regurgitation but normal left ventricular function without any clot in the atria.  The patient is diagnosed with non-valvular atrial fibrillation. His CHA2DS2VASc score is calculated as 3  considering age  hypertension  and diabetes mellitus putting him at intermediate risk for stroke. After discussing benefits and risks  patient agrees to start on anticoagulation. He is started on apixaban and is referred for rate control with a beta-blocker. The patient is also referred for possible cardioversion in the future after being on anticoagulation for at least three weeks. His condition is to be monitored closely during follow-up visits.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Smith is a 75-year-old Caucasian male presenting with complaints of palpitations and intermittent shortness of breath over the past two weeks. These episodes last for minutes to hours and resolve spontaneously. He denies any chest pain  light-headedness  or syncope.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a known medical history of hypertension managed well with Lisinopril. He also has Type II Diabetes Mellitus under control with Metformin. He underwent a right hip replacement 5 years ago but has no other surgical history. He does not have any known history of heart disease in his family. However  his brother was diagnosed with stroke at the age of 80.   Social History:  Mr. Smith is a retired school teacher. He smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 40 years but quit smoking ten years ago. He drinks alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use. He lives with his wife and is physically active. The patient admits to not following a specific diet but eats home-cooked meals regularly.   This presentation is typical of atrial fibrillation  requiring further evaluation and potentially adjustment of Mr. Smith's current medication regime.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Charles Brown  a 67-year-old African American male  presents to the clinic today with complaints of persistent palpitations and mild shortness of breath for the past two weeks. His heart rhythm feels irregular and he often perceives a 'skipped beat'. He also reports occasional episodes of lightheadedness but denies any fainting episodes  chest pain  or significant fatigue.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension  which has been managed by Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily for the past 6 years  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed by Metformin 1000 mg twice daily for the last 5 years. Additionally  he was diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia 3 years ago  for which he's been taking Atorvastatin 20 mg daily. There is no history of previous heart disease  stroke  or thromboembolic events. He has been regularly compliant with his medications with good control of his chronic conditions. He smokes half a pack of cigarettes per day and drinks alcohol occasionally.   On physical examination  his blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg and the irregular pulse rate is 110 beats per minute. No signs of congestive heart failure such as peripheral edema or pulmonary crepitations are appreciated. The rest of the clinical examination is unremarkable. His ECG was suggestive of atrial fibrillation.  Mr. Brown's complaints and findings on examination  along with his history of smoking and chronic conditions  increase his risk of developing complications like stroke from atrial fibrillation. It would be prudent to address his symptoms quickly and decide on appropriate management whether rate control  rhythm control or anticoagulation  depending on his risk profile and symptom severity. Support to quit smoking and control blood pressure is also crucial.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 72 year old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic with complaints of palpitations  intermittent shortness of breath  and fatigue for the past three weeks. He particularly notes that these symptoms seem to be provoked during physical exertion. Though he has experienced these episodes previously  they were usually fleeting  lasting no longer than a few minutes. However  the present episode has lasted for more than two hours  which is quite unusual for him  hence his visit for evaluation.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus both of which are fairly controlled with diet  exercise and medications. He also has a history of heavy smoking for many years but quit 10 years ago. He takes Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension.  His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease with both his father and older brother having suffered from heart attacks in their early 60s.   He is retired  living at home with his wife  and their daughter lives nearby and assists in his and his wife's care. He does not consume alcohol but has a 40-pack year history of smoking  although he quit smoking a decade ago.  He has no known drug allergies. On examination  his blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg  Pulse 110/min irregularly irregular  and respiratory rate is 18/min. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. His irregularly irregular pulse and his presentation suggests atrial fibrillation which is further confirmed with an electrocardiogram.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Caucasian male patient presents to the emergency department complaining of palpitations and fatigue for the past few days. He reports an associated occasional sensation of lightheadedness but states he has not fainted. Patient denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or recent illness.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a past medical history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient’s hypertension and diabetes are well managed with Metformin 1000mg BID  Lisinopril 40mg daily and Atorvastatin 20mg at bedtime. He has a 40-pack year history of smoking but quit smoking 5 years ago. There is no known history of heart disease in the family. He states his last health examination was respected six months ago.  Social History:  The patient is married and living with his wife. He is a retired accountant  drinks alcohol socially  and does not use any illicit drugs.  Review of Systems:  General: Fatigue  lightheadedness   Cardiovascular: Palpitations  no chest pain  no orthopnea or PND Respiratory: denies shortness of breath  cough GI: denies nausea  vomiting  abdominal pain GU: denies dysuria  hematuria Musculoskeletal: denies chest pain  joint swelling or pain. Neurological: denies headache  weakness  numbness Psychiatric: no change in mood or affect  On examination  his vital signs are: temperature 98.1 degrees Fahrenheit  heart rate 130 beats per minute (irregular)  blood pressure 155/85 mmHg  respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute. Electrocardiogram reveals atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The rest of the physical exam is unremarkable.   The patient is admitted to the hospital for further management of the new-onset atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. J. Johnson is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department complaining of an irregular heart beat and shortness of breath that started two days ago. He mentions feeling tired more frequently and having bouts of light-headedness. He denies chest pain  nausea  or fainting. Previously  he was in his usual state of health until these symptoms started.  Patient History:  Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago and Type II Diabetes Mellitus five years ago. His medications include Metformin 500mg twice daily and Lisinopril 10mg daily. He underwent coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG) 15 years ago because of significant coronary artery disease. He has a 45-pack year smoking history but quit smoking 10 years ago following his CABG surgery. He has no known drug allergies. His family history includes a mother with rheumatic heart disease and a brother with arrhythmias.  Physical Examination:  He appears slightly breathless during the conversation. His blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute and irregular  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. His body mass index (BMI) is 28 indicating that he is overweight.  The cardiac exam reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm with no gallops or murmurs. Pulses are irregular  and there is no edema in lower limbs. His lungs are clear on auscultation. The remaining of his physical examination is unremarkable.  Based on the patient's medical history and presenting symptoms  the irregular heart rhythm could suggest the diagnosis of atrial fibrillation. ECG and further tests are proposed to confirm this hypothesis. The patient is notified about the results of preliminary tests and an emergency consult with a cardiologist is made for further evaluation and treatment.

Patient Information:   Ms. Ortiz  a 75-year-old Hispanic female  presents complaining of episodic rapid heartbeats  intermittent dizziness  and occasional bouts of shortness of breath  primarily during moderate physical activities for the past 1 month.  Past Medical History:  Ms. Ortiz has a long history of hypertension (under control with Amlodipine 10mg daily)  moderate obesity (BMI 35.2)  and type 2 diabetes (maintained on Metformin 500mg twice daily). She also has experienced two previous transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) five and three years ago but has never experienced a stroke.  Family History:  Her father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 68. Her mother has been living with heart failure for the past six years.  Social History:  She is a non-smoker  drinks alcohol occasionally  and is physically inactive due to osteoarthritis.   Current Medications:  1. Amlodipine 10mg daily for hypertension 2. Metformin 500mg BID for type 2 Diabetes 3. Aspirin 81mg daily for TIA secondary prevention  Review of Systems:  General: Denies any fever  fatigue  or weight loss. Cardiovascular: Admits to palpitations and occasional shortness of breath. Neurological: Denies any headache  seizure  tremors or other neurological symptoms. GI: Denies nausea  vomiting  abdominal pain  or changes in bowel habit. Endocrine: Under control Type 2 diabetes symptoms. Musculoskeletal: Complains about joint pain due to osteoarthritis.   Physical Examination:   General: Obese  alert  oriented x 3.  Vital signs: BP 130/85 mmHg  HR 112 bpm (irregular)  Temp 98.6°F  RR: 16/min  Oxygen saturation: 96% on room air. Heart: Tachycardic  irregular rhythm without murmurs  gallops  or rubs. Chest: Lung clear to auscultation bilaterally.  Neurologic: Alert and oriented  cranial nerves II-XII grossly intact.   The patient's symptoms  irregular pulse  along with her risk factors including age  hypertension  obesity  diabetes  and prior transient ischemic events  raise suspicion for atrial fibrillation which needs to be confirmed by EKG and possibly a Holter monitor if paroxysmal.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Johnson is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic reporting palpitations and occasional shortness of breath  particularly during light exertion like walking up the stairs. He reveals that these symptoms have been ongoing for the past two weeks and seem to be progressively getting worse. He denies any chest pain  dizziness  or fainting episodes and his appetite and sleep patterns are normally preserved.   Mr. Johnson has a past medical history notable for hypertension  for which he has been taking Lisinopril for the last 10 years. He also has type 2 diabetes which is well controlled with Metformin. There is no family history of cardiac diseases. He admits to a 40-pack year smoking history although he quit 8 years ago. He reports moderate alcohol use and denies any illicit drug use.  On physical examination  his BP is 148/85 mmHg  HR 116 bpm and irregularly irregular  RR 16 bpm  and temp 98.6°F. His BMI is 28. Cardiovascular exam reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm with no other abnormal heart sounds. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Based on history and physical examination  a suspicion of atrial fibrillation is raised and diagnostic investigations are planned accordingly.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Williams is a 70-year-old African-American male presenting to the cardiology clinic with ongoing complaints of heart palpitations and shortness of breath for the last three months. He reports that these symptoms are episodic and occur more frequently after physical exertion. He has also noticed that episodes of dizziness accompany these spells. Mr. Williams notes that he was generally healthy until these symptoms started. He denies chest pain  nausea  vomiting  or fainting.  He has a past medical history of hypertension diagnosed at 50 years of age  well-controlled on Lisinopril 20mg daily. He has a 40-pack year smoking history; he stopped smoking 10 years ago. He also has a family history of coronary artery disease; his father suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. He denies any history of diabetes or dyslipidemia.  He currently lives with his wife and enjoys gardening. He admits to consuming one to two alcoholic beverages a day. His diet is moderately high in salt content  with primary protein sources being fish and poultry. His other medications include a multivitamin and over-the-counter aspirin.  On examination  Mr. Williams is slightly overweight with an irregularly irregular pulse. His blood pressure is in the prehypertensive range. Auscultation reveals an irregular heart rhythm with no murmurs. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  A 12 lead ECG shows evidence of atrial fibrillation. Blood results show slightly elevated BNP levels but otherwise no abnormalities detected. An echocardiogram has been requested for further evaluation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Richardson is a 70-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the clinic today with a chief complaint of palpitations that he describes as a ""fluttering in the chest."" He states that these symptoms have been intermittent and ongoing for about 3 months now. He has also experienced episodes of lightheadedness  but no syncope.   He has a significant past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which are controlled by medication. Mr. Richardson also has a 20-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally but denies illicit drug use. He had a cardiac evaluation two years ago as part of his executive health checkup  and it was within normal limits. His father died of myocardial infarction at age 72  and his mother is alive at 92 with a history of stroke.   He has overall been leading an active lifestyle with regular light exercises and balanced diet. On physical examination  his blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg  his heart rhythm is irregularly irregular  and he is not in respiratory distress at rest. His current medications include metformin and ramipril. The rest of his physical examination is unremarkable.

Patient Presentation:  A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic complaining of intermittent palpitations  fatigue  and mild shortness of breath for the past few weeks. The symptoms are most noticeable during his evening walks. He denies any chest pain  dizziness  syncope  or diaphoresis.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medications. He enjoys a social drink twice a week and has never smoked cigarettes. His mother had a stroke a few years back and his paternal grandmother had ""heart trouble""  details of which are not clear.   On physical examination  the patient's heart rate is irregular  ranging from 90 to 130 bpm and blood pressure is 132/85 mmHg. Auscultation of the heart reveals an irregular rhythm. No murmurs or gallops are heard. ECG shows irregularly irregular rhythm with no distinct P waves  indicative of atrial fibrillation. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.   The patient has been compliant with his antihypertensive medications and states he has been maintaining a low-salt diet. He is unaware of any recent emotional stress or changes to his exercise regimen. He is worried these symptoms could be an indication of a more serious heart condition  remembering his family history.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith  a 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic complaining of persistent palpitations and episodic fatigue for the past few weeks. Mr. Smith describes the palpitations as irregular  rapid heartbeats that are typically without pain  but occasionally associated with mild chest discomfort and shortness of breath. He also reported lightheadedness and transient dizziness occurring sporadically.   With a known past medical history of hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and coronary artery disease (CAD)  Smith has been on anti-hypertensive medications  oral hypoglycemic agents  and low-dose aspirin. His grandfather reportedly had an 'irregular heartbeat' but he has no other family history of heart disease.   Mr. Smith is a former smoker  quitting approximately 10 years ago after a 30-year history of tobacco use. He reports moderate  social alcohol consumption and denies any illicit drug use. Smith is retired and lives with his wife. They have 3 adult children.   On physical examination  Mr. Smith appears well-nourished and mildly anxious. His blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg  pulse is irregularly irregular at 98 beats per minute  and respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute. An irregular rhythm was noted on cardiac auscultation  and his lungs were clear. No peripheral edema was noted.

The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents today with the chief complaint of palpitations  fatigue  and occasional shortness of breath. The palpitations are irregular  and he describes the sensation as though his heart is “flipping around.” These symptoms have been intermittent and have been occurring for the past two months.   On exam  he is moderately obese with a BMI of 31. His blood pressure is 138/87 mmHg  heart rate is 100 bpm and irregularly irregular  respirations are 18 per minute  and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension  controlled with medication (Losartan 50mg daily)  and type 2 diabetes managed with Metformin. The patient quit smoking ten years ago and has a 30 pack-year history. He drinks alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use. He has no known drug allergies. His family history is notable for a brother with atrial fibrillation and a mother who had a stroke at the age of 75.  The patient's medications include Losartan 50mg daily for hypertension  Metformin 500mg twice daily for diabetes  and a multivitamin. He has no known drug allergies.  The rest of his physical examination  including a neurologic exam  is unremarkable. He is alert and oriented  with the ability to answer questions appropriately and maintain a conversation. His lungs are clear to auscultation  and his abdomen is soft and non-tender.  A 12-lead EKG shows atrial fibrillation with a ventricular response of approximately 98 beats per minute. The rhythm is irregularly irregular with no p waves  confirming the diagnosis of atrial fibrillation. The patient is scheduled for further cardiac testing and is provided education about his new diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 72 years old Caucasian male presenting to the clinic with symptoms suggestive of atrial fibrillation. He reports increasing episodes of palpitations and intermittent fatigue for the past two months. Mr. Smith also mentions occasional bouts of lightheadedness but denies any history of syncope or chest pain.   His prior medical history includes well-controlled hypertension under treatment for the past 12 years and managed by his primary care physician. He had a stroke five years ago with subsequent full recovery. Despite these  his adherence to prescribed medications is inconsistent  mainly due to forgetfulness. Mr. Smith is a former smoker  having quit 20 years ago. He also enjoys an occasional glass of wine on weekends. His family history consists of a father who died from a heart attack at 68 and a mother who died from stroke at 80.   On physical examination  Mr. Smith appears to be in no apparent distress. His vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  heart rate of 105 beats per minute irregularly irregular  respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. His body mass index is 25. Lung auscultation reveals clear breath sounds bilaterally. Cardiac exam reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm without murmur.   Initial laboratory tests including complete blood count and electrolyte panels are ordered. An EKG confirms the suspicion of atrial fibrillation. To further evaluate potential causes and complications  a 2D Echocardiogram and Thyroid Function Test are scheduled. Given his age and prior stroke  Mr. Smith has a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 3  indicating a moderate to high risk for stroke. Therefore  long-term oral anticoagulation is considered as per guidelines. Specialists' consultations are sought to discuss further diagnostic evaluation and management options.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired teacher  presenting with complaints of palpitations  occasional chest discomfort  and shortness of breath for the past two weeks. Symptoms seem to be agitated during routine household activities and subside during rest. He also reports occasional lightheadedness  but no notable syncope or presyncope. No reported leg swelling  orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Patient also mentions fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance.  Patient’s vital signs are as follows: Temperature - 98.7 F  Pulse - 110 bpm (irregularly irregular)  Respiration rate 17 breaths per minute  Blood pressure - 132/78 mmHg  SpO2 - 97%  Past medical history is significant for hypertension managed with lisinopril  borderline-high cholesterol treated with atorvastatin  and type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin. No previous history of heart disease or strokes. Patient has a 40 pack year smoking history. He drinks alcohol occasionally and denies the use of illegal drugs.   Family history includes father with coronary artery disease and an elder brother with atrial fibrillation.  On examination  the patient appears mildly distressed  cardiac auscultation illustrates irregularly irregular rhythm with no murmur  lungs are clear on auscultation  abdomen is soft  non-distended  no peripheral edema and the rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Given his symptoms  clinical examination  and family history  atrial fibrillation appears to be a likely differential diagnosis. Further diagnostic evaluation including ECG  blood tests  and echocardiogram are suggested for definitive diagnosis and management plan.

Patient Presentation:  Name: Mr. Edwards Age: 67 years Gender: Male Occupation: Retired Teacher  Mr. Edwards comes in  presenting with palpitations and intermittent shortness of breath that have been progressively getting worse over the past couple of weeks. He reports associated lightheadedness but denies any chest pain or fainting. He also notes intermittent fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance.  Past Medical History: Hypertension for 10 years  controlled with Lisinopril. History of smoking (20 cigarettes per day for about 30 years) but quit smoking 8 years ago. No known drug allergies. He consumes alcohol socially.  Family History: His father died of a heart attack at the age of 76  and his mother is living with well-controlled diabetes. His older brother had a stroke at the age of 71.  Physical Examination: On examination  he appears afebrile with a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg. His heart rate is irregularly irregular  at a rate of around 110 bpm. Heart sounds were normal with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. The lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally. His BMI was within normal range.  Investigations: An ECG was ordered  which demonstrated atrial fibrillation with a moderate ventricular response.  Further testing  including lab workup and echocardiogram  were ordered to rule out potential underlying causes  such as hyperthyroidism and structural heart diseases  for the new onset of atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic complaining of episodes of intermittent irregular heart rhythm and mild shortness of breath occurring over the last 6 months. He grades his fatigue as 6/10 which gets pronounced towards the end of the day and after mild to moderate exertion. He denies any chest pain  palpitations  dizziness  or fainting episodes. However  he reports he sometimes feels a slightly increased heart rate.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a known diagnosis of hypertension  for which he has been on Lisinopril 10mg daily for the last 10 years. His blood pressure has been well controlled with meds. His other significant past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed with Metformin. He is also on a low dosage aspirin as a preventive measure owing to his age and existing comorbidities. He has a history of smoking one pack a day  but he gave up smoking approximately 1 year ago.   Family history reveals his father had a myocardial infarction at age 82. There is no family history of sudden cardiac death or any known heart rhythm disorders.   Lifestyle:  Mr. Smith is a retired school teacher  lives with his wife in the suburban area  and has a history of significant alcohol intake  but he cut back on his intake to moderate drinking after the diabetes diagnosis. They have two adult children who live out of state. His degree of daily physical activity is low  mainly limited to house chores and some gardening. He has a diet controlled mostly by his both son and daughter-in-law who are healthcare professionals.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired school teacher  residing in suburban New York.  Chief Complaints: Persistent palpitations  occasional shortness of breath  and fatigue for the past two months.  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension controlled with lisinopril 10 mg daily for last 8 years 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus managed with metformin 500 mg twice daily for the past 5 years 3. Hyperlipidemia treated with atorvastatin 20 mg daily for the last three years 4. Previous smoker  quit 10 years ago  with a 20 pack-year history.  Review of Systems: Reported intermittent lightheadedness. Sleep disturbances due to nocturia. Denies any chest pain  cough  edema  or significant weight loss.  Family History: Father passed away due to stroke at age 68. Mother passed away due to complications from heart failure at age 70. Younger brother diagnosed with coronary artery disease at age 60.  Medications: Lisinopril 10 mg daily  metformin 500 mg twice daily  and atorvastatin 20 mg daily.  Physical Examination: 1. Vital Signs: Blood Pressure - 132/86 mmHg  Pulse - irregularly irregular at 105 bpm  Respiratory rate - 18/min  Oxygen Saturation - 97% on room air  Temperature - 98.6 F 2. Cardiovascular examination: Irregularly irregular rhythm noted on cardiac auscultation  no murmurs or additional heart sounds were heard. 3. Other systems: Unremarkable.  Summary: Mr. John Doe is a 72-year-old male with a significant past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia presenting with a chief complaint of persistent palpitations  occasional shortness of breath  and fatigue for the past two months. His vitals and physical examination findings  notably the irregularly irregular rhythm on cardiac auscultation  point towards a possible diagnosis of atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents today for a routine visit. He is an ex-smoker  quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially. The patient is retired  formerly worked in an office setting  and is now living alone after his wife passed away last year.  His chief complaint today is of persistent palpitations  fatigue  and ongoing mild dyspnea on exertion. He reports these symptoms have been occurring somewhat intermittently for several weeks but seem to have worsened over the past few days. No chest pain  syncope  or presyncope.  Past medical history is significant for hypertension  managed with Lisinopril 10 mg daily  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  controlled with Metformin 1000 mg twice daily. He has a history of a transient ischemic attack 3 years ago with no residual deficits. He denies any history of heart disease in his family.  On physical exam  heart rate is irregularly irregular  and auscultation of the heart detects a rate of approximately 110 bpm with absence of S1 and S4 heart sounds. Blood pressure is 148/90mmHg.  Given his symptoms  clinical presentation and physical examination a working diagnosis of atrial fibrillation is considered  but further diagnostic testing  such as an ECG or possibly Holter monitoring  is planning to confirm diagnosis. Treatment options  including rate control  rhythm control  and anticoagulation will be evaluated based on the results of diagnostic tests and patient's risk profile.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. James Smith is a 68-year-old white male retiree  who presents to the clinic with a 1-week history of palpitations  fatigue  and occasional shortness of breath. He states that these symptoms have been ongoing and persistent  however  he feels that they have worsened over the past few days. He denies chest pain  dizziness  or loss of consciousness.   He has a past medical history of hypertension and mild obesity managed with losartan 50mg daily and through dietary changes respectively. He has a history of heavy alcohol consumption during his youth but quit approximately 10 years ago. He quit smoking approximately 5 years ago after a 30-year  pack-a-day history. There is a family history of myocardial infarction; his father passed away from a heart attack at age 70 and his older brother had a heart attack at 65.   On examination  he has an irregular pulse rate of 110 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg. Lung sounds are clear to auscultation bilaterally and no lower limb edema is noted. Mr. Smith denies any recent illness  viral infection  or notable stress. He has not traveled recently and denies any changes to his diet  physical activity  or weight.   The rest of the review of systems is unremarkable. His current medicines are losartan for hypertension and a multivitamin tablet. He is compliant with his antihypertensive medication. He has no known drug allergies.   He currently lives with his wife  who is his primary caregiver. He is a former construction worker and retired about 8 years ago. He has two adult children with no significant health issues.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents with complaints of intermittent heart palpitations and mild shortness of breath over the past few weeks. The symptoms occur sporadically and can last from a few minutes to several hours. He denies any chest pain  dizziness  or syncope. However  he did notice increasing fatigue and reduced exercise intolerance during his normal morning walks.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has been on antihypertensive medications (Lisinopril and Hydrochlorothiazide) and oral hypoglycemic agent (Metformin) for several years. He is a former smoker  quitting 10 years ago  and admits to occasional alcohol consumption.   Mr. Smith has a family history of cardiovascular disease  with his mother having suffered a myocardial infarction in her late 60s and his brother diagnosed with atrial fibrillation at the age of 75. Mr. Smith is currently living with his wife in their own home and he denied any recent travel  stressful situations or significant changes in his lifestyle. He uses a walking stick for mobility due to mild osteoarthritis in his right hip.  On physical examination  his irregularly irregular heart rhythm  and other associated findings suggested atrial fibrillation  needing further investigation.

Patient Information: Mr. Wilson  a 70-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaint: Irregular heartbeat and shortness of breath experienced for a week.  History of Present Illness: Patient presents with a complaint of irregular  ‘fluttering’ heartbeat for a week. He also mentions episodes of breathlessness and fatigue on mild exertion. He denies chest pain  swelling in legs  and fainting spells.   Past Medical History: Patient has a known case of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus managed for the past ten years. He had suffered a stroke around 5 years ago and has been on antiplatelet medication since then. Regular medication includes Metformin  Lisinopril  and Aspirin. He used to smoke a pack of cigarettes daily  quit 1 year after his stroke.  Family History: Father had heart disease and mother suffered from type 2 diabetes.   Review of Systems: No recent weight loss  fever  chills  or other systemic symptoms.  Physical Examination: Blood pressure: 140/90 mmHg  Pulse: irregular at 120/min  Respirations: 20/min  and Temperature: 98.6F. Cardiovascular exam revealed an irregularly irregular rhythm. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Based on the history and physical exam  Mr. Wilson seems to present with symptoms suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Further investigations including an electrocardiogram  echocardiogram  and blood tests are planned. Following the results  the next course of treatment will be communicated to him.

Patient Information: A 76-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Smith presents to the clinic.  Chief Complaint: He complains of recurrent episodes of palpitations  fatigue  and shortness of breath that have been progressively worsening over the past four months.   History of Present Illness: Mr. Smith describes the palpitations as rapid and irregular  and they can last from a few minutes to a few hours. He notices that they are triggered by physical activity. The shortness of breath is moderate and increases noticeably upon exertion. He denies any chest pain  dizziness  or fainting spells.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension  for which he has been on Amlodipine 10mg daily for the past ten years. He is also diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus and mild congestive heart failure two years ago  for which he is on Metformin 500mg twice daily and Furosemide 40mg daily. He underwent coronary artery bypass grafting 6 years ago.  Family History: His father died from a stroke at the age of 80. His 73-year-old sister has a known medical history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation.  Social History: Mr. Smith is a retired engineer  currently living with his wife. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history but quit five years ago. He denies illicit drug use and drinks alcohol socially.  Review of Systems: Unremarkable.  As far as the physical exam  the patient appears in mild distress due to dyspnea. Vitals indicate a heart rate of 110 beats per minute with an irregular rhythm  blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  respirations of 18 per minute  and the oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. The cardiovascular exam revealed an irregularly irregular rhythm. No murmurs  rubs  or gallops were noted. Lung sounds clear to auscultation bilaterally. The rest of the physical exam was unremarkable.  Plan: The presentation aligns with the known symptoms of atrial fibrillation (AF). The patient was planned for an EKG  which confirmed atrial fibrillation. After consultation with a cardiologist  anticoagulation therapy with warfarin was initiated for stroke prophylaxis. The new medication regimen and lifestyle modifications were discussed with the patient. He was further advised for regular outpatient follow-ups and was instructed to report to the Emergency Department if symptoms significantly worsen.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 68-year-old African-American male who presents to the emergency department complaining of palpitations  breathlessness  and mild weakness which started three hours ago. He denies any chest pain  dizziness  or syncope. He also notes an intermittent irregular heartbeat over the past few months for which he has not sought any medical attention.  His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus of 10 years duration  for which he takes Metformin. He also has a 15-year history of hypertension managed with Lisinopril. He does not have any known history of heart disease  stroke or any other major illnesses. He is a non-smoker and does not take alcohol or illegal drugs. There is a positive family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father having died of a myocardial infarction in his late 70s.  On physical examination  he appears generally well  although slight symptoms of anxiety can be observed. Vital signs reveal blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 110 beats per minute and irregular  and respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. Auscultation of the heart reveals an irregular rhythm.   The patient's presentation and the irregularly irregular pulse suggest atrial fibrillation  and he requires further workup including an ECG to confirm the diagnosis. His underlying co-morbidities of diabetes and hypertension could potentially have contributed to his current cardiac condition.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. J is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and shortness of breath since the morning. He states the symptoms started when he was gardening  and although less severe  have persisted till now.  He has a past medical history of hypertension for the past five years and is currently on Amlodipine 5mg daily. He also has a history of hypothyroidism under control with Levothyroxine and moderate alcohol consumption. The patient reports a past smoking history  having quit about ten years ago.   There is no significant family history of heart disease  and the patient denies any chest pain  syncope  or history of stroke or blood clots. On examination  he appears slightly anxious with irregular heartbeats and a rapid pulse.  Based on his history and presentation  an EKG was conducted which revealed atrial fibrillation. Mr. J was subsequently started on a rate control strategy and anticoagulation medication to reduce the risk of stroke and managed as an outpatient.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Anderson  a 68-year-old African American male  presented to the emergency department complaining about experiencing bouts of rapid  irregular heartbeats accompanied by shortness of breath  fatigue and slight chest discomfort for the past several days. He reported these episodes to last for a few minutes to hours and occurred ""out of nowhere"" with no identifiable trigger.  Mr. Anderson is retired and does not take part in intense physical activities  but has a history of smoking about 10-15 cigarettes a day for 40 years. He quit five years ago. His diet could use improvement as he expressed a preference for fast food items high in salt and fat. Mr. Anderson also has a history of hypertension  which has been controlled with medications for the past seven years. He does not have any previous cardiac history  no known drug allergies and no prior surgeries.  Upon examination  his pulse was irregularly irregular  but his blood pressure was within normal limits (135/85 mmHg). The rest of his physical examination was unremarkable.  Family history indicates his father had a stroke at the age of 72  whereas his mother had myocardial infarction at 67. Mr. Anderson is married with three grown-up children and lives with his wife. He has six grandkids and remains active in his community. His nights are occasionally troubled by nocturia  while his alcohol intake is limited to mild social drinking.  Given his presentation  the healthcare team is concerned about atrial fibrillation and plans further diagnostic testing to confirm the same.

Patient Information: A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic reporting feelings of heart palpitations  shortness of breath  and light-headedness over the past several weeks.   Chief Complaint: The patient describes the heart palpitations as an irregular or fluttering feeling in his chest.   History of Present Illness: He reports his symptoms to be increasingly consistent and alarming. Accompanying these symptoms  he also notes periods of fatigue following slight exertion.   Past Medical History: Significant for hypertension  and type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 8 years ago which is under control with oral hypoglycemics. The patient also had a history of heavy smoking of about 25 pack years  but he quit about 5 years ago. There's no history of prior cardiac disease.  Social History: He lives with his wife  retired from his work as a teacher  denies use of alcohol or illegal drugs  stopped smoking 5 years ago.  Medications: Lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and Metformin 1000 mg twice daily for diabetes.  Family History: Father died from myocardial infarction at 67 years. Mother is alive and well with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Allergies: No known drug allergies.  Review of Systems: Denies chest pain  nausea  vomiting  or syncope. Reports of occasional nocturia.  Physical Examination: Heart rate irregularly irregular  blood pressure 135/85 mmHg  BMI 27.3 kg/m2. S1 and S2 are irregularly spaced with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops heard. No lower extremity edema noted. Rest of the physical exam was relatively normal.  Based on the history and physical examination findings  atrial fibrillation is suspected and further diagnostic tests are planned.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic complaining of palpitations and dyspnea on exertion for the past few days. The palpitations are intermittent  lasting anywhere from a few minutes to a few hours  and are not associated with any chest pain  dizziness  or syncope. The patient also mentions feeling fatigued more easily over the past week.   He is a retired banker with a history of hypertension  which is controlled on Lisinopril  and moderate alcohol consumption (approximately 6-8 drinks per week). His father had a stroke at age 72 and mother passed away due to a heart attack at age 67. He quit smoking approximately 20 years ago and denies any illicit drug use. He denies any recent illnesses  travel  or unusual stressors. He is sedentary and has a diet that is moderate in salt and fat.   On examination  his blood pressure is controlled at 132/82 mmHg and heart rate is irregularly irregular  ranging from 88 to 130 beats per minute with normal respirations  and oxygen saturation is 95% at rest. Pulses are equal in all extremities. He is afebrile. Cardiac auscultation reveals an irregular rhythm. Both lungs are clear to percussion and auscultation. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable.   He is further referred for an electrocardiogram (ECG) which confirms the diagnosis of atrial fibrillation. He is started on appropriate therapy and counseled about lifestyle changes  including limiting alcohol consumption and increasing physical activity.

A 73-year-old Caucasian man presents to the clinic complaining of intermittent palpitations and slight shortness of breath for the past two weeks. He also states that he has experienced episodes of light-headedness but no syncope. His past medical history is significant for hypertension  diagnosed 10 years ago  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  diagnosed 5 years ago. He does not have a history of cardiac disease  stroke  or anticoagulation. He has a 20-pack year smoking history  but quit 15 years ago. He occasionally drinks alcohol but has no history of drug use. He lives with his wife  who is his primary caregiver. He claims to be relatively physically active  often going for walks around his neighborhood.  On physical exam  irregularly irregular pulse palpable at the wrist and auscultation of the heart reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm. The remainder of his physical exam was unremarkable. Further investigations  including an EKG  are planned to confirm the suspected diagnosis of atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 76-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic complaining of palpitations and occasional dyspnea on exertion. He describes his heart beating irregularly for about two weeks now  with bouts of light-headedness. However  he denies any chest pain  fainting spells  or severe shortness of breath. He enjoys a moderate level of activity  including gardening and walking his dog daily.  His past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus  which is controlled with metformin  hypertension  controlled with lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide  and hyperlipidemia  which is controlled with atorvastatin. He has a 45 pack-year history of smoking but he quit smoking 10 years ago. His family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases – his father suffered a stroke at 68 and his brother has congestive heart failure.  On physical examination  his pulse is irregularly irregular and while at rest  the rate ranges from 82 bpm to 140 bpm within a minute. His blood pressure is 140/80 mmHg and respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute.  Mr. Doe is currently living with his daughter and her family. He reports occasional consumption of alcohol but no recreational drug use. He takes his medications regularly and has no known drug allergies. His other maintenance medications include low-dose aspirin for cardiovascular disease prophylaxis and multivitamins. There are no recorded history of previous surgical operations. It's also worth noting that he's not currently on any form of anticoagulant therapy.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presents today with complaints of heart palpitations  fatigue  and episodes of breathlessness for the past 2 weeks. His symptoms seem to exacerbate during physical activities  specifically when he is gardening or climbing stairs.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus.
