He has no known allergies and his social history is unremarkable for tobacco  alcohol  or illicit drug use. He did not have any recent illness or travel. His physical examination reveals an irregularly irregular pulse and the rest of his examination is unremarkable. An EKG confirms atrial fibrillation.

A 68-year-old African American male with a known medical history of hypertension  chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  and diabetes mellitus type 2  presents to the clinic complaining of new-onset palpitations for the past 2 days. He also reports feeling fatigued and light-headedness  but denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncope. On physical examination  his heart rate was irregularly irregular with a rate of 110 beats per minute and blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg. No signs of congestive heart failure were observed. An Electrocardiogram (ECG) subsequently confirms atrial fibrillation. His medications include metformin  lisinopril  and a combination inhaler (fluticasone and salmeterol) for his COPD.

Problem Representation:  A 63-year-old Caucasian man presents with persistent fatigue  palpitations  and occasional episodes of light-headedness over the past 3 months. He also reports shortness of breath following minor physical exertion. He has a significant medical history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus  which are well-controlled with medication (Lisinopril and Metformin  respectively). He has been an active smoker for the past 30 years. He denies any chest pain  syncope  or edema. On examination  he was tachycardic with an irregularly irregular pulse. Subsequent ECG confirmed atrial fibrillation.

Patient Profile: A 68-year-old African-American male with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus.  Presenting Complaint: Patient presented to the Emergency Department complaining of palpitations and intermittent shortness of breath for the past week.  History of Present Illness: Symptoms have been gradually increasing in severity. The palpitations are irregular with no specific triggering factor. The patient had two episodes of near-syncope last week and also noted increased fatigue. The shortness of breath is more severe upon exertion. There is no associated chest pain  cough  or lower limb swelling.   Past Medical History: Patient is hypertensive  well controlled on hydrochlorothiazide and amlodipine. He is also diabetic  managed with metformin and diet.  Review of System: The rest is not relevant.  Family history: father passed away due to a stroke and mother passed away due to breast cancer. The patient has three brothers and one sister  all of whom have hypertension.  Social history: non-smoker and denies alcohol or illicit drug use.  Physical Exam: Vital signs are BP 150/90 mmHg  HR 110 bpm  irregularly irregular  T 37.0 C  RR 18 bpm  SpO2 96% on room air  BMI 28 kg/m^2. Cardiovascular exam reveals tachycardia with no murmurs. Respiratory  GI  Neuro  Musculoskeletal exams are normal.   Laboratory results: EKG shows atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. Chest radiography is normal. Troponin I is within normal limits  BNP is mildly elevated. Fasting blood glucose level is 180 mg/dl  and HbA1c is 7.2%. Thyroid function tests are normal.  Impression: Atrial fibrillation most likely secondary to underlying hypertension or diabetes complications. Risk of stroke is high considering his age and comorbidities.  Plan: Admit for rate or rhythm control  coagulate if no contraindications  manage risk factors  and plan for cardioversion if necessary.  Ensure tight control of diabetes and hypertension  lifestyle modifications and educating the patient about the condition’s implications.

Patient is a 72-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia  who presents with recent episodes of palpitations and occasional shortness of breath for the past two months. He characterizes the palpitations as rapid  irregular  and causing a feeling of ""butterflies"" in his chest. Accompanying symptoms include mild fatigue. On further questioning  the patient reported some episodes of dizziness but denied any chest pain  syncope  or orthopnea. His medications include metformin  lisinopril  and simvastatin. He is a retired mail carrier  denies any tobacco or alcohol use  and reports a family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father having suffered a stroke at the age of 78. On examination  irregular heart rate was noted. An EKG confirmed irregularly irregular rhythm  thus raising suspicion for atrial fibrillation.

Patient Profile: Mr. James  a 64-year-old Caucasian male  ex-smoker and social drinker  with known medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He also has a family history of cardiovascular disease.  Presenting complaint: Mr. James comes in with a two-day history of generalized weakness  palpitations  shortness of breath  and episodes of lightheadedness.  Physical Examination: On examination  his blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg  pulse rate is irregular at 118 bmp  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and he exhibits slight pallor. Cardiovascular examination reveals an irregularly irregular pulse consistent with atrial fibrillation. Lung examination and other system examinations are otherwise unremarkable.  Investigations: His electrocardiogram (ECG) confirms a diagnosis of Atrial Fibrillation (AF). Fasting blood sugar levels show good glycemic control and lipid profile shows borderline high cholesterol. His complete blood count  kidney function test  and liver function test values are within normal limits. An echocardiogram is pending.   Treatment: Mr. James's high CHA2DS2-VASc score denotes a high risk of thromboembolism so anticoagulation therapy should be initiated after ruling out any contraindications. Rate control and potential rhythm control strategies should be considered as well as addressing his modifiable risk factors.   He has been advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle  regular follow-ups with his primary care physician and cardiologist  monitor blood pressure and blood sugar levels at home  adhere to medications prescribed and to report to the emergency department if symptoms deteriorate or new symptoms appear.

A 68-year-old African American female with a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents with a complaint of intermittent palpitations and fatigue over the past few weeks. She mentions that she is generally an active person  but lately she has been struggling with shortness of breath during her daily walks. She denies any chest pain  lightheadedness  or syncope. Upon examination  an irregularly irregular pulse is noted and later confirmed by an EKG as atrial fibrillation. Blood pressure is elevated at 145/90 mmHg  and random blood glucose levels are slightly above target. No overt signs of heart failure such as elevated JVP or peripheral edema are recorded. Patient's current medications include metformin and amlodipine.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  dyslipidemia  and type 2 diabetes  presents with a rapid  irregular heartbeat  fatigue  dizziness  and intermittent palpitations  which he reported started three days ago. He denies chest pain  dyspnea  syncope  orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He is currently on metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. He has no known drug allergies. Patient's family history reveals his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 72. He smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for 30 years and quit 8 years ago. He admits to drinking 2-3 glasses of wine several nights per week.

A 72-year-old female patient with a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents to the clinic complaining of a 2 week history of episodic palpitations associated with mild shortness of breath and fatigue. She denies associated chest pain  dizziness  or loss of consciousness. On examination  her heart rate is irregularly irregular  with no audible murmurs  and lungs are clear. Her blood pressure is controlled  and there is no evidence of peripheral edema. ECG confirms atrial fibrillation.

Patient is a 75-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes. The patient presents with complaints of recurrent palpitations  episodes of dizziness  and intermittent shortness of breath for the past few weeks. He also complained of occasional mild chest discomfort. He has no surgical history and his only medication is metformin for diabetes. No allergies were reported. No family history of heart disease. He is a retired professor  non-smoker  and denies alcohol or drug use. On examination  the patient appeared anxious. His blood pressure was 155/95 mmHg  pulse was irregular at 110 bpm  respiratory rate was 18 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation was 95% on room air. Cardiovascular examination revealed irregularly irregular heart rhythms. Other systemic examination was normal. His BMI is 29 kg/m2  indicating overweight.

A 70-year-old African American male  previously asymptomatic  with a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  presents with new onset of palpitations  intermittent dizziness  and generalized fatigue for the past two weeks. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or loss of consciousness. Risk factors include elderly age  male sex  an uncontrolled hypertension and diabetic. Physical examination reveals irregularly irregular pulse with blood pressure within acceptable limits. The EKG confirms atrial fibrillation. There's no prior history or family history of cardiac diseases or stroke. He also confirmed non-compliance to his prescribed anti-hypertensive and antidiabetic medications for the same duration.

Patient Representation: Mr. Davis  a 72-year-old Caucasian retired teacher  with a medical history of hypertension and type II diabetes  presents with complaints of palpitations and fatigue over the past two weeks. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncope. His hypertension is well controlled on Losartan  and his diabetes has been under control with metformin. There is no history of smoking  alcohol use  or substance abuse in the patient. There is a family history of cardiac arrhythmias on his paternal side. On examination  his vitals reveal an irregularly irregular heart rhythm and a rate of around 150 beats per minute. No other significant findings are discerned on physical examination. An ECG reveals atrial fibrillation.

Patient Information: A 75-year-old Caucasian female.  Medical History: She is a non-smoker with a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medication. She has no history of heart disease or stroke. Her mother had a stroke at the age of 78.   Presenting Problem: The patient presents to the clinic with a 1-week history of palpitations  fatigue  and shortness of breath on exertion. She has also occasionally noted feeling lightheaded during these episodes but has had no syncope. She denies chest pain  nausea  vomiting  or diaphoresis.  Physical Examination: On physical exam  her vital signs are stable  but irregularly irregular rhythm is noted on cardiac auscultation. There is no peripheral edema and her lung sounds are clear. The remainder of her physical exam is unremarkable.  Relevant Lab Findings: EKG shows atrial fibrillation with a ventricular rate of approximately 110 bpm.

A 72-year-old African-American male with a medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents to the clinic complaining of shortness of breath and fatigue over the past two days. He further reports occasional palpitations and dizziness but denies chest pain  nausea  or syncope. Upon examination  rapid and irregular heart rhythms are observed suggesting possible atrial fibrillation. He has been compliant with his antihypertensive and diabetic medication  however  has no history of anticoagulation therapy.

Problem Representation:  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  coronary artery disease (CAD)  and diabetes mellitus type II who presents with symptoms consistent with atrial fibrillation. He reports a 4-day history of palpitations  shortness of breath  fatigue  and lightheadedness. He denies chest pain  syncope  or lower extremity swelling. His EKG reveals atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular rate. The patient's blood pressure was 165/100 mmHg and his pulse rate was 120 beats per minute irregularly irregular. Labs reveal mild electrolyte disturbances with no signs of congestive heart failure or myocardial injury. Previous medical records indicate poor blood pressure control despite being on a three-drug antihypertensive regimen. The patient’s medications include insulin  metoprolin  amlodipine  and lisinopril. He is a retired engineer  does not smoke or drink alcohol  and is living with his wife. His family history includes CAD in his father and brother.

A 72-year-old African-American female with a medical history significant for hypertension  heart failure  and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with a 2-day history of palpitations  occasional shortness of breath  and fatigue. She reports that these symptoms began suddenly and have been progressively worsening. She denies chest pain  nausea  vomiting  or diaphoresis. Her medications include metformin  lisinopril  and aspirin. Vitals show blood pressure of 145/88 mmHg  heart rate of 132 bpm with an irregular rhythm  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. On examination  she has an irregularly irregular pulse  and the rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. EKG confirms atrial fibrillation. Chest X-ray is clear and troponins are within normal limits.

Problem Representation:  Patient profile: A 65-year-old Caucasian male  non-smoker  with a history of hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus.  Chief Complaint: Intermittent palpitations over the past one month  slightly worsening over the past week.  Relevant medical history: The patient was diagnosed with hypertension and diabetes five years ago and is on treatment (Metformin and Lisinopril); his blood sugar and blood pressure have been relatively well-managed. The patient has no allergies. His father had coronary artery disease but no family history of arrhythmias. The patient does not consume alcohol and has never smoked. His lipid profile was within normal limits during his last annual check-up three months ago.  Physical examination and symptoms: On presentation  the patient was having a rapid and irregular pulse rate of 110 per min  blood pressure was 140/90 mmHg. The patient primarily reports episodes of palpitations  especially after exercise  occasional light-headedness. There was no chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncope. The symptoms seem to come and go and are not constant. Body Mass Index (BMI) was 29 indicative of overweight. Rest of the physical examination was unremarkable with clear lung sounds  no peripheral edema  and no signs of cyanosis.   From the information above  the primary clinical problem is likely Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation given the intermittent palpitations  and age and medical history predisposing to this condition.

A 70-year-old Caucasian female patient presents in the clinic complaining of palpitations and occasional lightheadedness. Her medical history is significant for controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She has no known drug allergies. She has a 10 pack-year smoking history but quit 20 years ago. She currently drinks alcohol infrequently and denies any illicit drug use. There's no history of similar issues or known heart disease in her immediate family. The patient reports an onset of symptoms approximately 2 months ago  with increasing severity in the recent week. The symptoms are not associated with chest pain  shortness of breath  syncope  or lower extremity swelling. Examination reveals an irregularly irregular heart rhythm with pulse rate variably ranging from 90-140 bpm. Blood pressure levels are within controlled limits. Rest of the cardiovascular examination is unremarkable. EKG confirms atrial fibrillation.

A 72-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension presents to the clinic reporting palpitations and mild shortness of breath during exertion for the past two weeks. He notes a rapid  irregular 'fluttering' sensation in his chest which sometimes occur at rest but is more noticeable during his daily walks. He denies chest pain  dizziness  fainting  or lower limb swelling. He hasn't been monitoring his blood sugars recently but confirms adherence to his medications. The patient's family history is positive for stroke in his father. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. On examination  irregularly irregular pulse rate is noted without any signs of heart failure. His BMI is within the overweight range. Based on presenting symptoms  past medical history  and preliminary physical examination  acute atrial fibrillation is suspected.

Patient Representation: Mr. Davis  a 75-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes mellitus presents with complaints of palpitations  shortness of breath  and fatigue. He reports that the palpitations began suddenly while he was gardening and are ongoing. He also has associated lightheadedness but denies chest pain  nausea  or diaphoresis. His current medications include amlodipine  atorvastatin  and metformin. His blood pressure is 132/86 mmHg  pulse is 130 irregular  respirations are 18  and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. On physical examination  he has an irregular heart rate  and lungs are clear. An EKG confirms atrial fibrillation.

Problem representation:   A 72-year-old male presenting with recent onset episodes of palpitations  tiredness  and shortness of breath especially on exertion. He has an extensive medical history including ischemic heart disease  hypertension  and diabetes mellitus type 2. The patient admits to sporadic chest discomfort but no signs of angina. Neither dizziness nor syncope appears during episodes. Physical examination reveals irregular rhythm with a rapid pulse. EKG confirms atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation: An 82-year-old African American female with a past medical history of hypertension  diabetes  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the clinic with new onset palpitations and increased shortness of breath. The symptoms started suddenly a week ago. She has no history of prior cardiac disease. Family history is notable for a brother with atrial fibrillation. On physical exam  she appears in moderate respiratory distress. She has an irregularly irregular pulse  bilateral wheezing on chest auscultation  but no evidence of lower extremity edema. EKG confirmed atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. Laboratory findings revealed elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) and mildly elevated fasting blood glucose but were otherwise unremarkable.

A 68-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a 6-year history of ischemic cardiomyopathy presents with complaints of irregular heartbeat  fatigue  and shortness of breath. He also reports associated faintness and dizziness  especially when exerting himself physically over the last few days. The patient also mentions feeling palpitation in his chest  describing it as a ‘fluttering sensation’ which lasts for a few hours at a time. There is no history of chest pain  nocturnal dyspnea or orthopnea. He also denies history of smoking  alcohol consumption  and illicit drug use. His current medications include Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril and Atorvastatin for hypertension/lipids. There is a family history of heart disease with his father having suffered from a myocardial infarction at the age of 70. Physical examination reveals an irregularly irregular pulse and mildly elevated blood pressure. No other abnormalities are noted on physical examination. ECG confirms the diagnosis of atrial fibrillation. This patient’s presentation with irregular heartbeats  fatigue  shortness of breath  episodes of faintness  and an irregularly irregular pulse on physical examination strongly suggests the diagnosis of atrial fibrillation in the setting of underlying ischemic cardiomyopathy.

Patient Information: 73-year-old caucasian male  retired engineer  Chief Complaint: Fatigue  palpitations  and shortness of breath for last 2 weeks  Medical History: Diagnosed with mild hypertension 3 years ago  taking Lisinopril 10mg daily. History of moderate alcohol intake  quit drinking around 5 years ago. Ex-smoker  quit 10 years ago after a 35-year history of smoking. No previous diagnosis of cardiac diseases.  Family History: Father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 68. Mother has hypertension and diabetes.  Review of Systems: Denies dizziness  chest pain  symptoms of heart failure. Denies any recent weight loss or gains  changes in sleep or appetite. No fevers  chills  cough  or chest pain to suggest a concurrent infection. No blood in stools or black stools to suggest bleeding.  Physical Examination: Observably fatigued. Irregularly irregular pulse rate. Blood pressure is 142/90 mm Hg  heart rate is 110 beats/min with an irregular rhythm  respiratory rate is 19 breaths/min  body temperature is 98.6F  and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Cardiovascular exam shows no jugular venous distension  normal S1 and S2  no murmurs  rubs or gallops.  Presenting Problem: The patient's symptoms of fatigue  palpitations  and shortness of breath along with physical examination findings suggesting an irregular heart rate are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. The patient's history of hypertension is a known risk factor. Further noninvasive diagnostic evaluation would be warranted to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate the severity and possible causes.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male patient with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and chronic kidney disease stage III presents to the emergency department with palpitations and mild dyspnea. The patient notes that these symptoms began acutely approximately 8 hours prior. He further reports intermittent episodes of dizziness and feeling fatigue with exertional activities for the past 2 months which he initially attributed to aging. Examination findings reveal an irregularly irregular pulse  a slightly elevated blood pressure (145/95 mm Hg)  and normal oxygen saturations. An EKG confirms atrial fibrillation. Physical examination is otherwise within normal limits. Family history is significant for heart disease  including his father who had a myocardial infarction at the age of 65. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol moderately. The patient's medication list includes metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin.

Patient Demographics: A 72-year-old Caucasian male  Past Medical History: Hypertension  Type 2 Diabetes  Congestive Heart Failure  Presenting Symptoms: Patient presented to the emergency department complaining of palpitations and light-headedness over a period of several hours. He describes the fluttering sensations in his chest as irregular and very fast. This was associated with episodes of shortness of breath and fatiguability. The patient also reported a recent history of unexplained weight loss and frequent nocturia.  Relevant Findings: Physical examination revealed a blood pressure reading of 150/90 mmHg  heart rate of 140 beats per minute (irregularly irregular). EKG demonstrated atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. Laboratory evaluation showed elevated blood glucose level  HbA1c of 8.2% and slightly elevated BNP levels. There was no evidence of acute ischemia on cardiac enzymes. CHA2DS2-VASc score was calculated as 4 indicating high stroke risk.  Problem Representation: Herein is a case of a 72-year-old male with medical history significant for hypertension  Type 2 Diabetes  and congestive heart failure presenting with symptoms suggestive of atrial fibrillation  supported by an irregularly irregular rhythm at 140 beats per minute on EKG  associated systemic symptoms  and elevated stroke risk. There is a necessity for prompt rhythm or rate control alongside appropriate anticoagulation treatment coupled with optimization of his cardiac conditions.

Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  presenting with irregularly irregular heart rate of 120 beats per minute. He complains of a 2-day history of mild dizziness and fatigue. He denies any chest pain  palpitations  dyspnea  or syncope. On physical examination  he has an irregularly irregular heart rhythm  no murmurs  no jugular venous distention  and clear lungs. His blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg with no postural drop. CBC  BMP  TSH  and troponin values are within normal limits. His EKG demonstrates the absence of P waves  irregularly irregular rhythm  and a narrow QRS complex indicative of atrial fibrillation.

John Doe  a 68-year old Caucasian man with a past medical history significant for hypertension  chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and previous heavy alcohol use presents with heart palpitations and shortness of breath. The symptoms started approximately 36 hours prior to presenting to the Emergency Department. Mr. Doe says it feels like his heart is ""racing"". His blood pressure is elevated  and his heart rate varies from 85 to 165 beats per minute at rest. On physical examination  irregularly irregular tachycardia was noted. An EKG confirmed atrial fibrillation. Echocardiogram demonstrated a preserved ejection fraction with no significant valvular disease.

A 67-year-old African American male with a medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes presents with complaints of sudden onset palpitations for the past few hours. He describes the palpitations as rapid and irregular. He also reports an associated feeling of general weakness and light-headedness. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or loss of consciousness. He is compliant with his medications which include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Simvastatin. He has a 10-year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago. Physical examination reveals an irregularly irregular pulse rate of 115 bpm  BP 140/90 mmHg with no other significant findings. His EKG shows irregularly irregular rhythm consistent with atrial fibrillation.

Patient Profile: A 75 year-old Caucasian male.  Medical History: Hypertension and hypercholesterolemia diagnosed 10 years ago  managed with lisinopril and atorvastatin. Diagnosed with type II diabetes 5 years ago  currently on oral hypoglycemic agents. Had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) 2 years ago. Coronary artery disease diagnosed last year after which underwent angioplasty. Family history of ischemic heart disease. Former smoker and took alcohol socially. No known drug allergies.  Presentation: The patient presented to the emergency department with symptoms of fatigue  mild dyspnea  and palpitations. He mentions that these symptoms have been progressively increasing over the last week. He denies chest pain  syncope or dizziness  increasing dyspnea  orthopnea  or lower extremity swelling. Vital signs on admission – Blood pressure of 135/88mmHg  a regular pulse of 92/min  respiratory rate of 18/min  and O2 saturation of 98% on room air.  On examination  the patient was found to have an irregular heartbeat with an occasional skipped beat. He has no lower limb edema. Rest of the systemic examination was essentially normal. Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed irregularly irregular rhythm  absent P waves  and variability in R-R interval consistent with atrial fibrillation. Laboratory studies  including complete blood counts  kidney function  and electrolytes were normal except for increased blood sugar. Chest X-ray did not show any signs of heart failure or pneumonia.   This presentation suggests that the patient’s symptoms are likely secondary to atrial fibrillation possibly due to his pre-existing cardiac conditions. Further investigations and management are in line with the atrial fibrillation approach.

Patient Demographics: A 72-year-old Caucasian male  Medical History: Patient has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which are inadequately controlled with his current regimen. He is a former smoker  with a 20 pack year history quit 10 years ago.   Presentation: The patient presents with a 48-hour history of palpitations and fatigue. These symptoms were accompanied by shortness of breath  occasional chest discomfort  and dizziness. The patient denies any episodes of syncope  severe chest pain  or lower limb swelling. On examination  irregularly irregular heart rhythms  rapid heart rate  and blood pressure fluctuation were observed. EKG findings consistent with atrial fibrillation. Currently  the patient's CHADS-VASc score is estimated to be 3 (1 point for age  1 point for hypertension  1 point for diabetes).

Patient Information: A 67-year-old Caucasian male  Chief Complaint: Rapid heart beating and shortness of breath   History of Present Illness:  The patient is a 67-year-old male with a known history of high blood pressure  who presents with feeling of rapid heart beating and shortness of breath worsening over the last two days. The symptoms are more pronounced during moderate to high level physical activity but have also been present at rest. He denies any chest pain  fainting  dizziness or palpitations. No history of similar symptoms in the past. No recent travel history.  Medical History: The patient has Hypertension which is being managed with Lisinopril. No known history of diabetes  coronary artery disease or other co-morbidities. No previous surgeries. No known drug allergies.   Social History: Retired school teacher. Smoker with 20 pack-year history. Occasional alcohol intake but no illicit drug use. Lives with his wife and is relatively active.  Family History: Father died from a stroke at age 72; mother died at age 90 from complications of Alzheimer's disease. No known familial history of arrhythmias or early cardiac deaths.   Physical Examination: Heart rate is irregular and rapid at about 150 beats per minute  blood pressure at 142/83 mm Hg. Heart auscultation reveals irregular rhythm with no murmurs. There is no neck vein distension  pulmonary exam shows good air entry bilaterally with no added sounds. No peripheral oedema. Examination otherwise unremarkable.   Assessment: A 67-year-old male with a history of hypertension presenting with new-onset of atrial fibrillation characterized by rapid heart rate and shortness of breath. The cause of the atrial fibrillation in this patient could be chronic hypertension itself  but thyroid function  anemia and ischemic cardiac disease have to be ruled out. Other possible causes like excessive alcohol intake and smoking are also to be considered.

Patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male presenting with intermittent episodes of palpitations over the last 6 months. His history includes hypertension managed with Lisinopril  type 2 diabetes controlled with Metformin  and hyperlipidemia managed with Atorvastatin. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol in moderation. He reports associating these palpitations with feelings of fatigue  shortness of breath  and occasional mild chest discomfort. There is no associated dizziness  syncope  or lower extremity swelling. Family history is significant for heart disease. On examination  irregularly irregular heart rhythm is noted with no signs of acute heart failure. Preliminary analysis thus suggests atrial fibrillation.

Patient is a 75-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes mellitus type 2 who presents with complaints of palpitations and increasing shortness of breath over the last week. He denies chest pain  syncope  dizziness or vertigo. He also notes increased fatigue and diminished exercise tolerance. Physical exam is notable for an irregularly irregular pulse  mild peripheral edema  and pulmonary rales. Initial EKG confirms atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular rate. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. He has been compliant with his antihypertensive medications and oral hypoglycemic agents. There is no history of smoking  alcohol or illicit drug use. The patient lives with his wife  and he is retired.

Patient is an 82-year-old Caucasian male  long-term smoker with a significant medical history including hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and mild congestive heart failure. He presents to the emergency department with a complaint of palpitations that started approximately three hours prior  accompanied by mild shortness of breath and light-headedness. He has never experienced these symptoms before. On examination  his pulse rate fluctuates between 110 and 130 beats per minute and irregularly irregular rhythms were noticed. His blood pressure at presentation is 145/90 mmHg  and his oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Auscultation reveals an irregularly irregular heart rate without any added sounds. No signs of peripheral edema or jugular venous distension are noted. There is no cyanosis or clubbing.  Rest of his physical examination is within normal limits.

Patient is an 82-year-old African-American female with a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. She presents to the Emergency Department (ED) with a new on-set of palpitations and episodic shortness of breath over the past week. She does not recall any chest pain  diaphoresis  or syncope. She reports some light-headedness associated with the palpitations and shortness of breath. She denies any major change in diet  exercise  or medication regime. Initial vital signs show heart rate of 135  blood pressure of 140/85  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. Physical exam is significant for a rapid  regular rhythm  absent lateral apical impulse  and no noticeable murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Chest sounds are clear to auscultation bilaterally. All other exam findings are within normal limits. Initial EKG reveals atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history of hypertension  diabetes Mellitus Type II  and hyperlipidemia presents with new onset of palpitations and intermittent shortness of breath of three weeks' duration. The patient reports a rapid and irregular heartbeat  which is accompanied by episodes of light-headedness. There is no associated chest pain  visual changes  or unilateral weakness. He is currently managed with Metformin for diabetes  Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia and Lisinopril for hypertension. He is an ex-smoker and moderates alcohol consumption. Family history reveals that his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 67.

Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2  presenting with a 3-days history of palpitations  intermittent shortness of breath  and fatigue. He denies any chest pain  dizziness  syncope  or lower extremity edema. Upon physical examination  irregularly irregular heart sounds were identified. A 12-lead ECG was obtained revealing atrial fibrillation. Vital signs were stable. No signs of heart failure on physical examination.

Problem Representation:  A 67-year-old Caucasian male presents with complaints of palpitations which have been on and off for the last 2 weeks. Along with palpitations  the patient has been experiencing easy tiredness and increased frequency of urination. The patient has a previous history of ischemic heart disease  with coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) done 5 years ago. He also has been diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension  both conditions well controlled with medications. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. The patient takes aspirin and metoprolol as part of post-CABG medications  along with metformin for diabetes.  On examination  pulse rate was irregularly irregular  with a blood pressure of 130/85 mm Hg. On chest auscultation  no crepitations or wheezes were audible and heart sounds  though irregular  showed normal character and intensity. Point of maximal intensity was not shifted. Rest of the physical examination was non-contributory.   Given the history of cardiac disease with recent onset atrial fibrillation symptoms such as palpitations  tiredness and increased frequency of urination  further cardiac evaluation and management are suggested. His presenting symptoms also suggest he may be experiencing heart failure. This condition along with his comorbid conditions of diabetes and hypertension put him at risk for serious complications which need immediate management.

Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  moderate alcohol use and no prior episodes of atrial fibrillation. He presents today with complaints of rapid heart rate  intermittent chest discomfort  and feeling faint for 2 days. He has noticed some fatigue and shortness of breath upon exertion for the last week  more noticeable while climbing stairs. The patient does not report any stroke/TIA symptoms  recent surgeries  or illness. Hypertension is managed by his primary care doctor and he is compliant with his medications. He denies smoking or illicit drug use  but admits to drinking about 2-3 glasses of wine per night. He denies any family history of heart rhythm disorders. His blood pressure was slightly elevated but stable. On cardiac auscultation  his heart rhythm was irregularly irregular  suggesting atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation: Mr. J.M. is a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus.   Chief Complaint: He visited the Emergency Department complaining of recent onset palpitations and relative shortness of breath  describing the sensation as his ""heart skipping a beat.""  History of Present Illness: Upon further evaluation  he stated that his symptoms started approximately two days prior. There is no associated chest pain  dizziness  fainting  or lower extremity swelling. There were no triggers or aggravating factors identified. He denies any tobacco  alcohol  or illicit drug use. He reported compliance with his prescribed medications including metformin and amlodipine.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  his blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg  heart rate irregularly irregular at 110 beats/min  respirations 18 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation 96% on room air. Cardiac auscultation revealed irregular rhythm. There were no carotid bruits appreciated. Lung auscultation was clear bilaterally.   Based on the initial clinical picture  an EKG was conducted which confirmed atrial fibrillation.

Patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a significant past medical history of type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  presents with complaints of new onset palpitations and shortness of breath for the past one day. He also reports mild fatigue and lightheadedness  but denies chest pain  syncope  or swelling of lower limbs. The patient has a 40-year pack history of smoking  but quit 10 years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally and denies recreational drug use. The patient is currently on Metformin  Atorvastatin  and Lisinopril. Family history is significant for coronary artery disease in his father  who had a myocardial infarction at the age of 65. The patient has no history of stroke  and has never had symptoms like this before. Upon physical examination  he demonstrates irregularly irregular pulse and his electrocardiogram reveals atrial fibrillation.

Patient is a 73-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus  who now presents with palpitations  fatigue  dizziness  and mild dyspnea on exertion. On examination  irregularly irregular pulse is noted with a rate of 105 beats per minute. A previously unknown irregular rhythm is noted on 12-lead EKG  along with absence of P waves  which is consistent with atrial fibrillation. Blood pressure is slightly elevated at 145/85 mmHg. Patient admits non-compliance to previously prescribed antihypertensive medication and blood glucose monitoring.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with a new onset of palpitations  fatigue  and shortness of breath. He notes that these symptoms have developed over the past week. He has a 10 pack-year smoking history but quit 15 years ago. Family history includes a father with atrial fibrillation and a mother with coronary artery disease. On examination  he is found to have an irregularly irregular pulse and mild pedal edema. Electrocardiography confirms atrial fibrillation. Blood pressure and heart rate are within normal limits  but controlled with home medications. He has no history of bleeding or stroke. The patient’s active medications include metformin  lisinopril  and aspirin.

Mr. Thompson  a 72-year-old African American male with a known medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and hyperlipidemia presents to the clinic with symptoms of heart palpitations  shortness of breath  and feeling faint. The patient reports that this is the second time in a week that he has these symptoms and they tend to be more noticeable during physical activity. He denies chest pain  nausea  or diaphoresis. His medications include Metformin for his diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and a statin for hyperlipidemia.

A 72-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and sleep apnea presents to the clinic complaining of heart ""fluttering"" sensations  episodic shortness of breath  and fatigue for the last two weeks. He denies chest pain  syncope  or palpitations. His diabetes and hypertension are well-controlled with metformin and lisinopril  respectively. He uses CPAP nightly for his sleep apnea. On presentation  his heart rate is irregularly irregular  revealing suspected atrial fibrillation on physical examination. Further confirmation will be needed using electrocardiogram. His blood pressure is slightly elevated at 145/85 and he appears mildly dyspneic at rest. There is no ankle edema or jugular venous distention observed. Family history is notable for stroke in his mother.

Mr. Jones  a 78-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  presents with complaints of palpitations and intermittent dizziness for the past few weeks. He describes feeling an irregular and rapid heartbeat primarily during the latter part of the day. He has also noticed exertional dyspnea which noticeably reduced his exercise tolerance. His symptoms are unassociated with chest pain and he has not had any syncope or pre-syncope. Patient is on Metformin for his diabetes and amlodipine for hypertension. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. He has a family history of stroke and cardiovascular diseases. On examination  he is noted to have an irregularly irregular pulse and an EKG confirms atrial fibrillation. There are no signs of congestive heart failure and the remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable.

Patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  who presents with new onset of palpitations and intermittent shortness of breath for the past two weeks. He also reports fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance. No chest pain  fainting  or symptoms of congestive heart failure like lower limb swelling or nocturnal cough. He denies recent weight loss  fever  or other systemic symptoms. On examination  his heart rate is irregular with no significant murmur  lungs are clear  and there is no peripheral edema. His blood pressure is well controlled with medications and he is adherent to his diabetes management. The rest of physical examination is unremarkable. EKG shows irregular rhythm with no P waves  confirming atrial fibrillation.

Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2 who presents with new onset palpitations and intermittent episodes of dizziness over the past three weeks. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncope. Physical examination reveals an irregularly irregular heart rhythm. Electrocardiogram confirms atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response which he denies having on his previous annual check-ups. His blood pressure and blood glucose levels show poorly controlled hypertension and diabetes. The patient’s CHA2DS2-VASc score is 3  indicating an intermediate risk of stroke.

Patient is a 75-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He presents with complaints of palpitations  fatigue  and mild dyspnea during exertion. He reports these symptoms have been worsening gradually over the past few months. On further examination  it was discovered that the patient was experiencing irregularly irregular pulse and auscultation revealed an irregular heart rhythm. An electrocardiogram (ECG) confirmed the presence of atrial fibrillation. The patient's blood pressure was slightly elevated at 145/85 mmHg and his blood glucose level was within the expected range for a patient with controlled diabetes. The patient denied any chest pain. Additionally  he lost his wife to a stroke two years ago and lives alone with two adult children in another city. He is moderately mobile with the help of a walking stick. He smokes about half a pack of cigarettes per day and drinks alcohol socially. He has been compliant with his anti-hypertensive and oral hypoglycemic medication.

Patient Information: A 76-year-old Caucasian female  Chief Complaint: Heart palpitations and episodes of slight shortness of breath  History of Present Illness: Patient presents with symptoms starting 2 weeks ago that have been worsening. Patient also reports of occasional lightheadedness but no syncope  chest pain  or exertional symptoms.   Past Medical History: Hypertension for 10 years controlled with medication  treated hyperlipidemia. No prior cardiac history.  Social History: Non-smoker  rare alcohol use. Patient is retired and lives with her daughter.  Family History: Father had onset of AFib at age 80.   Review of Systems: Positive for the feeling of a rapid  irregular heartbeat and intermittent dizziness. Denied chest pain  cough  wheezing  lower extremity swelling.   Physical Examination: Vital values within normal ranges. Physical examination reveals a tachycardic  irregularly irregular rhythm. No murmurs  rubs or gallops heard. No distension of neck veins  lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally. Adequate perfusion  no peripheral edema. No focal neurological deficits.  Assessment & Plan: The findings are indicative of the possible onset of Atrial Fibrillation (AFib). Detailed image exams (ECG  echocardiogram) and blood tests (to check electrolytes  thyroid function  and screening for anemia) will be ordered to confirm. The patient will be educated about the condition and potential treatment plans will be discussed once we have all necessary results.

Patient Profile: A 70-year-old Caucasian male retired teacher from the Midwest.  Relevant Medical History:  The patient has a medical history of hyperlipidemia  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hypertension for which he takes metformin  simvastatin  and lisinopril  respectively. No history of cardiac issues  surgery  or smoking. Family history includes a father who passed at 78 due to an ischemic stroke and a mother who passed at 80 due to lung cancer.  Presenting Symptoms:  The patient has a chief complaint of a persistently rapid and irregular heartbeat with associated dyspnea during routine activities which have progressively worsened over the past week. Additionally  he also reports paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  fatigue  and occasional feelings of lightheadedness. No recent changes in diet  physical activity  or medication regime.   On physical examination  his heart rate is irregular  with a rate of 130 bpm  blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg  and other vitals are stable. Electrocardiogram confirms atrial fibrillation.   Other Labs and Investigations: Patient's complete blood count  renal function  and liver function tests are normal. HbA1c level is 7.5%. Thyroid function tests are within normal limits. The echocardiogram reveals no structural abnormalities.   Assessment:  The patient presenting with non-valvular atrial fibrillation (AFib) with rapid ventricular response  possibly secondary to long-standing hypertension. His symptoms and EKG confirm the diagnosis. The patient’s elevated blood pressure and high heart rate need to be addressed. Also  due to the increased risk of stroke with AFib  consideration for anticoagulation therapy should be made. CHA2DS2–VASc score (Congestive heart failure  Hypertension  Age ≥75 years  Diabetes mellitus  previous Stroke or transient ischemic attack  Vascular disease  Age 65–74 years  Sex category) is 3  which indicates a moderate-high risk of stroke and typically suggests the need for anticoagulation therapy.

A 68-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of hypertension  coronary artery disease  and high cholesterol presents with complaints of palpitations and mild dyspnea on exertion ongoing for the past two days. His vital signs on presentation are stable but tachycardic with an irregular rhythm. An ECG confirms the presence of atrial fibrillation. He denies any chest pain  severe shortness of breath  or syncope. Exam is largely unremarkable with the exception of an irregularly irregular cardiac rhythm noted on auscultation.

Patient is a 75-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension and diabetes presented with symptoms of fatigue  palpitations  and shortness of breath for 2 weeks. His family also noticed a decline in his ability to perform daily tasks. On examination  the patient was noted to have an irregularly irregular heart rate. The remainder of his examination was unremarkable. An EKG confirmed a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation. His lab results showed no abnormalities  except for elevated blood sugar levels. His anticoagulation status was addressed to assess stroke risk.

Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a significant past medical history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2  presenting with palpitations  left-sided chest discomfort  and dyspnea on exertion. He also reports recent bouts of fatigue and occasional dizziness for the past two weeks. He denies any history of syncope  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or lower extremity edema. The patient has been compliant with his antihypertensive and anti-diabetic medications  denies smoking  alcohol  and recreational drug intake. Examination reveals irregularly irregular pulse and elevated blood pressure. Cardiovascular exam reveals no murmurs. EKG confirms atrial fibrillation. The patient was subsequently put on anticoagulation therapy.

Patient is a 76-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He presents today complaining of intermittent palpitations for the last few weeks  associated with shortness of breath and mild fatigue. He denies any chest pain  dizziness  or syncope. On physical exam  he is noted to have an irregularly irregular pulse. Electrocardiogram confirms atrial fibrillation. There is no evidence of acute heart failure. Due to his age and comorbidities  including hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  and now atrial fibrillation  he is at high risk for stroke and appropriate investigations and interventions need to be started urgently.

A 70-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2 presents with palpitations and mild shortness of breath. The patient describes the palpitations as an irregular and rapid heartbeat that started abruptly a week ago  and has occurred sporadically since then  lasting for minutes to an hour each time. The patient denies any associated chest pain  dizziness or loss of consciousness. On examination  his heart rate is noted to be irregularly irregular  without any obvious murmur. His blood pressure is slightly elevated at 150/90 mmHg. There are no features suggesting congestive heart failure  such as peripheral edema or pulmonary crackles. The preliminary diagnosis based on this assessment is atrial fibrillation.

A 72-year-old African American male with a medical history significant for hypertension and type II diabetes presents to the clinic reporting symptoms of palpitations  shortness of breath on exertion  and occasional light-headedness. These symptoms have been escalating over the past two weeks. Patient denies any chest pain  recent illness  or falls. Patient lives alone  is a non-smoker  and drinks alcohol occasionally. On examination  irregular pulse noted with a rate of 110 bpm; other vitals including blood pressure within normal limits. Examination also reveals mild peripheral edema.  This represents a common presentation for a patient with atrial fibrillation (AFib)  characterized by an irregularly irregular heartbeat  a fast heart rate  and corresponding symptoms of heart palpitations  fatigue  and shortness of breath. Blood pressure is often elevated in these patients owing to their medical history of hypertension. The patient's age and history of hypertension and diabetes increase his risk for developing AFib. The presence of peripheral edema could suggest possible heart failure resulting from long standing  untreated AFib.

Patient  Mr. Johnson  is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for hypertension  moderate alcohol use  obesity (BMI 32.0). He presents to the clinic with heart palpitations and occasional dyspnea over the last two weeks. He describes palpitations as irregular  rapid heart rates which he noticed principally at rest. He has no chest pain  dizziness  or syncope. On examination  he exhibits signs of irregularly irregular pulse while his blood pressure is moderately controlled. Electrocardiogram confirms the presence of atrial fibrillation with a ventricular rate of 110. His physical exam is otherwise unremarkable  lacking features of heart failure such as peripheral edema or lung crackles. He doesn't have any history of stroke  thromboembolism  or bleeding disorder.

Patient Information: A 73-year-old male.  Medical History: History of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both controlled with medication. No prior cardiac events. Non-smoker and occasional alcohol use.  Presenting Symptoms: Patient reports experiencing intermittent chest discomfort and palpitations for the past four weeks. Also admitted feeling increased fatigue and slight shortness of breath upon physical exertion. However  he denies having experienced any severe chest pain  syncope  or symptoms suggesting heart failure like swelling of feet or weight gain.   On physical examination  he was found to have an irregular rhythm on cardiac auscultation with an otherwise normal cardiac exam. A subsequent EKG confirmed a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation.

Patient Profile: A 75-year-old African American male.  Presenting Issue: The patient reports palpitations and unusual shortness of breath intermittently for the past two weeks.  Medical History: The patient has a known past medical history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes. Both conditions are managed with consistent medication therapy. No previous cardiac complaints. The patient also has a history of smoking  with a 30 pack-year history  but quit five years ago. No known drug allergies. Regular medication includes Metformin and Lisinopril.  Symptoms: On physical examination  his heart rate was irregular  fluctuating between 70 to 110 beats per minute. The patient reported no chest pain  dizziness  or fainting attacks. He has no signs of heart failure or thromboembolism. However  he reports feeling occasional irregular  rapid heartbeats  followed by a ""thud"" and subsequently a period of normal rhythm. He also reports episodes of shortness of breath  especially on exertion.   Inference: The patient's symptoms  coupled with his medical history and physical examination  suggest a possible diagnosis of atrial fibrillation. Further diagnostic tests  like an EKG  will be needed to confirm the diagnosis.

A 72-year-old Hispanic female with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes presents to the clinic with recent onset fatigue and episodes of palpitations. The patient reports that these symptoms have been intermittent but persistent over the past three days. She denies any associated chest pain  shortness of breath  or dizziness. On physical examination  an irregularly irregular heart rate is noted. Electrocardiogram shows atrial fibrillation. The rest of the cardiovascular  respiratory and gastrointestinal examination is unremarkable. Her current medications include metformin for diabetes and lisinopril for hypertension.

The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He presents with a 3-day history of palpitations  lightheadedness  and increasing shortness of breath with exertion. He denies experiencing chest pain  nausea  or diaphoresis. He has noted a decrease in his exercise tolerance over the last couple of months. His baseline labs about 3 months ago showed good control of his diabetes with an HbA1c of 6.5 and well-managed BP. He denies tobacco  alcohol  or illicit drug use  but has a family history of cardiovascular disease with a father who had an MI in his early 60s. The patient's vitals include BP of 142/88 mmHg  HR of 132 bpm irregular  RR of 18 breaths per minute  SpO2 of 94% on room air  and temp of 98.6 F. He appears somewhat anxious and mildly distressed. His cardiovascular exam reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm  without murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Pulmonary exam is normal with clear breath sounds bilaterally. No peripheral edema is noted on the physical exam. An ECG shows atrial fibrillation with a fast ventricular response.

Patient Information: 70-year-old  Caucasian male   Medical History: Known case of hypertension for the last 15 years  Type II diabetes mellitus for 10 years  and a history of transient ischemic attacks (TIA) two years back. Ex-smoker  quit 10 years ago with a 20-pack year smoking history.  Chief Complaint: Presents with new-onset episodes of rapid heartbeats and intermittent episodes of feeling light-headedness witnessed over the past three weeks.  Physical Examination: Irregularly irregular heart rhythm observed; resting heart rate ranging between 90-160 beats per minute  blood pressure stable on antihypertensive therapy  blood glucose under control on oral hypoglycemic agents.   Additional Information: No other significant family history of cardiovascular diseases. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  fatigue  or other systemic symptoms.  Given the patient’s symptomatic irregularly irregular pulse  history of hypertension  type II diabetes  and TIA  he is likely suffering from atrial fibrillation. Prolonged uncontrolled atrial fibrillation could contribute to the risk of further cerebrovascular incidents. Immediate further investigation and management are warranted.

Mr. Johnson  a 72-year-old African American mail carrier with a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  presents with a six-hour history of palpitations and fatigue. He recently noticed his heart ""skipping beats"". He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  dizziness  or syncope. He also denies alcohol or caffeine abuse in the past. His medications include lisinopril  metformin  and atorvastatin. Upon physical examination  he was noticed to have an irregularly irregular rhythm with a heart rate of 110 bpm and blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg. His cardiopulmonary examination disclosed no murmurs or accessory lung sounds. There's no lower extremity edema. His EKG showed atrial fibrillation with a ventricular rate of 110 bpm. No ischemic changes were noticed. A thyroid function test was normal. His echocardiogram exhibited normal left ventricular systolic function with no valve abnormalities. His INR on presentation was 1.2.

Patient is an 85-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus who presents with a new-onset rapid  irregular heart rate of 110 beats per minute  palpitations  and bouts of breathlessness for the past 2 days. Patient also reports a feeling of fatigue  though denies any chest pain  dizziness or syncope. Upon examination  variable S1 and an irregularly irregular rhythm are observed. No pedal edema or signs of congestive cardiac failure are present. There is no significant family history of cardiac diseases. EKG confirmed atrial fibrillation. She has been compliant with her antihypertensive and hypoglycaemic medications till date. In light of her age and her present health condition  stroke risk is to be evaluated.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension  coronary artery disease  and TIA presents with palpitations  shortness of breath  and fatigue for a duration of 2 weeks. The patient notes that the irregular heartbeats are a new onset and seem to be getting more frequent. He has also been experiencing increasing fatigue over the last week. No chest pain  dizziness  fainting episodes  or leg swelling. The patient is a former smoker but denies alcohol use. He is currently taking Aspirin  Lisinopril  and Metoprolol.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Green is a 70-year-old retired engineer who presents to the clinic with newly developed symptoms of heart palpitations and episodes of shortness of breath during minimal exertion over the past two weeks. He also had occasional bouts of lightheadedness and fatigue. He denied chest pain  shortness of breath at rest  syncope  or any other focal deficits.   He has a known history of hypertension controlled with Lisinopril and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus managed with Metformin. He had a history of smoking for 30 years but quit 10 years ago. There are no known drug allergies. There is no family history of cardiac diseases. He has not been on any anticoagulant therapy to date.   Examination reveals an irregularly irregular pulse and blood pressure of 145/85. Rest of the general and systemic examination is uneventful. Initial Electrocardiogram (ECG) at the clinic confirms atrial fibrillation.

Problem Representation:  A 76-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder (COPD)  and a 40-pack year smoking history presents with palpitations and shortness of breath. He describes an irregular  rapid heartbeat that started suddenly and has not improved. He rates his dyspnea as a 7 out of 10. He denies chest pain  dizziness  or syncopal episodes. On examination  his heart rate is noted to be irregularly irregular with rates varying between 90-150 BPM. Breath sounds reveal decreased air entry bilaterally with expiratory wheezing. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. With a known history of smoking and COPD  the sudden onset and persistence of irregular rapid heartbeat and dyspnea suggest atrial fibrillation.

Patient Profile: A white male  68-years-old  Medical History: Diagnosed with high blood pressure  type 2 diabetes  and hyperlipidemia.  Symptoms: Presents with irregular heartbeats  tiredness  shortness of breath  and light-headed episodes. Noticed his heart fluttering in an irregular pattern  primarily over the last three weeks.  Current Presentation: The patient reports worsening fatigue over the period and has been experiencing an intermittent fast heart rate. He states the palpitations often come on at rest  are unprovoked and are sometimes associated with mild breathlessness but deny any chest pain or syncope.  Other Relevant Information: He is a retired engineer  quit smoking 10 years ago  does occasional alcohol use and has a high-carbohydrate diet. He takes Losartan for his high blood pressure  Metformin for diabetes  and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia. His father had a history of stroke.  Physical Exam Results: Blood pressure is slightly elevated. The cardiovascular exam reveals irregularly irregular rhythm with no murmur. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Given the symptoms and the irregular pulse found on physical examination  the patient is likely suffering from atrial fibrillation.

A 68-year-old African-American female retired school teacher with a past medical history significant for hypertension  dyslipidemia  diabetes  and heart failure with preserved ejection fraction presents to the clinic complaining of palpitations  intermittent lightheadedness  and shortness of breath on exertion. These symptoms have been progressively worsening over the past 2 weeks. She denies any syncopal episodes  but confirms feeling fatigued more than usual. On physical examination  irregularly irregular rhythm was noticed along with mildly elevated blood pressure. Further investigation revealed that the patient is in atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation: A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department complaining of palpitations and occasional shortness of breath that has been ongoing for the past 2 days.  Medical History: The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is a 40-pack-year smoker but quit 5 years ago. He does not have a history of previous heart disease. His diabetes and hypertension are well managed on oral metformin and amlodipine respectively. He denies any recent infections  chest pain  travel  or family history of clotting disorders. The patient also denies any drug or alcohol abuse.   Current Symptoms: The patient reports rapid and irregular heartbeats noticed primarily at rest and accompanied by intermittent shortness of breath. He denies associated symptoms of chest pain  light-headedness  syncope  or any neurological deficits. Physical examination reveals an irregular rapid heartbeat but is otherwise within normal limits. The rest of his cardiovascular exam reveals no murmur  rub  or gallop.  His lungs are clear to auscultation. Neurological exam is nonfocal. He is afebrile and his vitals are stable except for an elevated heart rate.

Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes who presents with new-onset palpitations. Patient reports a sensation of ""heart fluttering"" being experienced for the past 48 hours along with a new onset fatigue and slight shortness of breath. There is a recorded history of uncontrolled blood pressure over the last couple of months and patient has been inconsistently adherent to prescribed antihypertensive and hypoglycemic agents. He denies any chest pain  dizziness  syncope  dysphagia  or lower extremity swelling. He has no known allergies. He drinks alcohol occasionally and quit smoking ten years ago. Family history is remarkable for father who had a stroke at the age of 72. Examination reveals an irregularly irregular heart rhythm with minimal lower-extremity edema. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. The ECG performed confirms atrial fibrillation. The patient is otherwise alert  oriented and in no apparent distress. Further evaluation and management is underway.

Patient Information: Mr. Smith is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking.   Chief Complaint: ""Rapid  irregular heartbeat""   History of Present Illness: Over the past week  Mr. Smith noticed a recurring  irregular and rapid heartbeat  sometimes accompanied by fatigue and shortness of breath after moderate activity like climbing stairs. Denied chest pain  nausea  vomiting  or syncope. No change in urine output. Reported sleeping on two pillows to alleviate shortness of breath when lying flat.  Past Medical History: Hypertension (managed with Losartan)  Hyperlipidemia (managed with Atorvastatin)  30 pack-years of smoking (quit 10 years ago). No previous surgeries.  Family History: Father with coronary artery disease. Mother with stroke. Two paternal uncles with atrial fibrillation.  Social History: Lives alone  retired. No alcohol  reports smoking cessation 10 years ago  no use of illicit drugs.   Review of Systems: Occasional headaches. No loss of balance  no fever  no chills.  Physical Exam:  Vitals: BP 140/90 mmHg  HR 115 BPM irregularly irregular  SpO2 95% on room air  RR 18/min  Temperature 98.6F.  General: Appears well  alert and oriented x3  pink skin overlay  no presence of cyanosis/clammy skin. Cardiac: Irregular rhythm  no murmurs/rubs/gallops  capillary refill < 2 seconds. Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally  no use of accessory muscles during respiration. Abdomen: Non distended  soft  with no tenderness. Extremities: No edemas  peripheral pulsations present.  Assessment: Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation in a 72-year-old male with vascular risk factors (hypertension  hyperlipidemia) and positive family history. His symptoms  including irregular heartbeat  fatigue  and dyspnea on exertion indicate that he may be experiencing episodes of atrial fibrillation  which is confirmed by irregularly irregular rhythm on cardiac examination. The patient will likely need additional tests  including an EKG and possibly a Holter monitor  to confirm these findings and determine the best course of management.

Patient: Mr. Robert Smith  a 62-year-old Caucasian male.  Medical History: History of hypertension managed with medication  and high cholesterol. Had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) 2 years ago. Non-smoker and alcohol consumption within the recommended limit.  Problem Representation:  Mr. Smith has come to the ER with complaints of palpitations for the past day  with an associated intermittent chest discomfort  a feeling of shortness of breath  and fatigue. He denies syncope  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or recent illness. His BP is mildly elevated at 145/80  and his heart rate is irregular and fast  at about 130 bpm. His exam is notable for an irregularly irregular rhythm with no murmurs  and his lungs are clear. So  this presentation is most consistent with atrial fibrillation  likely due to chronically untreated hypertension. His history suggestive of ischemic heart disease and previous TIA also adds to his risks. Immediate cardiovascular consultation  EKG  and further cardiovascular risk stratification is needed.

Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He presents to the ED with complaints of palpitations  intermittent shortness of breath  and generalized fatigue for the last three days. The patient noticed a sudden onset of these symptoms that have progressively gotten worse. He denies chest pain  nausea  vomiting  diaphoresis or syncope. Patient is a former smoker of 20 years  quit 15 years ago  and drinks alcohol socially. Family history reveals both parents died of heart disease. Examination reveals irregularly irregular heart rate  elevated blood pressure  and diminished breath sounds in the lower lobes. His ECG shows atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. There's no evidence of ischemia. Initial blood investigations reveal mildly elevated troponin I levels.

Patient is an 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia presenting with shortness of breath and palpitations. Patient reports that these symptoms have been on and off for the past month but have recently become significantly more severe and frequent. The patient denies chest pain  dizziness  loss of consciousness but does note fatigue. Patient’s family history reveals that his father had a pacemaker for arrhythmia. On physical examination  patient's pulse was irregular  with a rate of 110bpm. EKG on presentation shows evidence of atrial fibrillation. No signs of heart failure were seen on echocardiogram. Lab results reveal no electrolyte abnormalities.

Patient Profile: A 72-year-old African American male.  Medical History: Hypertension  Type 2 Diabetes  history of smoking; no prior surgeries or known allergies. He has been moderately compliant with his prescribed regimen of Metformin and Lisinopril.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents with a complaint of intermittent palpitations for the past one week. He also reports feeling fatigue and occasional shortness of breath on exertion. The patient has had episodes of generalized weakness and dizziness but no chest pain  syncope  or dyspnea at rest. On physical examination  his heart rate was irregularly irregular and rapid. He denies any recent infections  alcohol intake  and caffeine products.  Based on the patient's age  symptoms  and medical history  he is suspected to have atrial fibrillation  likely due to his history of hypertension or possibly due to complication from his diabetes. Further investigations and management are required to confirm this.

Patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for chronic hypertension  hyperlipidemia and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He presents with complaints of intermittent palpitations  lightheadedness and exertional dyspnea for a couple of weeks. He also notes a recent decrease in exercise tolerance. He denies any chest pain  syncope  or presyncope. The patient has a prior history of ischemic stroke 2 years ago but has had no recurrent symptoms. He states he is compliant with his medications including metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin  but he is not on any anticoagulation. His BMI is 28 and he doesn’t have any known drug allergies. A 12-lead ECG shows an irregularly irregular ventricular response  with absent P waves  suggestive of atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Roberts is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and hypothyroidism who presents with an irregularly irregular heartbeat. The sensation of a fluttering heart began suddenly yesterday and has been continuous ever since. Associated symptoms include fatigue  lightheadedness  shortness of breath with exertion  and reduced exercise tolerance  but no chest pain  dyspnea at rest  syncope or pre-syncope. He denied any recent sick contacts  infections  recent travel or significant stressors. His routine medications include levothyroxine and lisinopril. He has no known allergies  does not smoke  drinks alcohol occasionally  and does not use any illicit substances. His father had a stroke at 75. On physical examination  his pulse is irregularly irregular with a rate of 102 beats per minute. Blood pressure is 148/90 mmHg. Heart exam reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm with no murmurs. Examination of other systems is normal. EKG shows atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. The patient is currently hemodynamically stable but expresses significant anxiety about his symptoms.

Patient Demographics: Mr. Jones  a 72-year-old African American male  retired teacher.  Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes. His medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Aspirin. He quit smoking 20 years ago but has a past history of 30 pack-year smoking. He drinks alcohol socially and denies any recreational drug use.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Jones presented to the ER with complaints of palpitations and occasional shortness of breath  mainly on exertion  for the past two days. He also reports feeling lightheaded but denies any chest pain  syncope  cough  or fever. He has no family history of cardiac disease. His blood pressure is slightly elevated at 145/85 mmHg  heart rate is irregular and rapid at 110 beats per minute. An EKG done immediately in the ER reveals atrial fibrillation.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:  The patient is a 66-year-old Caucasian female named Mary.  Demographics:  Her occupation includes being a retired librarian. She is a non-smoker and drinks socially. She lives with her husband in their own home in a suburban area. She has Medicare as her primary form of health insurance. She is moderately active with regular exercise  walking about 2 kilometers a day with her dog.  Presenting Complaint:  Her chief complaint concerns generalized fatigue  occasional dizziness  and irregular heartbeat. These symptoms started gradually over the past 2 weeks and have progressively worsened over time.  Past Medical History:  Her past medical history is significant for: 1. Hypertension: Diagnosed about 10 years ago and kept well-controlled with daily administration of Lisinopril. 2. Hyperlipidemia: Diagnosed 8 years ago and controlled with Atorvastatin. 3. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed 5 years ago. She is on oral anti-diabetics (Metformin) to manage her condition.  Family History:  There is a significant family history of cardiovascular disease. Her father had a myocardial infarction at age 58  and her sister was diagnosed with hypertension and atrial fibrillation (AF) in her early sixties.  Developing Problem List: 1. Fatigue: Started two weeks ago and progressively worsening. 2. Dizziness: Intermittent events observed for the same period as fatigue. 3. Irregular heartbeat: Predominantly observed during the evening time.     Overall  considering her symptoms  past medical history  family history  it is suspicious that she may be experiencing atrial fibrillation. Further diagnostic tests including Electrocardiography (ECG) are crucial to confirm the condition  and adjustments to her treatment plan are warranted in light of the potential diagnosis.

Patient Problem Representation:  Demographics: Subject is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  who is a retired engineer and lives with his wife. He quit smoking 15 years ago and has occasional alcohol consumption. He enjoys golfing as an exercise and has a family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Chief Complaint: The patient mainly presents with complaints of shortness of breath and feeling of heart racing which he described as ""fluttering"" in his chest. The symptoms have been recurrent for the last 10 days but have increased in intensity in the last 48 hours.   Past Medical History:  His medical history includes: 1. Essential Hypertension: Diagnosed 15 years ago  and has been under control with medication (Lisinopril 10mg daily). 2. Hyperlipidemia: Diagnosed 10 years ago  controlled with dietary management and medication (Atorvastatin 20mg daily). 3. Type 2 Diabetes: Diagnosed 8 years ago  managed by Metformin 1000mg twice a day. 4. Mild Chronic Kidney Disease secondary to hypertension and diabetes. 5. He had a Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) about 3 years ago with full recovery.  Medications: Along with aforementioned medications  he takes a daily low-dose aspirin (81mg) for secondary prevention after his TIA.  Allergies:  No known drug allergies.
