Family History:  Father died of myocardial infarction at 68 years old and mother had a stroke at 73 years old. He has two siblings  one of whom has coronary artery disease.  Review of Systems: Negative for chest pain  dizziness  syncope  notable weight changes  changes in urination or thirst. No changes in bowel habits or sleep pattern changes.   Social History: He has three children and six grandchildren. He is a retired engineer who enjoys playing golf. He quit smoking 15 years ago and drinks socially. He spends winters in Florida.  Vacation History: The patient has recently returned from a vacation in the Bahamas. He denied any illnesses during his travel or after his return.   This typical presentation is indicative of atrial fibrillation which could possibly be paroxysmal given the sporadic nature and increasing intensity of symptoms. The patient's past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia and TIA could have contributed to his current condition. Further diagnostic tests like ECG and echocardiogram may be needed for confirmatory diagnosis.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: Demographics: The patient is a 75-year-old Caucasian male  retired  who lives independently. He is a nonsmoker and consumes alcohol socially. His diet is balanced  and he engages in regular physical activity. He lives with his wife  and they have two adult children. He has a history of moderate hypertension and takes medication for it.  Chief Complaint: The patient has been complaining of intermittent palpitations  which he describes as his heart ""racing."" These episodes have been occurring over the past month  leading to fatigue and shortness of breath during physical activities. He also reported occasional lightheadedness  although no syncope.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension for the last 10 years  controlled with medication. He also had a myocardial infarction 12 years ago and has since been on a regimen of aspirin and statins. Patient endorsed a family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father passing away from a stroke at the age of 82.   Current Medications: Aspirin 81 mg daily  atorvastatin 20 mg daily  and lisinopril 10 mg daily for hypertension.  Recent Lab Results: BMP obtained in office was normal; potassium was 4.4  sodium 140  creatinine 1.0  and glucose 98. The patient's latest EKG demonstrated irregular rhythm consistent with atrial fibrillation.  Review of Systems: Positive for fatigue  mild dyspnea  and sporadic palpitations. Negative for syncope  chest pain  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  edema  cognitive changes  and other systemic symptoms.  Assessment: Probable atrial fibrillation based on symptoms and EKG findings.   Plan: The patient should be referred to a cardiologist for formal diagnosis and management of new-onset atrial fibrillation  including echocardiogram and decisions about anticoagulation. Patient education regarding symptom management  the importance of adherence to medications  and lifestyle modifications to control his hypertension and prevent cardiovascular events are also needed.  His medication should be reviewed and adjusted as necessary. Regular follow-ups should be scheduled to monitor his condition  adherence to treatment  and any potential side effects of medications.

Problem Representation:   Patient Profile: A 72-year-old Caucasian male born and residing in North Carolina  presenting with a complaint of intermittent palpitations that he describes as an uneven or 'fluttering' heartbeat.  Demographics:  The patient lives with his wife of 50 years and they have two grown-up children. He is a retired teacher  a non-smoker  and he consumes alcohol in moderation. He reports no known drug allergies.   Presenting Symptoms:  The patient has noticed irregular heartbeats over the last few months that are not associated with physical exertion or emotional stress. Recently  he has been feeling a bit more fatigued than usual  feels occasional shortness of breath and has had a few episodes of light-headedness. However  he didn't experience any chest pain  syncope  or fainting attacks.   Medical History:  The patient has a history of Hypertension for which he takes Amlodipine. He has been diagnosed with Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus 8 years ago and manages it with Metformin and diet control. His BMI is 28  signaling overweight  but he does moderate daily exercise. The patient has no history of any cardiac diseases  stroke  pulmonary diseases  or any major surgeries.   Family History:  His father died of a Myocardial Infraction at the age of 78  his mother passed away at 85 due to natural causes. He has one brother with no major health issues.   Based on the presenting symptoms  medical history  and age  the patient appears to potentially have Atrial Fibrillation (AF). It is the most common type of arrhythmia  especially in the elderly population  and can lead to severe complications such as stroke or heart failure if left untreated. Given the patient's history of Hypertension and Type-2 Diabetes  he is at a higher risk for developing AF. Further diagnostic tests  such as an electrocardiogram (ECG) and echocardiogram  will help confirm the diagnosis. If AF is confirmed  he would need to start on oral anticoagulation therapy to reduce the risk of stroke  along with other AF management plans.

Problem Representation:   Demographic Details: Mr. X is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired  from an urban setting. He is a former 20-pack-year smoker who quit smoking approximately 10 years ago and reports moderate alcohol intake. He has a sedentary lifestyle and is overweight with a BMI of 29. He lives with his wife and maintains a diet high in red meat and sodium.   Medical History: He has a medical history significant for well-controlled hypertension (on ACE inhibitors and diuretics)  suffered myocardial infarction two years ago with subsequent angioplasty  and maintained on low dose aspirin. He also has uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus (on metformin and sulfonylureas). No known allergies have been reported and he's not on any other medication or over-the-counter drugs. Family history is relevant for cardiovascular diseases.   Key Clinical Features: Mr. X is presenting with an increasing fatigue that has been progressively worse over the past few weeks  along with irregular heart beats. He reports occasional episodes of dizziness  breathlessness  and fainting. Recently  he has also noticed swelling in his legs.   Clinical Assessment: Physical examination findings reveal an irregularly irregular pulse  jugular venous distension  and lower extremity edema. Hemodynamic status (BP: 160/90 mmHg) is stable although resting heart rate is high (110 bpm). Routine blood tests show poorly controlled blood glucose levels.   The above findings suggest a working diagnosis of atrial fibrillation. Further assessment including electrocardiogram and echocardiogram are planned for confirmation and to assess the severity of disease.  Management will be per guidelines including rate control  rhythm control strategy and anticoagulation for stroke prevention  as well as managing his comorbid conditions.

Problem Representation:  Mr. John Smith is an 82-year-old Caucasian male patient  presenting with recent onset palpitations and occasional shortness of breath over the past two weeks. He further raises concerns about episodes of fatigue and lightheadedness. His baseline functional status is good; he is able to perform his regular household chores and lives independently.  His past medical history is notable for hypertension for which he has been on a calcium channel blocker (Amlodipine) for many years. He also has a history of transient ischemic attack (TIA) three years ago  for which he's on low-dose aspirin. He underwent a prostatectomy for prostate cancer 6 years ago and has been cancer-free since. No prior episodes of cardiac arrhythmias or known heart disease.  John is a non-smoker  drinks alcohol occasionally  and has a family history of myocardial infarction (father and elder brother). His BMI is within the appropriate range for his age and height but he has been generally sedentary in his habits. Nutritional status is adequate and he follows a balanced diet.  Remaining vaccines  including annual flu and recommended pneumococcal are up to date. His medications include Amlodipine 10mg/day and Aspirin 81mg/day. No known drug allergies.  On examination  his heart rate is irregularly irregular and an EKG confirms atrial fibrillation. Blood pressure is moderately elevated. There's no evidence of heart failure on physical examination.  Given his concomitant conditions  especially hypertension and past history of TIA  he falls into a higher-risk category for stroke in association with atrial fibrillation. Consequently  he may warrant anticoagulation therapy  but a careful discussion of benefits  risks  and alternatives should be carried out. As initial interventions  rate control and rhythm control could be considered. Also  lifestyle modification can play an essential part in the overall management plan. Lifestyle changes may include an increase in physical exercise  modifications to diet  optimal weight management  and regular monitoring of his blood pressure at home.

Regular monitoring of glucose level and possibly start antidiabetic therapy.

Atrial fibrillation is a highly possible diagnosis given this evidence and needs to be confirmed by further medical examination and tests  including an EKG to record heart's electrical signals and an echocardiogram to view heart's structure and function. Problem Representation:  Patient Description: A 67-year-old Caucasian male has presented with fluttering in the chest and occasional rapid heartbeat. He also has type-2 diabetes mellitus which is controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents. He has suffered a minor stroke about three years ago  fully recovering with no residual deficits.   Family History: There is a family history of cardiovascular disease: his father passed away at the age of 72 due to a heart attack and his younger sister  now 60 years old  has been diagnosed with heart failure.   Current Medications: The patient regularly takes Lisinopril 20mg/day for hypertension and Metformin 1000mg twice a day for diabetes. He also uses Aspirin 81mg/day as his secondary prophylaxis following his stroke.  Objective Assessment: On examination  his blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg  HR (Heart Rate) is noted to be irregular and fast with rates varying from 80 to 140 bpm  respiratory rate is 16/min and BMI is 28. EKG shows evidence of atrial fibrillation.  Coordinates of the Problem: The coordinates defining the problem include the symptoms of an irregular  often rapid heart rate causing palpitations  fatigue  and light-headedness. This clinical picture suggests atrial fibrillation. Major factors of concern are the patient's past medical history inclusive of hypertension  diabetes  stroke  and lifestyle factors - like the history of smoking  alcohol  and lack of physical activity. These increase the patient's risk for developing atrial fibrillation and associated complications like stroke and heart failure. The task is to determine the most effective treatment strategy to control his atrial fibrillation and manage risk factors.

John is a retired mechanical engineer  widowed  lives alone but his daughter checks on him often.  2. He has a 40-pack year history of smoking but quit 15 years ago. Limited alcohol use.   Symptoms: Noticed about 2 days ago  his symptoms include palpitations  fatigue and mild dyspnea on exertion. Denies chest pain or dizziness.   Vitals: His heart rate varies between 110-130 bpm and irregular  blood pressure 145/92 mmHg  respiratory rate 18/min  Spo2 96% on room air.   Clinical: On auscultation  no abnormal lung or heart sounds  except for an irregular rhythm. Rest of the examination is unremarkable.  Investigations: ECG confirms atrial fibrillation with a heart rate of 120bpm  Chest X-ray and complete blood count are normal  thyroid function tests are normal  troponin is within normal range.  This 68-year-old male with a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and previous stroke  presents with symptoms of atrial fibrillation for 2 days. He denies precipitating factors such as chest pain or acute illness. His ECG confirms the diagnosis.

Family History:  His father died from a sudden heart attack at 68  and his older brother has a history of atrial fibrillation and stroke. The presenting symptoms have a significant impact on the patient's quality of life. Proper management should be directed not only at rhythm control but also stroke prevention given his past transient ischemic attack.

Based on the patient's medical history  presenting complaints  clinical examinations and ECG results  he is diagnosed with Atrial Fibrillation (AF). The challenge now is to investigate the cause of AF  manage the symptoms  and reduce the risks associated with stroke and heart failure.   Patient education  lifestyle changes  rate control  rhythm control measures  anticoagulation therapy  as well as a closer follow up probably with a cardiologist  are the potential management options at this stage. Urgent referral to cardiology team would be the next step.   The care team should also provide ongoing support for his comorbidities like diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. A referral to smoking cessation services could also be beneficial.

Hyperlipidemia: The patient has high cholesterol levels  which are being managed with Simvastatin.  4. Prior Stroke: Patient suffered a stroke 2 years ago  from which he has recovered with minimal residual deficits.  5. Social History:  Smoking: The patient quit smoking about 10 years ago after a 30-years history of tobacco use.  Alcohol: The patient drinks socially  averaging about 1-2 drinks per week.  Exercise: The patient is mostly sedentary  citing shortness of breath and fatigue as reasons for lack of physical activity.  Diet: The patient reports a diet high in sodium and sugar.  Symptoms related to Atrial Fibrillation: Patient reports symptoms suggestive of atrial fibrillation  including palpitations  intermittent chest discomfort  fatigue  shortness of breath  and occasional lightheadedness.  On examination  irregular pulse and slightly elevated blood pressure were noted. The EKG has confirmed atrial fibrillation.  Diagnostic and therapeutic plan includes medication adjustment  further investigation to identify the triggering factors for the atrial fibrillation  potential use of anticoagulants considering the stroke history  and consideration of cardioversion or ablation procedures in the future if the symptoms cannot be controlled with medication. Lifestyle modifications would also be strongly recommended to the patient.  Summary: 75-year-old male with a history of hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and prior stroke  presenting with symptoms suggestive of atrial fibrillation. The patient's lifestyle  genetic factors  and pre-existing conditions potentially contribute to his current heart condition.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:   A 72-year-old Caucasian male non-smoker who resides in a suburban environment. He is a retired industrial worker  living with his spouse. His body mass index (BMI) is above average at 28. He does not consume alcohol  but leads a sedentary lifestyle with low physical activity. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease with both his father and paternal grandmother having passed from heart-related complications.   Medical History:   The patient has a 10-year history of hypertension  adequately controlled with lisinopril. He also has type 2 diabetes managed with metformin. One year ago he was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia and was prescribed atrovastatin.   Health Maintenance:   The patient is up-to-date with his preventive care screenings. He received his annual flu shot and has also been vaccinated against pneumococci and herpes zoster. His most recent lipid panel showed total cholesterol level at 145 mg/dL  LDL at 90 mg/dL and HDL at 40 mg/dL. His HbA1c level is 7.2  suggesting relatively good control of his diabetes.   Presenting Complaint:  He presents with new-onset fatigue  palpitations  and occasional shortness of breath on exertion. He denies chest pain  dizziness  or fainting.   Diagnosis:   Upon examination and confirmation from an electrocardiogram (EKG)  atrial fibrillation (AF) is being suspected. An echocardiogram will be performed next to assess structural heart disease and to further confirm the diagnosis. Based on his medical history and presenting symptoms  the patient's CHADS2-VASc score is 4  indicating a high risk of stroke and therefore warfarin therapy or a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) is considered as anticoagulation therapy after confirming there is no contra-indication for anticoagulation.   Plan:  The patient’s care plan would comprise managing and treating the new diagnosis of atrial fibrillation  with the assistance of a cardiologist. This would include determining the cause of the AF  managing the symptoms  preventing blood clots from forming and thus decreasing the risk of stroke  as well as managing any other related heart concerns or complications. Lifestyle changes would also be recommended. His diabetic  hypertensive  and hyperlipidemic treatment would also need adjustment as per circumstances.

Patient Identification: Mr. John Doe  a 68 year old Caucasian male.  Presenting Complaint: The patient complains of palpitations  fatigue  dizziness  shortness of breath  and a feeling of rapid  irregular heartbeat.  Demographic Information: The patient lives in an urban community  is a retired accountant  and lives with his spouse. He is a non-smoker and occasional consumer of alcohol.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a history of Hypertension  which has been under control with medication for 10 years now. He was diagnosed with Diabetes Mellitus type II  8 years ago  and it has been fairly controlled with Metformin. He underwent a gallbladder removal 6 years ago and had a Deep Vein Thrombosis episode post-surgery that was managed without any complications.   Family History: Father had Myocardial Infarction at age 60  who later passed away at 78 because of a stroke. Mother is a 90-year old who has been living with osteoporosis. The patient's older sister died of ovarian cancer at age 52.  Social History: The patient leads an active lifestyle  enjoying walks every morning and playing golf once a week. He has been trying to maintain a balanced diet since he was diagnosed with DM type II. However  he admits to experiencing some stress due to family issues.  Current Medications: The patient takes Metformin 500mg twice daily for Diabetes and Lisinopril 10mg once daily for Hypertension.  Review of Systems: He complains of irregular  rapid heartbeats  feeling tired and breathless more than usual. Denies any chest pain  nausea  or loss of consciousness. No reports of any tingling sensation in extremities or difficulty in speech.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  an irregular heartbeat was noted. The patient displayed no cyanosis  clubbing  or edema. Breath sounds were normal bilaterally and no hepatosplenomegaly was noted.   This is a typical patient presenting with symptoms of Atrial Fibrillation (AF). History of Hypertension  Diabetes  and a previous episode of DVT place him at a higher risk for developing AF. It must be determined whether this is a paroxysmal  persistent  or permanent form of AF and managed accordingly.

Blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg. Present Complaint: Mr. Doe presented with palpitations and mild shortness of breath ongoing for the past few days. He denies chest pain  lightheadedness  or syncope. He has been having intermittent episodes of rapid heartbeats off and onto the past few weeks.  Physical Examination: - BP: 140/85mmHg - HR: 110 bpm with irregular rhythm - Respiratory rate: 20 bpm - Oxygen saturation: 96% on room air - BMI: 28 Kg/m2  Laboratory Data: - ECG: Irregularly irregular heart rhythm with absence of P waves  suggestive of atrial fibrillation. - Blood tests: Elevations in fasting blood glucose and HbA1c consistent with diabetes  slightly elevated cholesterol levels. - Cardiac enzymes: Normal - TSH: Normal  Plan: The doctor plans a thorough assessment including an echocardiogram. Anticoagulation therapy will be considered after stroke risk assessment using the CHA2DS2-VASc Score. Rate or rhythm control therapy will also be considered in line with the patient's symptoms and comorbid conditions. The patient's current medications for hypertension and diabetes will be continued  with potential for adjustments based on assessment of the overall clinical situation. Patient education will be provided regarding lifestyle modifications including weight management and controlled alcohol consumption. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and response to therapy.

Patient Demographic and Medical History:  Patient ID: A101 Name: Smith  John  Age: 68 years old  Sex: Male  Race: Caucasian  Marital Status: Married  Occupation: Retired engineer  Health Insurance: Medicare   Presentation:  Mr. John Smith presented with complaints of irregular heartbeat and fatigue. Upon evaluation  he was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation.  Vital Signs: Blood Pressure: 145/90 mmHG  Heart Rate: 110 BPM  irregular  Respiratory Rate: 18 per minute  Temperature: 98.7 F  Body Mass Index: 28  Allergies  No known drug allergies   Current Medications: - Lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension  - Metformin 1000 mg twice daily for type 2 diabetes  - Atorvastatin 40 mg at bedtime for hyperlipidemia   Smoking/Alcohol/Drugs:  - Quit smoking 10 years ago  smoked 1 pack per day for 30 years  - Drinks socially  denies drug use  Relevant Past Medical History: - Hypertension  controlled with medication - Type 2 diabetes mellitus  diagnosed 6 years ago - Hyperlipidemia  controlled with medication - History of transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) 3 years ago  no residual neurologic deficits  Family History: - Father died of myocardial infarction at age 72  had hypertension and hyperlipidemia - Mother has type 2 diabetes and hypertension  alive at age 85 - One brother with early onset coronary artery disease  Current Issue: Patient experiences instances of atrial fibrillation and has sought medical attention. Problem Representation:  Patient Information:   A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents with a new onset of palpitations and intermittent light-headedness which has been ongoing for the past two weeks. The patient is a retired teacher  married with 3 children  and is a moderate alcohol consumer but non-smoker. He has a BMI of 26 and lives in an urban area. He is generally active but has noted decreased exercise tolerance recently. There is no family history of sudden cardiac death.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension which was diagnosed ten years ago and is well controlled under medication (Ramipril  5mg daily). The patient also was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes five years ago  which has been managed with diet  exercise  and metformin. He has a history of two episodes of transient ischemic attack (TIA) with complete resolution of symptoms  most recently one year ago. The patient was diagnosed with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) but has no history of cancer  thyroid disease  or rheumatic heart disease.   The patient’s medications include ramipril (5mg  daily)  metformin (1000mg  twice daily)  aspirin (75mg  daily)  and tamsulosin for his BPH. He has no known drug allergies.   Problem List:  1. New onset of atrial fibrillation: The patient has been experiencing symptomatic palpitations indicating regular cardiac rhythm disturbance for the last two weeks.      2. Hypertension: The patient has been managing hypertension for the past decade with medication.  3. Type 2 diabetes mellitus: The patient was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes five years ago  which is managed with lifestyle changes and metformin.  4. Transient ischemic attack: The patient has a history of two previous TIAs  most recently about a year ago.  5. Benign prostatic hyperplasia: The patient was diagnosed with BPH but is not on any medication for it at present.        This problem representation provides a concise summary of the patient's condition and history which will support further diagnostic investigations and management decisions for the presented atrial fibrillation.

Problem Representation:  Demographics: 1. Patient Name: John Doe  2. Age: 67 years old  3. Gender: Male  4. Occupation: Retired Engineer 5. Lifestyle: Non-smoker  moderate alcohol consumption  6. Race: Caucasian 7. Marital Status: Married 8. Residence: Community dwelling   Presenting Issue: - The patient has been experiencing episodes of palpitations  shortness of breath  and mild fatigue over the past few weeks.  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension: Diagnosed 11 years ago; under control with medication (Lisinopril  20mg daily). 2. Dyslipidemia: Diagnosed 8 years ago; under control with medication (Atorvastatin  40mg daily). 3. Type 2 Diabetes: Diagnosed 6 years ago; under control with medication (Metformin  500mg twice daily). 4. Mild Heart Failure: Diagnosed 2 years ago; prescribed Carvedilol (6.25mg twice daily).  Family History: - Father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 72. - Mother has history of hypertension and stroke.    Medications: 1. Lisinopril 20mg daily 2. Atorvastatin 40mg daily 3. Metformin 500mg twice daily 4. Carvedilol 6.25mg twice daily  Review of Systems: - General: Moderate fatigue - Cardiovascular: Palpitations  intermittent chest tightness  no orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. - Respiratory: Mild shortness of breath on exertion  no wheezing or cough.    Objective Data: - Physical Exam: Slightly irregular radial and carotid pulse  no jugular venous distension  lungs clear to auscultation  normal heart sounds. - EKG shows atrial fibrillation with controlled ventricular rate. - Echo shows mildly impaired left ventricular systolic function. - Blood tests: mild elevation of NT-proBNP  normal electrolytes  normal thyroid function test  HbA1c 7.2%.    Atrial fibrillation is the preliminary diagnosis based on the patient’s symptoms  physical exam  and EKG findings. Further management will depend on subsequent test results  risk stratification  and patient's preferences.

Patient Information:  - Age: 70 years - Sex: Male - Occupation: Retired teacher - Marital status: Married - Sex: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Residence: Urban - Smoking Status: Ex-smoker for 15 years  previously smoked 1 pack a day for 30 years - Alcohol intake: Moderate (2-3 times per week  1-2 units per time) - Exercise level: Sedentary lifestyle (occasional walking)  Presenting Problem: Chief complaint of irregular and sometimes rapid heart rate with occasional heart palpitations  fatigue  and shortness of breath.  Medical History:  - Hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago - Type II diabetes mellitus diagnosed 8 years ago - Previous myocardial infarction (Heart attack) 5 years ago - Mild obesity (BMI: 30) - Underwent coronary artery bypass graft surgery following heart attack - Family history of heart disease - his father had atrial fibrillation and his mother had congestive heart failure.  Prescription History:  - Metformin for diabetes - Lisinopril for hypertension - Aspirin and Clopidogrel (following heart attack)  Physical Examination:  - Blood pressure: 140/90 mm of Hg - Heart rate: irregular  110 beats per minute - Breath sounds: Clear to auscultation bilaterally  - No pitting edema present  - Body mass index: 30 kg/m²  Investigations:  - ECG: Atrial fibrillation with a variable ventricular response - Blood glucose level: Elevated - Lipid profile: Abnormal - Hemoglobin A1c: Elevated - BNP: Normal  Based on the information  this problem representation can be summed as follows:  A 70-year-old male ex-smoker with a history of hypertension  type II diabetes  and a previous MI presented with symptoms consistent with atrial fibrillation. His sedentary lifestyle and family history of heart disease have contributed to his cardiac issues. Despite being on medications for his past medical conditions  his blood pressure and blood glucose levels are noted to be high. Irregular heart rate on physical examination and ECG result confirms atrial fibrillation. Lifestyle modifications  a change or addition to current medications  and further treatment options for atrial fibrillation need to be considered.

Case Report: Atrial Fibrillation   Patient Information   The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male of Italian descent named Mr. Anthony Russo. Mr. Russo is a retired engineer  a widower with three children and seven grandchildren living in Brooklyn  New York. He is 5’9''  weighs 210 pounds  and is a non-smoker. His alcohol consumption is occasional  he admits to having a glass of wine with dinner a few times a week  and his nutritional habits are generally good.   Medical History  Mr. Russo’s past medical history is significant for treated hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He has been on Lisinopril 20mg daily and Atorvastatin 40 mg nightly for the past 15 years. He had a coronary angiography five years ago due to chest pain which showed no significant coronary artery disease. Mr. Russo underwent a total hip replacement surgery two years ago and recovered without complications. Additionally  he was diagnosed with bilateral cataracts  for which he had successful surgeries.  His family history reveals longevity with both parents living into their late 80s. His father had hypertension and his mother had type II diabetes mellitus. His elder sister died of breast cancer and his brother is in good health.  Present Illness  Mr. Russo presented at the clinic due to an episode of palpitations and mild shortness of breath experienced while gardening. He complained about a slight fast-beating or fluttering sensation in his chest for about 30 seconds but denied having chest pain or dizziness. He admits to observing such episodes more frequently  which he dismissed as 'just getting older'. The patient’s vital signs were within normal limits except for an irregular heart rate at 88 bpm.  Diagnosis  Further investigation was carried out through electrocardiography which confirmed a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation. His resting ECG showed irregular rhythm  absence of P waves with unorganized electrical activity in their place and a narrow QRS complex. Routine blood tests including full blood count  urea  and electrolytes  thyroid function tests  and a clotting screen were all normal.  Treatment Plan  The physician initiated a conservative approach for managing Mr. Russo's atrial fibrillation. The treatment regime included beta-blockers (Bisoprolol)  anticoagulation therapy (Rivaroxaban) to reduce the risk of stroke  and lifestyle modification education. The purpose of these therapeutic measures were laid out to the patient and he expressed agreement and readiness to adhere to the instructions.   This case report emphasizes the significance of considering atrial fibrillation in patients with cardiovascular risk factors presenting with nonspecific symptoms. Early diagnosis and management can avoid serious complications such as stroke and heart failure. Mr. Russo was scheduled for a follow-up after 4 weeks to review his symptoms and assess his response to therapy.

Patient Information: Mr. Williams  a 77-year-old Caucasian male  and a retired engineer. He presented with complaints of irregular heart rhythm  tiredness  and shortness of breath that began three weeks prior.  Clinical History: Mr. Williams has a past medical history notable for hypertension  high cholesterol  and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has been taking lisinopril 10mg once a day for hypertension  metformin 1000 mg twice a day for diabetes  and atorvastatin 20mg once a day for high cholesterol. He has no known drug allergies. Mr. Williams quit smoking 15 years ago. He denies any history of alcohol or drug abuse. There is a family history of cardiovascular diseases. His father passed away due to myocardial infarction at the age of 67  and his older brother had a stroke at the age of 75.  Presenting Complaints: During the consultation  Mr. Williams reported palpitations  dyspnea on exertion  and a diminished exercise tolerance. Moreover  he also mentioned experiencing episodes of light-headedness but denied any overt syncope.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  he appeared fatigued. His blood pressure reading was slightly elevated at 150/85 mmHg  and his resting heart rate was irregular at 100-125 beats per minute. Cardiovascular examination was suggestive of an irregular rhythm without murmurs. Lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally and there was no peripheral edema.  Investigations and Diagnosis: An electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed  diagnostic of atrial fibrillation (AF) with a rapid ventricular response. His blood tests including a full blood count and thyroid function tests were all within normal levels  apart from slightly elevated glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) and cholesterol levels. The remaining results of a comprehensive metabolic panel were within normal limits. An echocardiogram demonstrated mild concentric left ventricular hypertrophy  preserved ejection fraction with no evidence of valvular heart disease.  Treatment: Mr. Wiliams was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation likely secondary to his hypertension and diabetes. In addition to lifestyle advice and optimization of his existing medications  he was successfully cardioverted and was prescribed anticoagulation therapy (Apixaban) to prevent thromboembolic events. His medication regimen was also updated to include a beta-blocker (Metoprolol) to maintain heart rhythm and rate control.  Follow-Up: Mr. Williams was advised to attend regular outpatient follow-ups  with frequent monitoring of his blood pressure  heart rate  renal profile  and HbA1c levels. Further  he was instructed on AF symptom recognition and advised to report if he experiences any recurrence of his symptoms.  Considering Mr. Williams’s risk factors including age  hypertension  and diabetes  he remains at a high risk of stroke and will benefit from long-term anticoagulation and rhythm control strategy to manage his newly diagnosed atrial fibrillation. His case emphasizes the importance of considering AF in older patients presenting with unspecific symptoms like fatigue and shortness of breath.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  The patient is a 68-year-old African-American female.   Presenting Complaint / History of present illness:  The patient consulted due to complaints of palpitations and occasional shortness of breath for the past four weeks.  Past medical history:  The patient has been hypertensive for the past ten years  treated with 10mg Amlodipine once daily. She has type II diabetes mellitus diagnosed eight years ago and is on 500mg of Metformin twice a day. She also has a history of hypercholesterolemia which has been managed with Atorvastatin 20mg daily. She does not have known allergies to any medication. The patient quit smoking twenty years ago and only consumes alcohol occasionally. There is no previous history of cardiac disease or stroke.  Examination: The patient appears comfortable and alert; vital signs are as follows: BP- 145/90 mmHg  HR-113 bpm irregularly irregular  RR-18 breaths per minute  SpO2-97% on room air  and temperature 98.2 F. Cardiovascular exam reveals irregularly irregular heart sounds  but no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. There are no signs of congestive heart failure. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment:  The EKG showed atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. Laboratory tests revealed normal electrolytes  kidney  and liver function. HbA1C was 7.3%. Lipid panel was within the therapeutic goal. Thyroid function testing was normal.   Management:  The patient was admitted to the cardiac unit for further management. After consultation with cardiology  rate control was opted with metoprolol. For anticoagulation  Apixaban was initiated in order to prevent stroke. The patient responded well to treatment with a decrease in the ventricular rate and symptomatic relief. She was educated about the nature of the disease  need for regular monitoring  medication compliance  and modification of risk factors.  Follow Up:  The patient was asked to schedule follow-up visits with her primary care physician and cardiologist in one week  with scheduled INR checks as she continues her medication regimen. On discharge  her heart rate was controlled and her symptoms have alleviated significantly.  Informed Consent:  In accordance with patient confidentiality  the patient gave informed consent to use her medical record for this case report.   Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the importance of addressing common modifiable risk factors such as hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus in the management of atrial fibrillation. Furthermore  it presents a relatively straightforward case of atrial fibrillation management with rate control strategy and anticoagulation.

Case Report on Atrial Fibrillation   Patient Information: Mr. A  an 85-year-old Caucasian male of approximately 5'10"" and 185 lbs.  Presenting Problems: The patient presented symptoms such as palpitations  shortness of breath  weakness with mild exertion  fatigue  and occasional dizziness  which aggravated over a span of three weeks. A notable irregular heart rhythm was observed during a physical examination  leading to the suspicion of atrial fibrillation (AF).  Past Medical History: Mr. A’s medical history includes hypertension  which was diagnosed ten years ago  and type II diabetes  diagnosed eight years ago. Both conditions are currently managed with medication (metoprolol  50mg daily and metformin  1000mg twice daily). He was a long-term heavy smoker for 60 years  with a 30-pack year history  but quit smoking seven years ago. The patient denies any history of heart disease in his family.   Current & Ongoing Treatments: He continues his prescribed medications for hypertension and diabetes. Minimal side effects were reported with his current treatment regimen.  Investigations: An electrocardiogram (ECG) was conducted which suggested AF with a rapid ventricular response. The echocardiogram showed left atrial enlargement and preserved left ventricular ejection fraction. His fasting blood glucose was 153 mg/dL  and HBA1c was 7.1%. His blood pressure during initial examination was 158/95 mmHg. Two-dimensional Doppler echocardiography revealed a left atrial diameter of 48 mm and impaired left ventricular diastolic function.  Diagnosis: After evaluating the symptoms  medical history  and results of investigations  Mr. A was diagnosed with non-valvular atrial fibrillation.  Treatment Plan: Mr. A was assessed to have a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 4; thus  it was suggested that he starts anticoagulant therapy to reduce the risk of stroke besides continuing his ongoing medication. Metoprolol dose was adjusted to control the heart rate.  Follow-up: Mr. A was advised to visit for regular monthly follow-ups for monitoring vitals  such as heart rate and BP. He was also educated about a healthy diet  regular exercise  and the necessity for medication adherence.   In conclusion  the case of Mr. A illustrates the often-delayed diagnosis of atrial fibrillation due to its potentially subtle presentation. The importance of comprehensive risk assessment  primary preventive measures for the prevention of AF  and individualized treatment approach with multidisciplinary care is emphasized.

Patient Information:  Mr. John Doe  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the Emergency Department complaining of palpitations  shortness of breath  and light-headedness which started approximately 24 hours earlier. The patient is a retired school teacher and lives with his wife.   Past Medical History:  He has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes over the last 12 years and has hypertension for 10 years. He is on Metformin 1000mg twice a day and Lisinopril 10mg daily. His last HbA1c was 7.2%. He also reported having a history of cigarette smoking for 30 years but quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol casually. No known drug allergies.   Current Clinical Presentation:  On clinical examination  he was afebrile with a blood pressure of 142/88mmHg  pulse rate 128 and irregular  respirations 22 and saturating 96% on room air. Cardiac examination showed an irregular heart rate. There were no murmurs. Other systemic examinations were unremarkable.   Investigations:  His ECG confirmed atrial fibrillation (AF) with a rapid ventricular response. Blood tests showed normal electrolyte levels  and the Troponin I test was negative. The chest X-ray was normal. An echocardiography showed no valve disease or clot  but there was a mild left ventricular hypertrophy with preserved ejection fraction.   Treatment Plan:  The patient was given Metoprolol to control his heart rate. After discussing the risks and benefits  he agreed for the initiation of anticoagulation therapy and was started on Apixaban  considering his CHA2DS2-VASc score. He was scheduled for a cardiology outpatient follow-up for further management.  Discussion:  AF is one of the very commonly encountered cardiac rhythm problems  especially in the elderly population. Modifiable risk factors like hypertension  diabetes  obesity  and alcohol consumption play quite an essential role in the causation of AF. This case is an example of a typical presentation of AF. Early detection and management should focus on the control of ventricular rate  anticoagulation to prevent future stroke  and risk factor modification.  Conclusion:  In this context  Mr. Doe's current diagnosis of AF may potentially be due to underlying risk factors of hypertension and diabetes. This case reiterates the typical presentation of AF and highlights the significance of comprehensive management that includes control of heart rate  risk of stroke  and modification of lifestyle and risk factors. Follow-up is essential to monitor the patient's response to therapy and symptom alleviation.

Case Report: A Male Patient with Atrial Fibrillation  Patient Information:  Mr. Irving  a Caucasian 68-year-old retired civil engineer  presented to the emergency department (ED) complaining of palpitations. His wife explained that he had experienced several similar episodes these past few weeks  each lasting a couple of hours and resolved spontaneously.   History of the Current Illness:  Mr. Irving reported having irregular fast heartbeats that came and went  accompanied by shortness of breath  fatigue  lightheadedness  and occasionally slight chest discomfort. He denied syncope  fever  cough  or recent weight loss. His symptoms were more pronounced when he is physically active.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Irving has been diagnosed with hypertension for the past 12 years  it is controlled with a daily dose of 10mg Ramipril. He is not a smoker but admitted to having 1-2 units of alcohol daily. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) 7 years ago  controlled with Metformin 500mg twice daily. Approximately three years ago  he was treated for gastric ulcers. No other significant medical or surgical history was presented. There is no known cardiac disease history in his family.  Examination:  Mr. Irving appeared mildly distressed due to his symptoms. His blood pressure was 139/89 mm Hg  heart rate (HR) was 122 bpm and irregular  respiratory rate (RR) was 18 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation (SpO2) of 98% on room air. On cardiovascular exam  his precordium was active and irregular. There were no noted murmurs.  Investigations:   Initial electrocardiogram (ECG) showed atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. Blood investigations showed a slightly elevated level of BNP and mild renal insufficiency. Echocardiogram depicted left atrial enlargement and slightly reduced left ventricular systolic function  with an ejection fraction of approximately 50%.   Diagnosis:  Based on clinical findings  the ECG result  and affirmed by the echocardiogram  Mr. Irving was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation.  Treatment and Follow-up:  Mr. Irving was admitted to the cardiology ward where rate control was achieved with oral Metoprolol. Anticoagulation was initiated with NOAC (novel oral anticoagulant)  due to his elevated stroke risk per CHA2DS2-VASc score. For rhythm control  Cardioversion was considered  but it was decided to observe his rhythm response to medical therapy initially.   Education on lifestyle modifications and diabetes control were reinforced to Mr. Irving and his family. A follow-up after 2 weeks was scheduled to assess his condition and adjust his treatment regimen as necessary.  This case of Mr. Irving provides insight into an aged male  with a background of hypertension and diabetes  presenting with new-onset atrial fibrillation. It underlines the importance of early recognition and treatment of this common heart rhythm disorder.

Title: Management of Long-Standing Persistent Atrial Fibrillation in an Elderly Patient.  Patient Description:  Patient X  a 75-year-old Asian female  visited the outpatient clinic for a routine check-up. She is a retired high-school teacher  lives with her husband  and is a non-smoker. The patient was diagnosed with hypertension and type-2 diabetes mellitus about ten years ago. These conditions have been well managed with prescribed medications (Losartan for hypertension and Metformin for diabetes). Her family history includes heart failure in her father and stroke in her sister.   Presenting Problem:  During her visit  a routine electrocardiogram (ECG) assessment revealed abnormal findings  which indicated atrial fibrillation (Afib). The clinical examination confirmed irregular heart rhythm and the patient reported occasional shortness of breath and episodes of palpitation  especially at night in the past few months. Based on these findings  she was diagnosed with long-standing persistent atrial fibrillation.  Investigations:  Laboratory investigations were conducted to ascertain her current state of health and the impact of her condition on her organs. The patient had normal thyroid function tests and her kidney function tests were also within normal limits. Her HbA1c was 6.5%  which suggested that her diabetes was well controlled. An echocardiogram showed a slightly enlarged left atrium and normal left ventricular function with an ejection fraction of 60%.   Overview and Outcome:  The interprofessional healthcare team  composed of a cardiologist  a primary care physician  and a pharmacist  reviewed the patient's case. Owing to her age and presence of hypertension and diabetes  the patient was deemed at high risk of stroke. Anticoagulation as a measure of stroke prophylaxis was discussed.   After a thorough benefit-risk evaluation considering her risk factors and possible side effects  oral anticoagulant (Rivaroxaban) therapy was started to treat her atrial fibrillation and to reduce her stroke risk. A rhythm control strategy using flecainide was also initiated.  At the 3 months follow-up  her symptoms had significantly improved  ECG showed sinus rhythm  and she reported taking the medications regularly with no side effects. This case highlights the importance of routine check-ups  early detection  and proper management of persistent atrial fibrillation  especially in high-risk individuals  which can significantly improve their quality of life.  Further scheduled follow-ups included in the management plan to monitor patient X’s condition and assure the effectiveness and safety of her medications.

Patient Profile: Name: (confidential for privacy reasons) Age: 68 Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Presenting condition: Atrial Fibrillation  Case Report:   Mr. X  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with complaints of heart palpitations  shortness of breath and mild chest discomfort. He reported that these symptoms had been irregular but present for the past week  and were more noticeable during exertion. Mr. X has a medical history of hypertension and diabetes  both of which are managed by medication. He has no known allergies and doesn't smoke or drink alcohol.  On examination  his blood pressure was 155/90  pulse was irregularly irregular at 108 bpm  respiratory rate was 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation was 95% on room air. On cardiac auscultation  an irregularly irregular rhythm was heard. No murmurs  rubs  or gallops were appreciated. All other physical examination findings were normal.  An ECG was conducted which confirmed a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation (AF). Bloodwork  including full blood count  kidney function tests  liver function tests and thyroid function tests were carried out. Blood sugars were controlled  indicating good diabetes management. The other blood tests were within normal ranges. A chest X-ray was conducted to exclude other respiratory causes of dyspnea  which appeared normal.  The patient was admitted for treatment and observation. He was started on anticoagulation therapy to prevent thromboembolic events. Rate control versus rhythm control strategy was extensively discussed with the patient. He was initiated on metoprolol for rate control after considering his age  clinical profile  comorbidities  and symptoms. We also prescribed flecainide to maintain sinus rhythm. The patient was advised to avoid vigorous physical exertion and to follow a low salt and diabetic diet.  During the hospital stay  the patient was monitored closely and his atrial fibrillation was brought under control. His symptoms resolved and he reported feeling much better. He was discharged with a detailed explanation of his condition  prescribed medications  potential side effects  and signs of complications that should prompt immediate medical attention like chest pain  severe breathlessness or fainting. Regular outpatient follow-ups and ECGs were scheduled.  Patient education was also provided on lifestyle changes to manage AF  such as staying adequately hydrated  maintaining a healthy weight  regular physical activity as tolerated  and optimal control of diabetes and blood pressure. Patient compliance and understanding of the chronic nature of the disease were ensured before discharge.  In conclusion  this is a case of an elderly patient with existing hypertension and diabetes who developed atrial fibrillation  which was managed successfully with rate control strategy and anticoagulation therapy. He is maintaining regular follow-ups and is in good health currently.  [Please note that the initials used  Mr. X  are fictitious in order to maintain patient confidentiality.]

Title: Management of Atrial Fibrillation in a 73-Year-Old Female with a History of Hypertension  Introduction: Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a common cardiac arrhythmia occurring more frequently in the elderly.  Case Presentation: The patient is a 73-year-old Caucasian female who presented in the emergency department complaining of sudden palpitations  fatigue  and mild shortness of breath that began the previous night. She describes these palpitations as irregular and rapid and noted their onset was unprovoked. She denies any chest pain  dyspnea  presyncope  or syncope episodes. She has a known history of hypertension controlled with Amlodipine 5mg/day medication for the last 7 years. She does not smoke or consume alcohol and has no history of illicit drug use. There were no known drug allergies.  Examination: Physical examination was generally unremarkable except for an irregularly irregular heart rate of 110 beats per minute  a blood pressure of 130/85 millimeters of mercury (mmHg)  and mild tachypnea. Electrocardiogram (EKG) confirmed AF with an irregular rhythm  absent P waves  and a variable ventricular response. Chest X-ray ruled out possible pneumonia or any other acute pulmonary disorders. Lab investigations including complete blood count  electrolyte levels  renal function  and thyroid function were within normal limits. An echocardiogram showed no structural abnormalities and preserved ejection fraction.  Management: The patient  having a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 3 (age >75 years  female sex  hypertension history)  is at moderate-to-high risk for stroke. Given her newly diagnosed AF  anticoagulation therapy was initiated after ruling out any contraindications for bleeding risk  in her case using Warfarin. She was also started on rate control therapy using Metoprolol. We refrained from performing cardioversion at this time due to lack of knowledge about the onset of her AF.  Outcome and Follow-Up: There was noticeable improvement in palpitations and the heart rate trended down to the 80s. She was followed up by a cardiologist in the outpatient department after discharge. Education regarding the importance of medication compliance  lifestyle changes  and regular follow-ups was emphasized before discharge. She was extremely cooperative and glad that her symptoms were noticeably improving.  Discussion: The case brings to light the importance of timely intervention  appropriate assessment of stroke risk  and initiation of rate control and anticoagulation in the management of AF  particularly in at-risk populations like elderly patients with other comorbidities.  Conclusion: Atrial fibrillation is a common presentation particularly in the elderly and patients with hypertension. Early detection  risk assessment  and appropriate anticoagulation are paramount in AF management.

Patient Details: Ms. Jane Doe  a 72-year-old African American female  presented to our clinic complaining of palpitations and occasional feelings of dizziness over the past several months. She is not diabetic  but has a history of hypertension  and received treatment for breast cancer in her mid-50s. She has been smoking 15 cigarettes per day for the past 45 years. The patient's family history suggests that her mother had suffered from rheumatic heart disease and her grandfather developed a stroke at age 82.  Social History: The patient lives with her younger sister and does not drink alcohol. She is a retired high school teacher and reported no regular physical activity. She confirmed adherence to a diet that is quite rich in fast food and low in fruits and vegetables.  Physical Examination: Ms. Doe appeared comfortable  with a blood pressure reading of 150/90  a weight of 90 kg  and a height of 1.65 meters. Heart sounds revealed irregular rhythms  and no jugular vein distension was found. Lower extremity examination showed no edema. The remainder of her physical examination was otherwise unremarkable.  Investigation: ECG results showed an irregularly irregular rhythm  absent P waves  and a ventricular rate of 100 bpm which is consistent with atrial fibrillation. Her chest x-ray did not show any cardiovascular or pulmonary abnormality. A complete blood count  lipid profile  liver  and thyroid function tests were within normal range. An echocardiogram confirmed a mild dilation of the left atrium.  Management: The CHA2DS2-VASc score of 3 led to treatment initiation with oral anticoagulants (warfarin) for stroke prevention. The patient was prescribed a rate control strategy with beta-blockers to manage her symptoms and decrease hypertension. She was also given advice about smoking cessation  increasing physical activity  and improving her diet. An appointment for a follow-up evaluation was scheduled in three weeks.  Discussion: The case of Ms. Doe represents a common presentation of atrial fibrillation. Her history of hypertension and her prolonged smoking habit would have placed her at a higher risk of developing this condition. It is crucial to implement anticoagulation  rate control  and risk factor modification in patients with atrial fibrillation to prevent subsequent strokes and maintain their well-being.           This case also highlights the importance of obtaining a detailed past medical history from the patient  accurately examining physical signs  and conducting necessary investigations to diagnose the condition accurately. The recommended medication regimen as per guidelines and lifestyle modification counseling have been provided to Ms. Doe for better management of her condition. Regular follow-ups will ensure medicine tolerance and monitor symptom developments.

Patient Information:   Mr. Reid  a 67-year-old Caucasian male farmer  presented to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and shortness of breath occurring intermittently for the past week. He also mentioned moderate fatigue and mild discomfort in the chest during the episodes.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension managed with Lisinopril for the past five years. He has no history of diabetes  stroke  or coronary heart disease. He was a smoker for 30 years  having quit 10 years ago. He consumes alcohol in moderation and reports a sedentary lifestyle for the past two years due to retirement. There is a family history of heart diseases  with his father having suffered from a heart attack at the age of 72.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  he appeared anxious with audible irregular heartbeats. His blood pressure was 150/92 mm Hg  heart rate was inconsistent  ranging between 80 to 120 bpm  respiratory rate was 18 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation was 95% on room air.   Diagnostic Assessment:  The electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed a pattern with irregular rhythm and absent P waves  consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF). He underwent a transthoracic echocardiogram which suggested a slightly enlarged left atrium. Blood tests indicated slightly elevated NT-pro-BNP levels. No signs of acute myocardial infarction were observed in the ECG or blood tests.   Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was admitted for rate control  anticoagulation  and potential cardioversion. Intravenous administration of beta-blocker Metoprolol was initiated to control the ventricular rate. A direct oral anticoagulant  Apixaban  was started for stroke prophylaxis considering his CHA2DS2-VASc score of 2.  Follow-Up and Outcome:   After 48 hours of rate control therapy and symptom improvement  the patient underwent transesophageal echocardiography followed by electrical cardioversion. The procedure was successful and sinus rhythm was restored. The patient was discharged after 4 days from the hospital with Metoprolol and Apixaban  with advice on regular follow-ups  lifestyle modifications including regular physical activity  and a low salt diet to control his blood pressure.   Patient Perspective:  Mr. Reid expressed relief after restoration of sinus rhythm and improved symptoms. He was nervous about the possible recurrence of atrial fibrillation but appeared motivated to stick to lifestyle modifications and prescribed treatments.   Informed Consent:  Written informed consent for anonymous patient information to be published in this article has been provided by Mr. Reid.   Peer Review:  This case has been peer-reviewed by a cardiologist and confirmed to be accurately described and treated appropriately.

Title: A Case Report: Management of Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation in a 68-Year-Old Male  Patient Information: Mr. X is a 68-year old Caucasian male who resides in the urban outskirts of Texas  USA. He is a retired mechanic and has an active lifestyle with controlled smoking habits.  Clinical manifestation:  Mr. X presented to the emergency department complaining of palpitations  lightheadedness  and fatigue which started several hours ago. Vitals revealed tachycardia at 120 beats/minute and blood pressure was 145/88 mm Hg. An ECG indicated irregularly irregular rhythms  absence of P waves  and varying QRS complexes concluding atrial fibrillation (AF).  Background Medical History:   The patient has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed with losartan 50 mg and atorvastatin 20 mg daily respectively. He also has a history of smoking around 10 cigarettes a day for the past 45 years  but he cut back to 5 cigarettes/day for the last two years. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases; his father passed away at the age of 73 due to myocardial infarction.  Clinical Findings:   Mr. X was diagnosed with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation  identified through an ECG. His cardiologist confirmed the diagnosis with a transthoracic echocardiogram showing left atrial enlargement. Serum tests showed an increased level of N-terminal pro B type Natriuretic Peptide (NT-proBNP) at 1456 pg/mL.  Therapeutic Intervention:   Initially  a rate control strategy was followed utilizing metoprolol. Subsequently  the decision to proceed with a rhythm control strategy was made owing to the patient's diminished quality of life. He underwent successful electrical cardioversion and was started on oral anticoagulation (apixaban) for stroke prevention. The patient was also placed on dofetilide  a class III antiarrhythmic drug  twice a day.  Follow-up and outcomes:  Mr. X has maintained a sinus rhythm for around 6 months post the electrical cardioversion. He reports an improved quality of life and has adhered to recommendations  including medication  moderate exercise  diet control  and reduction in smoking. Warfarin therapy is well monitored and within therapeutic range. The patient has been scheduled for regular follow-ups.  Patient Perspective: The patient was glad about the amelioration of his symptoms and was determined to follow all the lifestyle modifications and medication instructions provided by his physicians.  Informed Consent:  Mr. X provided informed consent for this case report.  It makes an interesting case report as it provides evidence on the management of atrial fibrillation related to the common risk factors  hypertension  and smoking  in an elderly patient. The complexity of this case can shed light on the decision-making process regarding the choice between rate control and rhythm control strategies and the importance of patient lifestyle habits on disease management.

**Title:** New-Onset Atrial Fibrillation in a Nearly Asymptomatic Elderly Female Patient  **Abstract:** This case report discusses an instance of new-onset atrial fibrillation discovered incidentally in a nearly asymptomatic 78-year old female patient. The report includes the patient's demographic information  past medical history  current medical condition  clinical manifestations  diagnostic procedures  and management strategies.  **Patient Information:** The patient is a 78-year-old Caucasian woman with a previous medical history of hypertension managed with losartan and no known history of cardiovascular disease. The patient is not a smoker but reported regular alcohol consumption of approximately one standard drink a day. She lives in an assisted living facility and has not previously reported any difficulty performing activities of daily living. Her familial history reveals one sibling diagnosed with coronary artery disease at age 84.  **Clinical Findings:** During a routine visit  the patient complained of brief episodes of lightheadedness and fatigue for one week. She denied chest pain  shortness of breath  palpitations  syncope  or any other symptoms. On physical examination  her pulse was irregular but there was no detectable murmur. Her blood pressure was controlled  and the rest of her physical exam was unremarkable.  **Diagnostic Assessment:** An electrocardiogram (EKG) was performed  showing irregular rhythm with no distinct P waves  consistent with atrial fibrillation (AFib). Labs  including complete blood count  complete metabolic panel  and thyroid stimulating hormone  were within normal limits. An echocardiogram was also performed  which showed normal left ventricular function with no significant valvular disease.  **Therapeutic Intervention:** This patient was started on a beta-blocker  metoprolol  to control her ventricular rate. She was also initiated on oral anticoagulation with Eliquis  given her age and diagnosis of non-valvular atrial fibrillation  to mitigate stroke risk. We discussed the risks and benefits of rhythm control strategy  but given her asymptomatic nature  she chose a rate control strategy.  **Follow-up:** She has been scheduled for a routine visit in three months to reassess her symptoms and the effectiveness of the treatment regimen. She has also been advised to immediately report any worsening or new symptoms to her care team.  **Conclusion:** This case highlights the importance of a rigorous clinical examination in elderly patients who may present with subtle symptoms potentially indicating significant underlying pathology. Even though our patient had minimal symptoms  she was at risk for serious adverse events such as stroke due to her atrial fibrillation  underscoring the need for adequate rate control and stroke prevention with anticoagulation.

Title: Management of Atrial Fibrillation in a Geriatric Patient with Previous Stroke History  Case Report:   A 78-year-old African American female with a past medical history significant for hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2  and ischemic stroke three years prior came to the outpatient department complaining of new-onset palpitations  mild shortness of breath  and fatigue over the previous week. She denied chest pain  syncope  or presyncope. She reported compliance with her regular medications  which included Losartan  Metformin  Aspirin  and Atorvastatin.  On examination  her blood pressure was 140/80 mmHg and irregularly irregular heart rhythm was noted. An electrocardiogram (EKG) revealed atrial fibrillation (AF) with a ventricular rate of around 95 beats per minute. No other acute ST or T wave changes were noted. Her blood glucose level and other basic laboratory parameters were within normal limits. A subsequent echocardiogram demonstrated preserved left ventricular ejection and no significant valvular abnormalities.  The diagnosis of non-valvular atrial fibrillation (NVAF) was made. Given her age  hypertension  diabetes  and previous stroke history  she fell into a high risk stratification category (CHA2DS2-Vasc score of 5)  suggesting the need for anticoagulation therapy for stroke prevention. After discussion with the patient about the benefits and risks  apixaban was commenced.  Further management included rate control and rhythm management. Metoprolol was initiated for rate control and subsequently titrated to maintain a heart rate less than 100 beats per minute. The issue of rhythm control was discussed extensively with the patient  considering her persistent symptoms and the possible risk/benefits of antiarrhythmic drugs or cardioversion.  In view of her moderately symptomatic AF and consistent with the 2014 AHA/ACC/HRS Guideline for the Management of Patients with Atrial Fibrillation  she was started on Sotalol for rhythm control with a plan to reassess her symptoms and potentially consider direct current cardioversion (DCCV) if there was no improvement.  The patient was followed up on an outpatient basis and showed considerable progress. Her symptoms were greatly diminished  and a follow-up EKG confirmed sinus rhythm. She maintained good adherence to her medication regimen and did not encounter any side effects. Regular follow-up and monitoring were planned to ensure ongoing management efficacy.  Conclusion: This case highlights the need for individualized therapy in accordance with risk stratification and patient symptoms in the management of NVAF. Regular follow-ups are essential to assess patients' symptoms  drug safety  and efficacy of the therapeutic approach.

Patient Information  Name: Patient X (Identity is kept confidential) Age: 69 Sex: Male  Occupation: Retired Engineer Ethnicity: Caucasian Marital Status: Married  Presenting Problem  The patient presented himself to the outpatient department (OPD) complaining of constant palpitations and occasional dizziness for more than two weeks.  Medical History  The patient has a chronic history of hypertension for over 10 years and was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus five years ago. Both conditions are managed adequately with prescribed medications: Amlodipine 10mg once daily for hypertension  and Metformin 500mg twice daily for diabetes. There is also a previous history of an episode of transient ischemic attack (TIA) ~2 years ago; no recurrent episodes were reported after that.   Family history: Patient's father died due to a Myocardial Infarction and his elder brother has been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation.   Clinical Findings  Upon examination  the patient's heart rhythm was irregularly irregular  and pulse rate varied between 80-100 bpm. Blood pressure was slightly elevated at 145/85 mm Hg. Physical examination of the chest did not reveal any remarkable symptoms and abdominal examination was essentially normal. His cardiovascular and neurological exams were within normal parameters.  Investigation Results  Upon EKG  the patient's rhythm confirmed atrial fibrillation (AF) with a ventricular response ~90-100 bpm. No ST-segment changes were observed. A transthoracic echocardiogram was performed which showed left atrial enlargement with no evidence of any valvular disease.  Thyroid function test and electrolytes were within normal limits. Blood glucose levels were slightly elevated (despite taking the prescribed antidysrhythmic therapy) and so were lipid profile parameters  indicating poor glycemic and hyperlipidemia control.  Diagnosis  The clinical presentation and investigations led to the diagnosis of non-valvular atrial fibrillation with a moderate-to-high stroke risk.  Management   Therapy was initiated with oral anticoagulation (Warfarin) targeting an INR of 2-3. Rate control was achieved by increasing the dose of Amlodipine to 10 mg twice daily and adding Metoprolol 25mg twice daily due to his dual therapy resistant hypertension and atrial fibrillation. His glycemic control was addressed by adding Glipizide 5mg daily to his existing Metformin treatment. Lifestyle modification counseling and dietary advice were given.  Follow-up  The patient was booked for fortnightly follow-ups to monitor his INR levels and the impact of new therapies.  Summary   The patient's atrial fibrillation seems to be aggravated by his co-existing chronic conditions i.e.  hypertension and diabetes  which were not adequately controlled. His previous history of TIA and family history of MI and AF play a crucial role in his ongoing atrial fibrillation persistency and potential thromboembolic risks. The patient has been put on serious medical therapy and close follow-ups. His health condition needs to be monitored regularly to avert any serious cardiovascular event.

Title: New-Onset Atrial Fibrillation in a 65-Year-Old Female: A Case Report  I. Patient Information:   1. Demographics: A 65-year-old Caucasian female. 2. Presenting complaint: Complaints of intermittent palpitations and shortness of breath for the past four weeks.   II. Clinical Findings:   On physical examination  vital signs were stable with a blood pressure reading of 130/85 mmHg  respiratory rate of 20 breaths/min  and a pulse rate of 110 beats/min  irregularly irregular. Cardiovascular examination revealed an irregularly irregular heart rhythm.   III. Personal & Past Medical History:   The patient had a history of well-controlled hypertension for 10 years and is under medication (Lisinopril 20 mg once a day). She is non-diabetic  a non-smoker  and occasionally consumes alcohol. There is no family history of cardiac diseases.   IV. Diagnostic Assessment:   Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) showed normal left ventricular systolic function with no structural heart disease. Complete blood counts  liver function test  kidney function test  and thyroid function test were all within normal limits. Anticoagulant therapy was started immediately based on CHA2DS2-VASc score calculation (Score: 2 - Hypertension and age). Additionally  a Holter monitor was installed to document the frequency and duration of episodes.  V. Therapeutic Intervention:   The patient was managed with a rate control strategy using beta-blockers (Metoprolol 50mg) and anti-coagulation therapy with Apixaban 5mg twice a day.   VI. Follow-up and Outcomes:  She was advised to monitor her heart rate and blood pressure at home and to maintain a healthy lifestyle with a low-sodium diet  regular exercise  and moderate alcohol consumption. After three weeks  the patient reported a substantial decrease in symptoms with stable heart rate and blood pressure. There were no complications noted in the subsequent follow-up visits.  VII. Learning Points:   Atrial fibrillation can occur in the absence of significant structural heart disease and can present as intermittent palpitations and breathlessness. In an elderly patient with hypertension  it is essential to be cautious of silent atrial fibrillation and start anticoagulation therapy to avoid complications like stroke. Emphasis should be placed on lifestyle modifications in the management of atrial fibrillation.   VIII. Patient Consent:   Consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.

Patient Case Report – Atrial Fibrillation  Patient Information Patient initial: M.S. Gender: Male Age: 78 years old Ethnicity: Asian Occupational Background: Retired engineer.  Presenting Concerns The patient presented the complaints of palpitations  intermittent shortness of breath  anxiety  unilateral weakness and fainting episodes for the past four weeks. He also expressed increasing fatigue and occasional dizziness particularly on exertion.  Medical History The patient has a known medical history of Hypertension  Dyslipidemia and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. He was diagnosed with these conditions 10 years ago  for which he is on medication - Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Statins for Dyslipidemia. The patient quit smoking 7 years ago and has a 30-pack per year history of smoking. He admits to being a social drinker and being non-compliant to his medications occasionally.  Family history noted his father had ischemic heart disease and his mother had a stroke in her late 70s.  Clinical Findings On physical examination  the patient appeared anxious. The irregular rhythm of his heartbeat was observed. His blood pressure was 145/90mmHg and pulse irregular at 110 bpm. No signs of peripheral edema were observed. No notable abnormalities were observed in the chest and lungs.  Diagnostic Assessment An Electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed which indicated atrial fibrillation (AF)  with an irregularly irregular rhythm  absence of P waves and a varying ventricular response. There was no evidence of ischemia or infarction on the ECG.  For further investigation  an echocardiogram was performed that showed mild left ventricular hypertrophy and left atrial enlargement  otherwise normal systolic function of both ventricle. Thyroid function tests were within normal range  ruling out any thyroid-induced AF. Other blood tests revealed impaired glucose tolerance and elevated cholesterol levels.  Management The patient was diagnosed with chronic AF. Anticoagulant therapy (Warfarin) was initiated to prevent thrombus formation and reduce stroke risk due to his elevated CHA2DS2-VASc score (3 points for hypertension  age and diabetes). Rate control was achieved with beta-blocker (Bisoprolol).  The patient was also suggested lifestyle changes and dietary modification to manage his blood pressure  blood sugars  and cholesterol levels. He was advised regular follow-ups for monitoring his condition and anticoagulation status.  Prognosis With the right management and lifestyle modifications  the patient was explained that his symptoms could be controlled  and risks reduced. However  he was also told the importance of medication adherence.  Informed Consent Consent for this case report was taken from the patient. The patient's identity remained confidential.

Title: Persistent Atrial Fibrillation in a 69-Year-Old Male with History of Heart Disease  Patient Profile:  A 69-year-old Caucasian male presented to the outpatient department complaining of recurrent episodes of palpitations and mild shortness of breath for the past two months.  Medical Background:  The patient has a known clinical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia and coronary artery disease  which have been treated with atorvastatin  lisinopril  and metoprolol respectively. He had a balloon angioplasty 7 years ago due to a heart attack and since then has been on regular follow-ups. His surgical history is uncharacteristic  having had only a right inguinal hernia repair 25 years ago. The patient quit smoking approximately 15 years ago  after a 20-year history of tobacco use. He denies any history of alcohol or drug abuse. There are no known allergies. His family history is remarkable for hypertension in both parents and myocardial infarction in his father.  Symptoms & Physical Examination:  The patient described his symptoms as a sensation of a rapid  irregular heartbeat  intermittent mild dyspnea  and occasional fatigue. He denied experiencing chest pain  lightheadedness  or syncope. On physical examination  he was normotensive with a blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg  pulse irregularly irregular at a rate of 82-107 beats/minute  and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air.  Investigations:  His 12-lead electrocardiogram (EKG) showed irregularly irregular rhythm without any obvious P wave and absence of an isoelectric line  confirming atrial fibrillation (AF). Echocardiogram exhibited normal ventricular function with left ventricle ejection fraction (EF) of 55% and no valvular abnormalities. Lab work included a complete blood count  comprehensive metabolic panel  and thyroid-stimulating hormone  all of which were within normal limits  except for slightly elevated LDL cholesterol. The patient's CHA2DS2-VASc score was calculated to be 3  indicating moderate risk for stroke.   Treatment:  The patient was started on oral anticoagulation (rivaroxaban) to prevent thromboembolic complications  and his dose of metoprolol was increased to better control the heart rate.  Follow-Up & Prognosis:  He was encouraged to follow a low-saturated fat diet and increase his physical activity. Patient compliance and tolerance with his updated medication regimen have been optimal with reports of symptomatic relief. He is being regularly followed-up in the outpatient department for monitoring his symptoms  side effects  and INR levels.  This case demonstrates a typical presentation of persistent atrial fibrillation in an elderly male patient with existing heart conditions  identifying risk factors and management approaches that are ideally suited for such a case.

Title: Management of Atrial Fibrillation in a 72-year-old Female Patient  Patient Information  The patient is a Caucasian 72-year-old female with a history of atrial fibrillation (AF) from a rural setting. She has medical history comprising diabetes mellitus type 2 and hypertension. She does not have any known drug allergies.  Clinical Findings  The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of palpitations and shortness of breath  which started three days before her admission. She denies having chest pain  cough  or fever. Upon further evaluation  it was noted that she had an irregular pulse.
