The patient’s blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg  and her heart rate was 120 bpm  irregularly irregular. The body mass index was within normal limits. There were no signs of congestive heart failure.  Diagnostic Assessment  Her electrocardiogram (ECG) showed AF with a rapid ventricular response. A complete blood count (CBC) and basic metabolic panel (BMP) were within normal limits. Hemoglobin A1C was 7.3%. An echocardiogram showed normal systolic and diastolic function without any valvular abnormalities.   Therapeutic Intervention   The patient was initiated on diltiazem drip with a subsequent decrease in heart rate to 80 bpm  after which she converted to normal sinus rhythm. She was started on anticoagulation therapy with warfarin considering her CHA2DS2-VASc score; given her history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus  and her being above 65 years of age. Her rate control was managed with metoprolol tartarate.  Follow-up and Outcome  Upon discharge  the patient was advised to continue medications as prescribed and to follow up in the outpatient clinic in two weeks or sooner if symptoms recur. An appointment was scheduled with a cardiologist for further management of her AF. During the outpatient visit  she reported feeling much better  and her repeat ECG confirmed normal sinus rhythm.  Lessons Learned  Keeping in focus the aging population and the increased prevalence of AF  the primary focus should be to identify the condition promptly and manage it effectively to reduce complications. Effective rate control  using beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers to control the heart rate  should be used in managing patients with atrial fibrillation in context of emergency. Anticoagulation therapy is highly recommended in patients with a higher risk profile to prevent stroke. The patient's comorbid conditions significantly contribute to the choice of medication and management strategy. Regular follow-up is crucial to monitor the disease progression and necessary adjustment of the treatment regimen.

Case Report:  Patient Information: A 75-year-old African American male named John presenting with a history of palpitations and fatigue during daily activities. The patient resides in a suburban neighborhood in North Carolina. He is retired  a non-smoker  and has a known history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. He follows a prescribed medication regimen of Metformin for diabetes and Losartan for hypertension.  Presenting Complaints and Symptoms: The patient has been experiencing symptoms such as racing and irregular heartbeats  fatigue  and shortness of breath for the past month. He reported that these symptoms are progressively becoming more noticeable and severe  particularly impacting his daily activities.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  a pulse check revealed irregular rhythm. In his electrocardiogram (EKG)  irregular R-R intervals and the absence of distinct P waves were evident  suggesting atrial fibrillation (AF). Moreover  a physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 145/95 mmHg  and a blood glucose level of 180 mg/dL. The results of his blood test depicted elevated HbA1c levels  implying poor control of diabetes.  Diagnosis: Given the clinical findings and the EKG results  the patient was diagnosed with AF. This diagnosis was based on guidelines by the American Heart Association (AHA) indicating that the presence of an irregular rhythm with no distinct P waves is indicative of AF.  Treatment Plan: The patient was started on a course of anticoagulant therapy (Warfarin) to reduce the risk of stroke associated with AF  along with a Rate Control strategy (beta-blocker: Metoprolol) to manage the patient's AF. The patient's existing antihypertensive therapy was reassessed and a decision was made to continue the dose. Furthermore  his diabetes management was optimized by intensifying his diet control and adherence to Metformin.  Prognosis: Proper adherence to the therapeutic plan would improve his symptoms and quality of life. Given his age and comorbid conditions  the patient is considered at increased risk for stroke  thus regular follow-up visits and adjustments to treatment as necessary are of utmost importance.   This case underscores the importance of considering AF in elderly patients presenting with symptoms such as palpitations and fatigue. Additionally  it highlights the need for regular monitoring and effective management of co-existing conditions like hypertension and diabetes in patients with AF for reducing associated risks and improving patient outcomes.

Patient Demographics:  - Gender: Male - Age: 73 years - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired - Residential History: Lives in Mississippi  Case Description:  Mr. Smith  a 73-year-old retired Caucasian male living in Mississippi  presented to the outpatient department with complaints of palpitations  light-headedness  and occasional bouts of breathlessness. He described the palpitations as irregular and rapid and said they had been occurring over the past four weeks  despite no unusual physical exertion. He denied any history of neck pain  recent accidents  chest pain  or weight loss.  Medical History:  His past medical history includes hypertension diagnosed ten years ago  which is managed with Lisinopril. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia controlled with Atorvastatin. The patient has been a chronic smoker for the past 50 years and consumes mild-to-moderate amounts of alcohol. There is no known history of diabetes or stroke. He is not allergic to any known medications. His family history includes cardiovascular diseases; his father passed away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 65 and his mother had also suffered from atrial fibrillation.  Clinical Examination:  On examination  Mr. Smith appeared mildly distressed. His blood pressure was 160/95 mmHg  pulse irregularly irregular at 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 19 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation was 95% on room air. There were no jugular venous distension  swelling in the legs  or visible bulging veins.  Investigations:  Following this assessment  an electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed which showed atrial fibrillation (AF) with a rapid ventricular rate. Blood tests including complete blood count  renal function  liver function  TSH  and electrolyte  were within normal ranges. Lipid profile showed mild hyperlipidemia. Echocardiography revealed a structurally normal heart with mild left ventricular hypertrophy but with preserved ejection fraction. No other cardiac abnormalities were detected.  Diagnosis:  Mr. Smith was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation  based on his presenting complaints  clinical examination  and interpretation of the ECG results.  Treatment:  He was initially placed on a rate-control strategy with a calcium channel blocker  Diltiazem. Additionally  full anticoagulation with Apixaban was started given his risk factors (hypertension  age  and a father with past cardiac problems) to prevent any stroke.  Mr. Smith was advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle  perform regular exercise  and quit smoking and alcohol consumption. He was referred to a pharmacist to ensure medication compliance  and a dietician for weight management advice.  The above case report serves as an example of a patient presentation for underlying atrial fibrillation  which is pivotal to identify and manage early to prevent further cardiogenic and thromboembolic complications.

Patient Information: John Doe  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  former engineer residing in California  USA. He's a non-smoker with a history of moderate alcohol consumption and has been sedentary for the last ten years since his retirement. He has a family history of heart disease  with his father suffering a heart attack at the age of 74.   Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 8 years. He has been on medication (Metformin for Diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension) with fair control of both conditions. He also has a history of mild asthmatic attacks  for which he has been prescribed Salbutamol inhaler as per required usage. There is no record of surgeries or trauma to the chest. He is not on any anticoagulant or antiplatelet therapy.  Presenting Complaints: The patient presented at the outpatient clinic with complaints of episodic palpitations  fatigue  and shortness of breath  which have been increasing in frequency and intensity over the past few weeks.   Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  an irregular heart rhythm was noted. The heart rate was irregular between 96-130 beats per minute; blood pressure was 145/90 mmHg. His body mass index (BMI) was found to be 28  which suggests he is overweight.  Diagnosis: ECG confirmed atrial fibrillation (AFib) with an irregularly irregular rhythm with no discernable P waves. Blood tests revealed controlled blood sugar levels with HbA1c of 6.9% but slightly elevated lipid profile.  Treatment: The patient was started on Beta-blocker (Metoprolol)  to control his heart rate  and an anticoagulant (Apixaban) to reduce the risk of clot formation. Lifestyle changes were also recommended  including a diet rich in fruits  vegetables  and whole grains  regular physical activity  weight loss  and limiting alcohol consumption.   Outcomes: The patient reported a decrease in the intensity and frequency of his symptoms after a month of therapy. Regular follow-ups were fixed with cardiology and internal medicine departments. The patient was advised to monitor his symptoms and seek help promptly if they worsen.   This case illustrates the importance of considering issues such as lifestyle factors and family history while managing patients with chronic conditions. It also reinforces the value of regular monitoring and timely intervention in managing cases like AFib. Patient compliance with medication and lifestyle modifications were crucial in this case for symptom improvement.   Patient Consent - Obtained.   Acknowledgements: None.  Conflict of Interest: None.   Funding Source: None.  Ethical Approval: Not required.

Title: A Case Report on Atrial Fibrillation in a 75-Year-old Male  Demographic Information   Patient initial: Mr. J   Age: 75   Sex: Male    Location: Utah  USA   Race: Caucasian    Clinical Presentation  Mr. J  a 75-year-old Caucasian male  residing in Utah  USA  presented to the hospital with symptoms of palpitation  shortness of breath  dizziness  and occasional chest discomfort. These symptoms were intermittent  largely occurring during the night.  Past Medical History  Mr. J was previously diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  approximately seven years ago. He had a myocardial infarction three years ago  for which he underwent angioplasty. Mr. J quit smoking 20 years ago but had a significant history of 30 pack-years prior to quitting. He has a known allergy to penicillin.  Family history indicated that his father died from a stroke at age 80 and a sister had coronary artery disease. He is under anti-hypertensive therapy (Lisinopril)  anti-diabetic medication (Metformin)  and a statin (Rosuvastatin)  and is on dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel) post angioplasty.  Physical Examination  Upon physical examination  he had an irregularly irregular pulse with a rate of about 110 per minute. The blood pressure reading was 135/84 mmHg. Oxygen saturation level was 96% on room air. Auscultatory examination unveiled a quiet first heart sound with an irregularly irregular rhythm.  Diagnostic Assessment  An electrocardiogram (ECG) was done which revealed an irregularly irregular rhythm with no recognizable P waves and an uncontrolled ventricular rate  indicative of atrial fibrillation. Echocardiography showed normal left ventricular function  mild left atrial enlargement and no significant valvular disease. Standard laboratory blood tests including complete blood count  blood glucose levels  renal function  liver function  lipid profile  and thyroid function tests were within normal range except for a slight elevation in blood glucose and LDL cholesterol.  Management & Follow-Up  Mr. J was diagnosed with chronic atrial fibrillation (non-valvular) and was categorized as moderate-high risk based on the CHA2DS2-VASc score. The goal of management was rate control  prevention of thromboembolic events  and symptom relief.   He was initiated on a beta-blocker (Metoprolol) for rate control. As the risk for stroke was high  he was started on oral anticoagulant therapy (Warfarin) after explaining the risk-benefit profile and obtaining informed consent. He was advised to monitor his INR levels every month and to adhere to his drug regimen meticulously. His anti-diabetic and anti-hypertensive treatments were continued with a tighter blood pressure and glucose control intended.  He was scheduled for a follow-up after 1 month and advised to seek immediate medical help if symptoms worsen  or if any signs of bleeding occur.  The patient’s quality of life showed signs of improvement with reduced episodes of palpitation and breathlessness on the subsequent follow-up. The INR was in the target range and the heart rate was well controlled. He is scheduled for routine follow-ups every three months to monitor his status.  Summary   This case report illustrates an elderly patient with a history of hypertension  diabetes  and prior myocardial infarction  developing atrial fibrillation. The patient's risk factors were properly assessed  and a suitable treatment plan was initiated which resulted in improved symptomatology. It reinforces the need for vigilance in monitoring and managing multi-morbid elderly patients.

Case Report: Atrial Fibrillation in a 68-Year-Old Male  Patient Information: Mr. X is a 68-year-old African American male  a retiree  residing in the urban area of Tucson  Arizona  with his wife. He's a nonsmoker with a history of moderate alcohol consumption but has been abstinent for the past five years.   Medical History: The patient has a history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus (well-controlled with Metformin)  Hypothyroidism (on Levothyroxine)  and Hypertension (managed with Losartan). He's been maintaining a good diet  regularly exercises and complies well with medications  showing a positive control over his chronic illnesses. However  he recently reported experiencing increasing fatigue  occasional light-headedness  and intermittent  rapid  palpitation-like sensations in his chest.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. X presented to the emergency department with palpitations  shortness of breath on exertion  and mild bilateral ankle swelling that he was experiencing over the past week.   Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed irregular heart rhythms without any murmurs  elevated blood pressure (145/90 mmHg)  and mild pitting edema in both ankles. The rest of the examination did not reveal any significant findings. Electrocardiogram (ECG) performed has demonstrated irregularly irregular rhythm without any ischemic changes  suggestive of atrial fibrillation (AF).   Diagnostic Assessment: Further cardiac testing was done which included Echo-Doppler showing an enlarged left atrium  and mild thickening of the mitral valve leaflets with no significant regurgitation or stenosis. The Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) level was within the normal range. Pro-BNP levels were slightly elevated.  Therapeutic Intervention: He was started on Warfarin and Atenolol along with a diuretic (Furosemide) for volume management. Patient's rhythm control was achieved with electric cardioversion. He was advised to continue his anticoagulation and return for follow-ups every month.  Follow-up and outcome: In the following weeks  the edema improved. The patient’s fatigue decreased significantly  and he was able to progressively resume his normal activities. He was counseled about his condition  the importance of regular INR check-ups while on Warfarin and medication adherence.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of considering atrial fibrillation in patients who present with symptoms of palpitations and shortness of breath  especially in the presence of risk factors like hypertension and diabetes. Early detection and proper management significantly influence the prognosis and quality of life of patients.

Patient Information  Mr. A  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  visited his primary care physician following episodes of palpitations and intermittent shortness of breath over the past few months. He has been a resident of Boston  Massachusetts  working as a retired finance executive. He lives with his wife  is a non-smoker  and practices moderate alcohol consumption.  Medical History  The patient has a medical history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He has been prescribed amlodipine 10mg daily for hypertension and atorvastatin 20mg nightly for hypercholesterolemia. He has been compliant with his pharmacotherapy and regular check-ups. There is no history of diabetes mellitus or thyroid disorders. His father had a myocardial infarction in his late sixties.   Clinical Findings  On examination  Mr. A had an irregular pulse of about 95 beats per minute. Blood pressure was 138/86 mm Hg. Other physical examination findings were unremarkable. An electrocardiogram (ECG) confirmed the presence of atrial fibrillation (AF). Laboratory tests including thyroid function were within normal range  except slightly elevated cholesterol levels. An echocardiogram was performed which did not indicate valvular disease or signs of structural heart defects.  Diagnosis  Based on his clinical findings and ECG evidence  Mr. A was diagnosed with non-valvular Atrial Fibrillation.  Treatment  After weighing his risk vs. benefit  the patient was prescribed Warfarin as an anticoagulant to prevent risk of stroke associated with AF. Additionally  control of heart rate and rhythm was targeted. He was started on metoprolol  a beta-blocker  to reduce his heart rate. As he was symptomatic with palpitations  a rhythm control strategy with amiodarone was adopted.  Follow-up and Outcomes  Mr. A was scheduled for routine check-ups every 3 months. His complete blood count  liver  and renal function tests were monitored regularly to assess for side effects of amiodarone and warfarin therapy. His INR levels were kept within the therapeutic range of 2.0-3.0. Over the next few months  he reported an improvement in his symptoms and a better quality of life.  Conclusion  The key to managing patients like Mr. A with AF involves careful consideration of a combined strategy of rate control  rhythm control  and anticoagulation. Patients should be closely monitored for therapy adherence as well as their therapeutic INR levels when on warfarin therapy. A multidisciplinary approach is necessary to lower the stroke risk and improve health outcomes  increasing patients' quality of life.

Case Report: Atrial Fibrillation  Patient Information:  Mr. Smith  a 69-year-old Caucasian male  presented to our cardiology department complaining of palpitations  shortness of breath  and fatigue. He works as a retired engineer  and he lives with his wife in the suburbs. He is a former smoker and has a detailed history of moderate alcohol consumption. His past medical history includes hypertension  managed with daily medication (Lisinopril - 10 mg). He also suffers from type 2 diabetes  which is controlled with Metformin (1000 mg twice daily). There has been no documented significant family history of cardiac diseases.  Clinical History and Examination: Upon examination  an irregular pulse was noted  along with high blood pressure readings (150/95 mmHg). The cardiovascular examination revealed an irregular cardiac rhythm with no murmurs. There was no lower extremity edema or jugular venous distention. Chest auscultation was clear  with no evidence of congestive heart failure. Further questions revealed he had been experiencing these symptoms intermittently for the past two months.  Diagnosis:  An Electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed  which showed an irregular rhythm with no distinct P waves  suggestive of Atrial Fibrillation (AF). A subsequent 24-hour Holter Monitor substantiated the suspected diagnosis of non-valvular atrial fibrillation. An echocardiogram did not show any significant valve disease or chamber enlargement. Routine blood tests were within normal range  except elevated HbA1c (8.2%)  confirming poor diabetic control.  Treatment and Progress:  Guided by his symptoms  CHADs-VASc Score (3 points for age  hypertension  and diabetes)  and HAS-BLED Score (2 points for hypertension and age over 65 years)  he was started on a treatment regimen which consisted of Rate Control Strategy (Metoprolol 50mg twice daily)  and anticoagulation therapy (Apixaban 5mg twice daily). Metformin dose was increased to achieve better control of his diabetes.  Follow-up and Outcomes: The patient was discharged with a scheduled 4-week follow-up to assess his response to the medication. Regular monitoring of vitals along with blood tests primarily for checking INR  kidney function  and blood sugar was recommended.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of prompt evaluation of cardiac symptoms in high-risk individuals. Crucially  the management of non-valvular atrial fibrillation includes addressing the underlying risk factors and comorbidities including hypertension and diabetes  which in this case were suboptimally controlled leading to his AF symptoms. Adherence to guideline-directed therapy is anticipated to yield stabilization of his atrial fibrillation and broad improvement in his cardiovascular health.

CASE REPORT  Patient Information: Mr. A.B  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired teacher  residing in Wisconsin. He is a non-smoker and moderate alcohol consumer.  Chief Complaint: Persistent palpitations and occasional fatigue over the past three weeks.  Past Medical History: Mr. A.B has a known case of Hypertension for past 15 years and Type II Diabetes Mellitus for four years. Both conditions are well-controlled with regular medications. He had a cholecystectomy 8 years back with no complications post-surgery. His family history reveals his father had a Myocardial Infarction at the age of 65. The patient is not known to have any drug allergies.   Clinical Findings: On examination  he appeared anxious. His pulse was irregularly irregular  with a rate of 120 beats/minute. His blood pressure was 170/100 mmHg. Cardiovascular examination revealed a soft first heart sound and no murmurs. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Investigative Tests: His electrocardiogram (ECG) showed atrial fibrillation (AF) with a rapid ventricular response. Blood tests revealed slightly elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP)  while blood glucose  lipid profile  renal function tests were within the normal range.  Diagnosis: Newly diagnosed with Atrial Fibrillation. His CHA2DS2-VASc score (a clinical prediction rule for estimating the risk of stroke in patients with non-rheumatic atrial fibrillation) was calculated to be 3  which suggests a moderate risk of stroke.  Management: He was started on a beta-blocker (Metoprolol) to control the heart rate. After ruling out contraindications  he was initiated on Oral anticoagulants (Apixaban) to reduce the risk of stroke. The patient was educated about his disease  drug compliance  lifestyle modifications  regular follow-ups  and when to seek hospital care.  Follow Up: The patient is scheduled for outpatient follow-up in two weeks to check for symptom resolution and ECG.  This case represents a typical first presentation of atrial fibrillation in an elderly patient with comorbid conditions  highlighting the importance of timely diagnosis and proper management to prevent severe complications like stroke.  This case was prepared by: Dr. XYZ  Cardiology Department  University Teaching Hospital  Wisconsin.

Case Report: Atrial Fibrillation in a 72-Year-Old Male Patient   Patient Information:   Mr. J is a 72-year-old Caucasian male presented into the emergency department with complaints of palpitations  fatigue  and shortness of breath  which he had been experiencing intermittently over the last two months. He had been previously healthy with no known medical illnesses. Patient works as a retired insurance officer and lives with his wife in a suburban residence.   Medical History:  He has no known allergies. He has not undergone any previous surgical procedures before this. He doesn't have a family history of heart disease. The patient is an ex-smoker and quit smoking about 20 years ago. He admits to moderate alcohol consumption.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  his heart rate is irregular and tachycardic  120 beats/minute. His blood pressure is 144/90 mmHg. He appeared slightly pale with cold sweats but was not in acute distress. His weight and body mass index were within normal limits. On auscultation  his heart sounds were irregularly irregular with no added sounds or murmurs. His respiratory and abdominal examinations were normal. His oxygen saturation was above 95% on room air.  Diagnostic Assessment:   An emergency electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrated atrial fibrillation (AF) with a fast ventricular rate. Also observed was a slight ST-depression. Laboratory findings  including a full blood count  serum electrolytes  thyroid function test  D-dimer  and biomarkers for myocardial infarction (troponin I and CK-MB) were obtained and found to be within normal range  excluding acute coronary syndrome.   Echo-cardiogram findings confirmed mitral valve regurgitation and left atrial enlargement. Treadmill exercise stress testing could not be conducted due to his heart condition.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was started on a rate-controlling drug (β-blocker  metoprolol) and anticoagulation with warfarin for stroke prevention. Electrical cardioversion was considered but was deferred as the AF is suspected to be more than 48 hours.  Follow up and outcomes:  The patient was overseen for four days in the hospital before he was discharged with a follow up appointment in the outpatient clinic. At a 2 weeks follow up  he demonstrated good tolerance to medications  and palpitations were not recurrent. His AF was managed with medical therapy (rate control strategy) and anticoagulation  given his elevated CHA2DS2-VASc score.  This case underpins the significance of a prompt diagnosis and the need for acute treatment  emphasizing on rate control  rhythm control  and prevention of thromboembolism in managing atrial fibrillation. Increased awareness about this common arrhythmia amongst primary care physicians is requisite for the timely diagnosis and management of such patients.

Title: Case Report of A Primary Aorto-Pulmonary Fistula Leading to Atrial Fibrillation in a 65-Year-Old Female  Patient Information:   The patient  a 65-year-old Caucasian female  presented at the Emergency Department with chief complaints of chest discomfort  palpitations  dyspnea  and mild dizziness. The patient is a retired school teacher and lives with her husband. She is a nonsmoker and nonalcoholic. She has a known case of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which she had been managing with medication and lifestyle modifications for the past 5 years. Her family history revealed her father had myocardial infarction at the age of 67.   Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  the patient displayed an irregular heartbeat with a rate of 140 beats per minute and blood pressure of 155/85 mmHg. Her oxygen saturation level was 95% in room air. Furthermore  an electrocardiogram (ECG) showed atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. Chest radiograph  blood tests  and thyroid function test were within normal limits.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was initially treated with intravenous metoprolol for rate control  as well as for its protective effect in myocardial ischemia. Simultaneously  oral anticoagulant drug Warfarin was also started considering her CHA2DS2-VASc score of 3 (hypertension  diabetes  and age >65).   Outcome:   The patient's heart rate was controlled and her symptoms were improved within 48 hours. She was advised for cardioversion  considering her rapid ventricular rate and symptomatic status  but she opted for the rate control strategy alone.   Follow-up:  Close follow up was advised to the patient to monitor the external signs of bleeding or bruising due to anticoagulant therapy. She was made to understand the need for monitoring International Normalized Ratio (INR) values regularly while initiating the anticoagulant. The importance of maintaining a healthy lifestyle  regular exercise  salt  and dietary restrictions were emphasized during discharge counseling.  Conclusion:  This case study elucidates the need for an appropriate approach in managing atrial fibrillation  especially in elderly patients with comorbid conditions like hypertension and Diabetes Mellitus. Advocacy for personalized medicine  careful monitoring  and patient education play a pivotal role in managing such cases.  Contributors:  Physician: Dr. XYZ Nurse: Ms. ABC Pharmacist: Mr. LMN

Title: Chronic Atrial Fibrillation in a 68-year-old Male Patient: A Case Report   Patient Description: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  living in a suburban area with his wife. He has a history of smoking for 40 years but quit 10 years ago. He reports occasional alcohol consumption.  Past Medical History: He has a history of hypertension which has been controlled with antihypertensive medication (lisinopril) for the last 15 years. Diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago  he has been managing this condition with metformin and a modified diet. His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 72 and his older brother has been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented to the outpatient department with an irregular heartbeat and episodes of breathlessness over the past two months. These episodes were usually during physical activity and subsided with rest.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the patient had an irregular pulse of 98 beats per minute. His blood pressure was 160/90mmHg  indicating that his hypertension was not well-controlled. A Chest X-ray showed no signs of pulmonary edema. An electrocardiogram was performed and demonstrated atrial fibrillation.  Diagnostic Assessment: The patient was diagnosed with chronic atrial fibrillation based on his symptoms  physical examination findings  and electrocardiogram results. Further assessment of his condition was conducted through a comprehensive blood panel  revealing poor glycemic control and elevated cholesterol levels leading to a diagnosis of dyslipidemia.  Interventions: The patient was prescribed warfarin to reduce the risk of thromboembolic events associated with atrial fibrillation. Instructions were given on monitoring his blood thinning levels (INR checks). His antihypertensive medication was switched to a calcium channel blocker (amlodipine) to help manage the atrial fibrillation and an additional statin medication was prescribed to lower his cholesterol. A recommendation was made for him to meet with a dietitian to help manage his glycemic control and lower cholesterol through dietary modifications.  Outcome and Follow-up: With medication adjustments and dietary changes  the patient’s symptoms eased substantially. His blood pressure and cholesterol levels improved. He was scheduled for regular follow-ups with the cardiology department to keep a close check on his atrial fibrillation  blood glucose levels  and overall cardiac health.   Conclusion: This case illustrates the complexity of managing a patient with multiple comorbidities including atrial fibrillation  diabetes and hypertension. It also emphasizes the importance of comprehensive follow-up and the need for patient adherence to medication and lifestyle changes.

Title: Atrial Fibrillation Case Study in a 65-year-old Male with Hypertension  Patient Information:   The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired school teacher  who presented to the clinic due to palpitations and mild chest discomfort which started two days prior to the consultation.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of hypertension for the past 10 years and has been on antihypertensive medications  specifically Losartan (50mg) and Amlodipine (10mg)  which he takes daily. According to the patient  he has been adherent to the medication regimen. He was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia 5 years back and is on Atorvastatin (20mg daily).   There is no history of diabetes  thyroid disease  or previous episodes of palpitations. He has not undergone any operations or hospitalizations previously. The patient does not smoke or consume alcohol.   Clinical Findings:  On examination  the patient appears comfortable but anxious. His blood pressure is found to be 140/90 mmHg  and a heart rate of 110 beats per minute (bpm)  which was irregularly irregular on auscultation. His respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute and he maintains 97% oxygen saturation on room air.  Diagnostic Assessment:  The electrocardiogram (ECG) showed atrial fibrillation with a ventricular response of 110 bpm. A transthoracic echocardiogram demonstrated normal left ventricular systolic function and no valvular abnormalities  but left atrial enlargement was noted.  Laboratory findings showed a slight elevation in the N-terminal pro b-type natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) levels. Complete blood count  renal function  and electrolytes were within normal ranges. The lipid profile showed total cholesterol of 210mg/dL and LDL of 130mg/dL. TSH levels were normal.   Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was started on anticoagulation with Apixaban to reduce his risk of stroke. Rate control was achieved using beta-blockers (Metoprolol). He was advised to continue his antihypertensive and antihyperlipidemic treatments.  Follow-Up:  The patient was discharged after stabilization and scheduled for a follow-up after 2 weeks. He was counselled about the signs and symptoms of potential complications like stroke and heart failure and was advised to seek immediate medical help in case such symptoms occur.  Conclusion:  Given the patient's age  existing hypertension and newly diagnosed atrial fibrillation  his management was centered on controlling his heart rate  maintaining his blood pressure and preventing possible thromboembolic events. His case highlights the importance of appropriate management of these cases to reduce morbidity and mortality associated with atrial fibrillation.

Title: Chronic Atrial Fibrillation in a 65-Year-Old Diabetic Female  Patient Information: A 65-year-old African American female was admitted to the hospital complaining of irregular heartbeat  shortness of breath  fatigue  and slight dizziness for the past few days. The patient is a widow living in a suburban area; she has two children who live abroad.   Past Medical History: The patient has a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus for which she has been on metformin for the past 10 years. In addition  she has been diagnosed with primary hypertension and managed with a daily dose of Lisinopril for the last 7 years. Her familial history reveals that her father died of myocardial infarction at 70 years old  and her mother died from breast cancer at 78 years. The patient was found to be obese with body mass index of 32  follows an unhealthy diet  and has a sedentary lifestyle. She is a non-smoker and has no history of alcohol misuse.   Presenting Complaints:  She reported experiencing irregular heartbeat  fatigue  and slight dizziness over the last couple of days. In addition to worsening fatigue  she had two episodes of brief lightheadedness  which were more pronounced upon rising from seating position. She denied chest pain  night sweats  nausea  or vomiting.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed irregularly irregular pulse rate at 110/min  blood pressure 150/90 mmHg and an oxygen saturation level of 96% on room air. Cardiovascular examination detected an irregular rhythm. No murmurs or gallops were detected. The rest of the examination was essentially unremarkable.  Diagnostic Tests and Intervention:  To confirm the diagnosis  an electrocardiogram was performed which verified atrial fibrillation. Further  an echocardiogram showed normal systolic and diastolic function with no valvular abnormalities. Initial lab results showed slightly elevated HbA1c and blood glucose levels  indicating the patient's diabetes was not well controlled. Targets were adjusted  and the patient was advised to maintain a stricter control and diet modifications.  Following these tests  the patient was managed with rate control which was achieved with the aid of a beta-blocker  metoprolol. Oral anticoagulation for stroke prevention was initiated with apixaban  taking into account her age and the presence of diabetes and hypertension.  Discussion:  The presence of persistent atrial fibrillation in the patient  her age above 65 years  and a history of hypertension and diabetes put her at a high risk for developing embolic events including stroke. As such  she was started on oral anticoagulant therapy for stroke prevention. She was also educated on the need to maintain a healthier lifestyle and proper diet to control her diabetes and obesity  both of which are exacerbators of her atrial fibrillation.  Conclusion: This case underscores the need for early recognition and management of atrial fibrillation  particularly in patients with diabetes and hypertension  and the importance of preventive strategies including healthier lifestyle changes. Patients should be educated about their diagnosis  treatment options  and associated risks.

Patient Information:  Mr. X is a 72-year-old Caucasian male residing in the suburban region of the Midwestern United States. He has been retired for ten years  previously working as a school teacher. He is a non-smoker but admits to moderate alcohol consumption. His dietary habits are generally healthy and he has no known drug allergies.   Presenting Complaint:  He primarily presented with new onset palpitations lasting for hours  occasional dizziness  and increasing fatigue over the last two months.  Past Medical History:  Mr. X has a documented medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he has been on medication (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  respectively) for roughly seven years. There are no records of any cardiac issues or surgical intervention.   Family History:   His mother passed away in her 80s due to a reported myocardial infarction  but his father lived till his late 90s  with no known significant illnesses. His two older siblings are alive and well  with no significant illnesses.   Physical Examination:  On physical examination  Mr. X’s vital signs were within normal limits apart from a mildly elevated blood pressure (145/90 mmHg). He had an irregular rhythm which was noted on auscultation. His lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally  and there were no reports of hearing loss.  Investigations:  Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed irregularly irregular rhythm and absence of P waves were noted  in keeping with atrial fibrillation (AF). The thyroid function test  renal function test  and liver function test were within normal limits. His lipid profile was marginally elevated. A transthoracic echocardiogram revealed no apparent structural abnormalities  and the left ventricle ejection fraction was estimated to be around 55%.  Diagnosis:  Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation.   Treatment:  He was started on a regimen of beta-blockers (Metoprolol) for rhythm control and rate control. An oral anticoagulant  Warfarin  was commenced considering his stroke risk factors  after he consulted with the doctor.   Conclusion:  In conclusion  Mr. X's case is a common presentation of new-onset atrial fibrillation in the elderly  with risk factors including hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The necessary medical therapy was instituted after appropriate investigations were performed. He has been advised about lifestyle modifications  and regular follow-up visits are scheduled for close monitoring.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 70 years Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Accountant  History:  Mr. Doe has been under the monitoring of Dr. Smith for the past 15 years with a history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus  both are well controlled with medication (Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension). Mr. Doe is a non-smoker  and drinks moderate alcohol occasionally. His father had a history of cardiovascular diseases and passed away due to myocardial infarction at the age of 75.  Presenting Complaints:  Over the past few weeks  Mr. Doe has been experiencing occasional bouts of breathlessness  fatigue  and palpitations particularly during slight physical activity. The symptoms were initially brushed off as effects of aging and stress  but when the frequency increased  he decided to consult Dr. Smith.  Clinical Examination:  During the physical examination  Dr. Smith noted irregular heartbeats with a heart rate of 96 beats per minute. Blood pressure was within the normal range. An EKG was ordered immediately.  Investigations and Results:  The EKG confirmed irregular heart rhythms  consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF). A blood test was also conducted  the results of which showed an elevated level of B-type natriuretic peptide  suggesting heart failure. Other routine blood parameters like blood glucose  lipid profile  and renal function were within normal limits. An echocardiogram was advised  which exhibited reduced ejection fraction and left atrial enlargement  matching with the diagnosis of atrial fibrillation.  Diagnosis:  Mr. Doe has been diagnosed with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation with a high CHA2DS2-VASc score which points towards a high risk of stroke.  Management Plan:  The treatment strategy is aimed towards controlling the heart rate  preventing subsequent strokes  and restoring the normal heart rhythm. Mr. Doe is prescribed beta-blockers (Metoprolol) to manage heart rate and anticoagulant therapy (Warfarin) to prevent any thromboembolic event. He will also be given Flecanide under close supervision in the hospital to restore the normal heart rhythm.  Follow up:  Mr. Doe is scheduled for regular monitoring and follow ups every two weeks to adjust medication doses if necessary. He is also advised to reduce alcohol intake  maintain a healthy diet  and engage in regular light physical exercise. The importance of adhering to medication is emphasized to Mr. Doe  including the need for regular INR monitoring while on Warfarin.  DR. SMITH  MD Primary Care Physician

Title: An Uncommon Case Report of Atrial Fibrillation in a Young Adult Female with No Preexisting Cardiovascular Conditions  Patient Identification: Anonymous (to respect patient's confidentiality)  Demographics: A 26-year-old Caucasian female  Chief Complaint: Palpitations  shortness of breath  fatigue  occasional dizziness  Present History: The patient has been experiencing episodes of palpitations and fatigue over the past two months. These incidents have been become increasingly frequent in the last two weeks  one time resulted in a near syncope. This led her to seek medical attention.   Past Medical History: The patient has no personal or family history of cardiovascular disease or other significant disorders. Her medical history was notable for hypothyroidism which she reported was well controlled with appropriate doses of levothyroxine. She denied any history of smoking  excessive alcohol usage or any substance abuse. She does not take any medications besides her thyroid medication.   Clinical Examination: Examination showed an irregularly irregular pulse. Blood pressure was 115/70 mm Hg  heart rate was irregular at 92-156 bpm  and respiratory rate was 16 breaths/min. Cardiovascular exam revealed irregular rhythms  no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Lungs were clear.   Investigations:  - Blood samples demonstrated normal complete blood count  metabolic panel and thyroid function tests.  - Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed irregular rhythm with no P waves  consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF). - Echocardiogram showed normal ventricular size and function  without any valvular abnormalities.  - Holter monitoring for 24 hours confirmed paroxysmal atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.   Management: As this is the first episode  a rate control strategy was implemented with beta-adrenergic blockers. In addition  due to her age and low CHA2DS2-VASc score  anticoagulation was not immediately initiated. However  considering the frequent episodes and her symptomatic status  a rhythm control strategy may have to be considered in the future.  Outcomes and Follow-Up: Her symptoms significantly improved on the rate control strategy with fewer episodes of palpitations. She was advised regular follow-ups and to report back immediately if any new symptoms arise or existing symptoms worsen.  In summary  this case highlights the unpredictability of atrial fibrillation  suggesting that in patients presenting with similar symptoms  regardless of their age or absence of risk factors  a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation should be explored.   This case also reinforces the importance of individualized treatment strategy in atrial fibrillation considering the variability in clinical presentation and course of disease among patients.

Title: A case of Non-valvular Atrial Fibrillation in a 72-Year-Old Male with Hypertension and Diabetes  Patients Information  Patient: Mr. John Doe Gender: Male Age: 72 years old Ethnicity: Caucasian  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Doe presented at the clinic complaining of recurrent episodes of palpitations and fatigue since 3 weeks.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension which were diagnosed 10 years prior. Both conditions have been managed with oral medication: Metformin 500mg twice daily for diabetes and Lisinopril 10mg once daily for hypertension. He also reported having controlled his lifestyle: routine physical exercise and restricted salt and sugar intake. Family history revealed his father died of a stroke in his 70's.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed an irregularly irregular pulse on palpation and a blood pressure reading of 145/90 mmHg. Cardiac auscultation further showed irregular rhythms. Other systems revealed no abnormalities.  Investigations: An EKG confirmed an atrial fibrillation (AF) with no evidence of acute ischemic changes. His blood investigations including full blood count  renal function  thyroid function  and coagulation profile were within normal limits. His glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) was noted to be 7.3% and a fasting glucose level was 145 mg/dl. A transthoracic echocardiogram revealed no structural abnormalities  ruling out valvular AF  with a preserved left ventricular ejection fraction.  Diagnostic Assessment: Mr. Doe was diagnosed with non-valvular atrial fibrillation. His CHA2DS2-VASc score (a clinical prediction rule for estimating the risk of stroke in patients with non-rheumatic atrial fibrillation) was 3  placing him in a high-risk category.  Therapeutic Interventions: He was started on Apixaban  an oral anticoagulant  for stroke prevention. Rate control with Metoprolol was preferred over rhythm control  considering his age and co-existing comorbidities.  Follow Up: He responded well to the treatment with a reduction in episodes of palpitations and improved overall well-being. His blood pressure was also better controlled. The patient was scheduled for monthly follow-ups  and was advised about lifestyle modifications and regular monitoring of INR and kidney function.  Summary: This case highlights the common presentation of AF in an elderly patient with underlying chronic diseases  particularly hypertension and diabetes. It emphasizes the necessity of early identification and intervention to prevent potential complications such as stroke.

Case Report: Atrial Fibrillation In An Elderly Patient  Patient Information  The patient is an 81-year-old Caucasian female presenting with intermittent palpitations and an episode of sudden onset shortness of breath. She resides in a suburban environment and lives alone. She is a retired school teacher  nonsmoker  and consumes alcohol occasionally. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia and has no known drug allergies. She is currently on Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension  and Atorvastatin 20mg daily for hyperlipidemia.  Clinical Findings   The patient reports experiencing palpitations intermittently over the past six months  but recently they have increased in both frequency and intensity. She also reported an episode of suddent onset shortness of breath that lasted for roughly 20 minutes and subsequently resolved itself. No accompanying chest pain  lightheadedness  or syncope was reported. Other symptoms  such as fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance  were also noted. She denied systemic symptoms like fevers  chills  weight loss  blurry vision  or confusion.  Diagnostic Assessment  On physical examination  her vital signs on arrival showed a blood pressure of 150/80 mmHg  heart rate of irregularly irregular 96 beats per minute (bpm)  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 96% while breathing room air.   Her ECG showed an irregularly irregular rhythm  confirming atrial fibrillation. Her complete blood count  kidney  and liver function tests were found to be within the normal range. However  lipid profile revealed elevated levels of LDL cholesterol. Transthoracic echocardiography displayed normal left ventricular function without any significant valvular heart disease.   Therapeutic Intervention  The patient was stabilized with a rate control strategy with Metoprolol titrated to achieve a resting heart rate less than 80 bpm. She was initiated on Rivaroxaban anticoagulation therapy for stroke prevention due to her elevated CHA2DS2-VASc Score.  Follow-Up and Outcomes  The patient recorded a satisfactory response to the rate control therapy as her symptoms reduced significantly. Follow-up after four weeks showed the patient was stable without any further episodes of palpitations or breathlessness. Regular blood tests  including INR monitoring  confirmed that the anticoagulation was being managed appropriately.  Patient Perspective  The patient expressed relief regarding her symptom control and understanding of her condition. She welcomed the changes to her medication regimen  with the primary concern being the prevention of stroke.  Conclusion  This case underscores the importance of taking detailed history and performing pertinent physical examination in the diagnosis of atrial fibrillation  a common cardiac arrhythmia in the elderly that can lead to severe complications if not managed properly. This patient’s atrial fibrillation was successfully managed with rate control and anticoagulation strategy.

Title: A Case Report on a 78-Year-Old Female Patient with Atrial Fibrillation  Patient Information: The patient is a 78-year-old Caucasian female with a medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hypercholesterolemia. She retired from her job as a school teacher at 65 and has been living a sedentary lifestyle since then. The patient lives independently in her own home and has a network of close relatives who actively participate in her care and wellbeing.  Presenting Concerns: The patient presented to the cardiology outpatient clinic with a three-week history of palpitations  fatigue  and intermittent light-headedness. She reported no associated chest pain  syncope  dyspnea  cough  or fever.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed an irregularly irregular pulse at a rate of 92 bpm. Blood pressure was measured at 152/84 mmHg. The rest of the cardiovascular exam  including auscultation  did not reveal any significant abnormalities. Electrocardiogram (ECG) confirmed atrial fibrillation (AF) with a ventricular rate of 95 beats per minute.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment: Complete blood count and metabolic panel were within normal range with the exception of slightly elevated blood sugar and cholesterol levels. Transthoracic echocardiogram showed a structurally normal heart with a mildly dilated left atrium but no thrombus was detected. Thyroid function tests were normal  ruling out thyrotoxicosis as a cause of AF.  Therapeutic Focus and Intervention: Risk factors were assessed via the CHA2DS2-VASc and HAS-BLED scores which were calculated to be 4 and 2  respectively  suggesting a significantly higher risk of stroke but a relatively lower risk of major bleeding. She was started on oral anticoagulation with warfarin to prevent thromboembolic events. Rate control was the primary treatment of choice for her AF. She was started on metoprolol to achieve adequate rate control and to relieve her symptoms of palpitations and fatigue. Her hypertension  diabetes  and hypercholesterolemia were managed with ongoing medical therapy (lisinopril  metformin  and atorvastatin).  Follow-Up and Outcomes: After a week of treatment initiation  the patient reported substantial improvement in symptoms. Follow up ECG showed adequate rate control within the target range. She will be closely monitored for potential side effects of warfarin therapy with regular INR checks and also for optimal control of her other chronic conditions. She has also been counseled to maintain a more active lifestyle within her capabilities and adhere to a diabetic and cardiac friendly diet.  Patient Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for the publication of this case report.

Patient Case Report: Atrial Fibrillation  Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the walk-in clinic with complaints of heart palpitations  fatigue  shortness of breath  and occasional dizziness. He is a retired teacher who lives with his wife in a suburban community.  Past Medical and Family History: Mr. Doe has a history of type 2 diabetes (for 15 years  currently under control with diet and oral medication: Metformin) and hypertension (treated with Lisinopril). He was a smoker for 30 years  but quit 10 years ago. His mother died at the age of 72 due to a stroke  and his father passed away at 78 from a myocardial infarction.  Clinical Findings: At presentation  the patient’s vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  pulse irregular at 110 beats per minute  a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. Physical examination showed irregular pulse rhythm. No sign of congestive heart failure was identified. No signs of overt ischemia were seen on the EKG  except for irregularly irregular rhythm  which raised the suspicion of atrial fibrillation (AF).  Diagnostic Assessment: To confirm the diagnosis  a 24-hour Holter monitor was ordered  which showed persistent atrial fibrillation. His blood workup was revealed a controlled blood glucose level and an elevated blood pressure. Fasting lipid profile showed elevated LDL-cholesterol. An echocardiogram was then ordered  which showed no structural heart disease but confirmed the presence of atrial fibrillation.  Treatment: The patient was started on anticoagulation with warfarin (aiming for an INR of 2-3) to prevent thromboembolic events. Since he carries structural heart disease risk factors and is symptomatic with AF  rhythm-control strategy was used to manage his AF. Thus  he was also started on sotalol for rhythm-control of his AF. Along with the medication  lifestyle modifications were recommended  including a low-sodium diet and regular exercise.  Follow-up: The patient was re-evaluated after a month  and improvement was noted in his symptoms. His AF was well controlled on the sotalol  and his INR was in the therapeutic range. He was advised to continue his prescribed medication and follow-up every three months initially  with a regular check-up for his blood pressure and INR.  Conclusion: This clinical case highlights the importance of a high index of suspicion for AF  particularly in a patient with palpitations  fatigue  and known risk factors for cardiovascular disease. Here  we successfully integrated medical therapy and lifestyle modification to reach symptom and rhythm-control in a patient with AF for the prevention of potential complications  particularly  stroke.

Title: A Case of Atrial Fibrillation in an Elderly With History of Hypertension  Patient Information:   Mr. Perez  a 78-year-old Hispanic male  presented himself to the cardiology department following observations of consistent irregularities in his heartbeats. He is a retired school teacher and lives with his wife. He has been a non-smoker for 20 years and drinks alcohol occasionally.   Clinical Findings:   Mr. Perez complained of episodic palpitations  mild dizziness  and shortness of breath  especially after moderate physical activities. He denied chest pain  fainting  or any neurologic symptoms.   Past Medical History:   He was diagnosed with hypertension ten years ago and has been on antihypertensive medication  Losartan 50mg daily. He also has a history of Bell's palsy  which was treated five years back. His family history reveals that his father died of a sudden cardiac episode in his late seventies.  Diagnosis:   On physical examination  his blood pressure was found to be 150/90 mmHg  pulse rate 110 bpm  irregular  respiratory rate 20/min  and Oxygen saturation 96%. Laboratory tests were mostly within normal limit  but EKG showed irregularly irregular rhythm confirming atrial fibrillation. Two-dimensional echocardiogram showed a preserved left ventricular ejection fraction with no significant valvular disease.  Treatment:   Considering his age  hypertension  and newly diagnosed atrial fibrillation  he was started on oral anticoagulation (Warfarin) to prevent stroke and a beta blocker (Metoprolol) to control his heart rate. He was also advised to continue his antihypertensive medication.   Outcome and Follow-up:   On his follow-up visit after six weeks  his symptoms were much improved. His palpitations were less frequent  and his conditions were stabilized. His INR was in the therapeutic range  suggesting good control with Warfarin. His blood pressure was also better controlled with his current medication regimen.  Learning Points:  This case underlines the importance of paying attention to atypical symptoms in elderly patients with a history of hypertension  as they may be at risk for atrial fibrillation. Proper management with anticoagulation and rate control can significantly improve their quality of life. Anticoagulation control is vital in such cases to minimize the risk of stroke. It also emphasizes the importance of follow-up and close monitoring of these patients. Regular echocardiographic evaluation may be appropriate in managing such patients.

Case Report: Atrial Fibrillation in an Elderly Female  Introduction:  Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a common cardiovascular disorder  marked by an irregular and often rapid heart rate. This case report discusses an elderly female presenting with symptoms consistent with atrial fibrillation.   Patient Information:  The patient is an 84-year-old Caucasian female  residing in a suburban area  living independently. She is a non-smoker and reports moderate alcohol use. She has a family history of ischemic heart disease with her father having died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 64.   Clinical Findings:  The patient presents with complaints of episodic rapid heartbeat  dizziness  and palpitations  primarily during the late evening and early morning hours. The palpitations are described as irregular and “flopping” in nature. She also reports an increasing level of fatigue over the past several months  occasional light-headedness but denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncope. There is no history of recent illness  fever  or trauma.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  which is relatively well controlled with metformin. She also has mild  chronic kidney disease (CKD) and hypertension (HTN). She has been on Lisinopril for HTN  and has a documented history of intermittent AF. There is no documented history of stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA)  and she has not undergone any previous cardiovascular surgeries.   Diagnostic Focus and Assessment:  On examination  the patient was alert and coherent. Vital signs showed a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  heart rate varying between 80-130 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 16 per minute  and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. The cardiovascular examination revealed irregular rhythm with no murmurs or gallops. Lab tests including complete blood count  serum electrolytes  liver  and kidney function tests are order and awaiting results. An Electrocardiogram (ECG) confirmed atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. A referral for Transthoracic Echocardiogram (TTE) is added to evaluate the heart’s structure and function.   Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was initially managed with rate control using beta-blockers with plans to start anticoagulation therapy if needed post TTE results. She was also advised on lifestyle modifications like salt restriction to manage her hypertension and AF symptoms  along with regular monitoring of her blood sugar levels and renal function.   Conclusion:  Management of AF in elderly patients  especially with comorbidities like diabetes and CKD  requires a personalized approach. Regular follow-up and comprehensive care play a key role in overall disease control. This case emphasizes the diagnostic and therapeutic challenges encountered in the management of AF in such a complex clinical scenario.

Title: Persistent Atrial Fibrillation in a 65-Year-old Caucasian Male: A Case Report  Patient Information:   The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male from an urban setting in Northern California. He is a retired teacher  a non-smoker  and has a moderate alcohol intake. He has been struggling with obesity (BMI of 30.5) for the last 10 years.  Clinical Findings:   The patient first presented to our clinic with palpitations  shortness of breath  and intermittent dizziness  which had gradually worsened over the previous five months. There was no associated chest pain  syncope  or edema.  Diagnostic Assessment:   Initial physical examination found the patient to be normotensive (BP 130/75mmHg)  with irregular rapid pulse rate (130 bpm)  and grade II systolic murmurs. The rest of the clinical examination was unremarkable. Electrocardiogram (ECG) findings confirmed atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular rate. Blood tests (including thyroid function tests) were normal  though lipid profile displayed dyslipidemia. The patient also had elevated proBNP levels suggestive of heart strain.  A transthoracic echocardiography confirmed left atrial enlargement and exclusion of structural heart disease. A non-contrast CT brain was performed to rule out any underlying cerebrovascular event and was found normal.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia over the past 15 years. He has been on treatment with antihypertensive (lisinopril) and statins (simvastatin). There is no known history of diabetes mellitus  renal or liver diseases. The patient has a family history of ischemic heart disease.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Given the patient’s CHA2DS2-VASc score of 2 (for his age and hypertension) and HAS-BLED score of 1 (for hypertension)  a decision was made to commence anticoagulation with apixaban to prevent stroke  along with rate control using beta-blocker metoprolol  and the statin was continued for his hyperlipidemia.  Follow Up and Outcomes:  During follow-up  repeat ECG confirmed successful rate control of atrial fibrillation. The patient’s palpitations and shortness of breath had significantly improved. He has been advised regarding lifestyle modifications including a low-sodium diet  regular exercise  and weight management.  Conclusion:  The present case highlights the significance of early recognition and comprehensive management of atrial fibrillation. Regular follow-ups and lifestyle modifications play an essential role in the successful management of such cases.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. F.N. is a 73-year-old Caucasian male who presented to our ambulatory care clinic with complaints of intermittent palpitations  concomitant fatigue and slight dyspnea upon exertion for the past one month. He further noted unintentional weight loss  declining appetite  and a few instances of dizziness over the same period.   Past Medical History:  Mr. F.N has a history of hypertension for which he has been on hydrochlorothiazide for the past 10 years. He had a myocardial infarction 5 years ago  for which he underwent percutaneous coronary intervention and was placed on aspirin and atorvastatin. He also has a past history of X-linked chronic idiopathic urticaria for which regular antihistamines (fexofenadine) had been prescribed. He had a lumbar discectomy twenty years ago but has not had any further spine issues to date.   He quit smoking close to 20 years ago after a habit of 15 pack years and currently  he consumes alcohol socially. His diet is mainly comprised of home-cooked meals which he evaluates to be balanced  though he admits to indulging in high salt and high-fat foods quite often.  Family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases  with his father dying of heart failure and his brother having a non-fatal myocardial infarction. His mother was diabetic and passed away from stroke complications. He has two adult children  both of whom are hypertensive.  Personal/Social History:  Mr. F.N is a retired school teacher and lives with his wife of 45 years in a suburban environment. He is generally independent  active  and describes his mood as satisfactory. He has a history of regular exercise but has decreased this due to his recent symptoms.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  a disorganized and fast irregular pulse was recorded. Cardiovascular examination revealed irregularly irregular rhythm which was confirmed to be atrial fibrillation (AF) on 12 lead EKG. There were no signs of heart failure and respiratory auscultation was normal  as was his neurological examination.  Investigative Findings:  Laboratory tests were performed which revealed normal kidney  liver  and thyroid function. Electrolytes were all within the normal range. Full blood count showed no anemia. NT-proBNP was slightly raised  maybe suggestive of atrial enlargement secondary to chronic AF. Echocardiography showed preserved ejection fraction  no valvular disease but was indicative of mild left atrial enlargement. Holter monitor confirmed persistent AF with a mean ventricular rate around 110 beats per minute.  Diagnosis:  A calculated CHA2DS2-VASc score of 3 (hypertension  age above 65  and previous MI) identified Mr. F.N as high risk for stroke. The HAS-BLED score for bleeding risk was also deemed significant (2) due to hypertension and age above 65.   Plan:  Considering his persistent symptoms  the decision-of-care focused on a rate control approach with anticoagulation as per current guidelines. Beta-blocker (Metoprolol) was added to his medication regime for ventricular rate control. Aspirin was stopped and apixaban  a novel oral anticoagulant was initiated for stroke prevention. The importance of regular follow-ups and side effect monitoring was emphasized to the patient.  In conclusion  Mr. F.N's case represents a frequently encountered clinical profile in AF management where strategizing individual care demands striking a balance between stroke risk reduction and avoiding potential bleeding complications from anticoagulation.

Case Report: Atrial Fibrillation  Patient Information:  Mr. J  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presented to our cardiology clinic with complaints of recurrent “heart fluttering” sensations  generalized fatigue  and occasional periods of lightheadedness worsening over the past four weeks. He is a retiree with a past notable socio-economic status as a former civil engineer. He lives with his wife  has two grown-up children  and is a non-smoker  although he enjoys occasional social drinking. There is a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his late father suffering from coronary artery disease and his sister currently managing hypertension and type 2 diabetes.  Medical History:  Mr. J has a history of stage 2 hypertension which has been controlled with amlodipine for the past 10 years  hyperlipidemia managed with atorvastatin and well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with metformin and lifestyle adjustment for the past 7 years. He had no history of hospitalization or surgery. His BMI is within the expected range for his age and he maintains a regular exercise regimen. Other vaccinations and routine preventative health measures are noted to be up to date. He has no known allergies.   Current Medication:  1. Amlodipine 10mg daily for hypertension 2. Atorvastatin 20mg daily for hyperlipidemia 3. Metformin 500mg twice daily for type II diabetes  Clinical Findings:  A physical examination found Mr. J to be alert and oriented. His blood pressure was slightly elevated at 140/90 mmHg  with a rapid and irregular pulse rate averaging about 110 beats per minute. Further cardiovascular evaluation showed irregularly irregular heart rhythm  suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Lung and abdominal examination were otherwise unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Given the physical examination findings  an electrocardiogram was immediately performed which confirmed the suspected paroxysmal atrial fibrillation without rapid ventricular response. A transthoracic echocardiography was conducted which did not reveal any significant structural heart abnormalities. His routine blood tests results were within normal limits except for slightly elevated HbA1c and lipid profile.   Therapeutic Intervention:  Following his diagnosis  he was started on a beta-blocker  metoprolol (50mg once daily)  to control his heart rate and reduce his symptoms. In addition  given his new onset of atrial fibrillation and CHA_2DS_2-VASC score of 3  he was also started on anticoagulation therapy with apixaban (5mg twice daily) to prevent stroke.  Discussion:  This case highlights the essential entity of atrial fibrillation encountered in a primary care setting. Regular follow-ups are scheduled for Mr. J to monitor his clinical signs and symptoms  adherence to medication  essential laboratory parameters  and potential side effects.  Patient consent was obtained for publishing the case details.

Title: Management of Atrial Fibrillation in an Elderly Male Patient with Comorbidities  Introduction: Mr. X  a 78-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the out-patient department complaining of palpitations  intermittent episodes of chest discomfort  and fatigue for the past two months. A retired civil engineer  he is a non-smoker and rarely consumes alcohol.  Past Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (DM) approximately 10 years ago and had also been treated for moderate Hypertension (HTN) for the last 15 years. He is regularly taking Metformin 500mg two times daily for diabetes and Losartan 50mg once daily for hypertension. He had suffered a transient ischemic attack (TIA) seven years ago  which did not result in significant sequelae owing to prompt treatment.   Presenting Symptoms: He reported an abnormal feeling in his heart  which he described as 'fluttering' or 'pounding ' often accompanied by dizziness and mild shortness of breath. He also stated his fatigue was progressively worsening  affecting his daily activities. Occasionally  he experienced chest tightness not related to physical effort. He denied symptoms of syncope  orthopnea  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.   Clinical Findings: On examination  pulse rate was found to be irregularly irregular with a rate of 90-110 bpm  and blood pressure was 140/85 mm Hg. Cardiovascular examination revealed irregular heart rhythms with no murmurs. Lung auscultation and abdominal examination were normal.   Investigations:  An Electrocardiogram (EKG) showed atrial fibrillation (AF) with a variable ventricular response. His blood tests  including complete blood count  renal function test  and liver function test  were within normal range. Glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) was slightly elevated to 7.2%. Echocardiography showed normal left ventricular function with no valvular abnormalities.  Management: The patient was diagnosed with Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation (PAF). Due to the presence of AF alongside comorbidities  the CHA2DS2-VASc score was calculated as 4  putting the patient at high risk of stroke. The patient was started on Rivaroxaban (anticoagulant) to mitigate this risk. Rate control was achieved by adding a beta-blocker (Metoprolol) to his medication regime.   Follow-up:  Mr. X is currently under regular monthly follow-ups and is noted to have improved symptomatically. His AF is well controlled on medication  and he is being closely monitored for potential complications and any adverse effects of the medication.  Conclusion: This case highlights the management of AF in a patient with comorbidities. It emphasizes the importance of risk stratification for stroke in AF using the CHA2DS2-VASc score and the need for stringent control of DM and HTN  which are proactive steps to prevent cardiovascular complications. Regular follow-ups and patient education are critical aspects of management.

Case Report: Atrial Fibrillation in a 75-Year-Old Male  Patient Profile: Mr. X is a 75-year-old Caucasian male residing in suburban United States. He has retired from his profession as an engineer and lives with his wife. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol moderately. His diet is rich in fats and carbohydrates with minimal physical activity.   Presenting Condition: Mr. X presented at the emergency department with complaint of palpitations and discomfort in his chest which had been ongoing for several hours. He also reported episodes of feeling light-headed and short of breath. These symptoms had not been present prior to this event.  Past Medical History: Mr. X has been managing his hypertension for the last ten years. He has also been treated for hypercholesterolemia and Type 2 diabetes for nearly five years. He has undergone a knee replacement surgery approximately ten years ago. His father passed away at 82 with ischemic heart disease and his mother died at 79 of stroke. He has no history of allergies.   Physical Examination and Diagnosis: Upon examination  irregular heartbeats with a fast pulse rate was detected. Blood pressure was slightly elevated. Mr. X appeared anxious but was well-oriented. An electrocardiogram (ECG) was conducted which showed irregular  rapid atrial waves consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF). There was no evidence of other structural heart diseases. A transthoracic echocardiogram confirmed the absence of valvular heart disease.  Hospital Course: Mr. X was admitted to the cardiology department. He was started on beta-blockers to manage heart rate  low dose aspirin for thromboprophylaxis  and statins for cholesterol. Anticoagulation therapy was considered  but given his age and the risks associated  it was not initiated. His blood glucose levels were also monitored and managed with his regular medication. Regular ECGs were carried out to monitor his heart rhythm.   Mr. X responded well to the treatment and his heart rate gradually returned to normal over the course of his hospital stay. He showed no further symptoms of light-headedness or shortness of breath.   Discharge and Follow-up: Prior to discharge  Mr. X and his wife were educated about atrial fibrillation  its implications  management  and the need for adherence to medication. Regular outpatient follow-ups were scheduled for the management of hypertension  diabetes  and hypercholesterolemia. Mr. X was also recommended dietary modifications and a regular walking regimen. He was encouraged to seek immediate medical help in case of recurrence of palpitations or any new symptoms.  In conclusion  the case of Mr. X emphasizes the importance of diligent treatment and management of risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes  and hypercholesterolemia  particularly in the older population  to prevent the occurrence and recurrence of atrial fibrillation.

Patient Information: Name: A.B. Gender: Male Age: 78 years Height: 170 cm Weight: 78 kg Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired – Former Engineer Residential Area: Urban  Presenting Complaint:  The patient came to the hospital  citing recurrent episodes of heart palpitations  increased fatigue  and shortness of breath over the last two months.  Medical History:  The patient has a medical history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus type II  and hypercholesterolemia. He was on Losartan 50mg  once daily for hypertension  Metformin 500mg twice daily for diabetes  and Atorvastatin 20mg  once daily for hypercholesterolemia.  There was no known family history of heart diseases. The patient was a former smoker who quit 10 years ago and no known allergies have been reported.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  the patient showed signs of irregularly irregular pulses and unsustained pedal edema. His blood pressure was 145/90mmHg  he had a pulse rate of 110/min  which varied at rest  gradient 95-115 bpm and regular respiratory rate of 16 breaths/minute.  Investigations:  A 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) was conducted which showed ventricular irregular rhythm  absence of P wave  and presence of f waves (flutter waves)  suggesting atrial fibrillation.  The blood panel spikes concern for renal and liver function  indicating slightly elevated urea and creatinine levels. Lipid profile was also abnormal referring to the already known hypercholesterolemia. Hemoglobin A1c was 7.8%  indicating poor control of diabetes. An echocardiogram  on the other hand  showed normal left ventricular function and no significant valve disease. There were no thrombi seen in the atria.  Diagnosis:  Based on his clinical presentation and ECG results  a diagnosis of non-valvular atrial fibrillation was made.  Management:  The management included rate control  anticoagulation  and potentially rhythm control. Metoprolol 50mg once daily was added to his drug regimen for rate control under close monitoring of blood pressure and heart rate. For stroke prophylaxis  considering his age  comorbidities  and CHA2DS2-VASc score of 4  oral anticoagulation was started with Apixaban 5mg twice daily. Blood sugar control and lipid profile correction required Titration of Metformin and Atorvastatin dose in upcoming follow-ups.  Follow-up:  Patient education and self-monitoring are key components for this treatment plan. A regular follow-up plan was scheduled  with periodic checks on his cardiac rhythm  renal function  and liver function as well. He was advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle  increase physical activity  manage weight  quit alcohol  and follow dietary restrictions.   This case highlights the importance of recognizing the symptoms of atrial fibrillation in a patient with risk factors  as early diagnosis can significantly influence the patient's prognosis.
