Family Medical History: He has a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 65 and his older brother has clinical congestive heart failure.  Social History: He lives with his wife and has a supportive network of family and friends. He used to be a heavy smoker  with a 30-pack-year history  but quit smoking 15 years ago. He drinks alcohol in social settings only.   Allergies: He has no known drug or food allergies.  Medications: Amlodipine 5mg OD  Metformin 500mg BD  and Aspirin 75mg OD.  On further enquiry  he recalled having episodes of irregular heartbeat occasionally in the past  but never sought medical attention as it was asymptomatic. No previous history of syncope or falls. He remains compliant to his medication and follows a regular exercise regimen.    This case report would then lead to instructing students to suspect atrial fibrillation given the intermittent palpitations  shortness of breath  and history of essential hypertension and TIA. Further focused physical examination and ECG will confirm this diagnosis.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:   The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired  living independently with supportive family in the region.   Past Medical History:   He is a former smoker with a history of long-standing hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which are well-managed with daily prescribed medications (lisinopril 20mg for hypertension and atorvastatin 40mg for hyperlipidemia). He gave up smoking approximately 20 years ago and was moderate alcohol consumer. Patient has a history of occasional episodes of palpitations but did not seek medical attention for them. No known allergies are documented. Additionally  the patient has no history of surgeries or transfusions.   Key Complaints:   The patient came to the emergency department complaining of sudden-onset palpitations that were more intense and sustained than his previous episodes  associated with fatigue and light-headedness. He also reported experiencing occasional bouts of breathlessness which he initially attributed to his age. He denied other symptoms such as chest pain  syncope  or leg swelling. There was no recent history of infection  fever or any change in behavioral or motor function. No family history of atrial fibrillation or any other heart disorders was reported.

Patient Information:   Mr. John Smith  a 73-year-old Caucasian male who resides in an urban community and is retired from his job in finance. He lives alone but is still socially active in his community. He is a former smoker  having quit 20 years ago  has a history of moderate alcohol consumption  and is committed to a daily walking regimen.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed with regular medication including a thiazide diuretic and statin for the past 15 years. He also has a history of occasional gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)  managed with over-the-counter antacids. There is no family history of any major heart diseases  but his mother had a stroke at the age of 79. Mr. Smith has no known drug allergies and has had no previous surgeries or hospitalizations. In general  he has always been proactive about his healthcare  having regular check-ups and follow-ups with his primary care physician.  Key Complaints:  Recently  Mr. Smith has been complaining of episodes of palpitations  intermittent dizziness  and fatigue  particularly when engaging in his daily walking regimen  symptoms that he hasn't experienced before. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or syncope. He claims to have had more episodes of palpitations and fatigue over the past 2 weeks. His sleep patterns have been disturbed due to anxiety over these recent health concerns. He felt these symptoms warranted a visit to the doctor out of fear that these are symptoms of a serious condition.   This case presents the typical patient picture of atrial fibrillation  with an older patient experiencing palpitations and fatigue. The medical students examining this case should consider the patient's age  history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and new symptoms. They should be guided toward obtaining an EKG and evaluating for atrial fibrillation. It would be beneficial to discuss the pathophysiology of atrial fibrillation and its management  particularly in the context of this patient's personal health history. The objective should be to have students recognize atrial fibrillation  understand its account  manage the condition  and anticipate potential complications such as stroke and heart failure. They should also understand the need for potential anticoagulation therapy.

Patient Information:  Mr. James Thompson  a 69-year-old Caucasian male  retired banker  non-smoker  with a moderate alcohol intake.  Chief Complaints:  He presented with a 3-day history of palpitations  breathlessness on exertion  and occasional dizziness.  Past Medical History: He has been hypertensive for the past ten years  maintained on Lisinopril. He was diagnosed with Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus five years ago  managed with Metformin. His lipid profile is also elevated  for which he is on Atorvastatin. He has no known allergies. Family history is remarkable for cardiovascular disease  with his father dying of myocardial infarction at the age of 72.  Current Medications: - Lisinopril 20 mg once daily - Metformin 500 mg twice daily - Atorvastatin 40 mg once daily  Physical Examination: On examination  he appears uncomfortable due to palpitations. His pulse is irregularly irregular  heart rate varying between 110–170 bpm  and blood pressure is 150/95 mmHg. Cardiovascular examination reveals an irregular rhythm.  Investigations to Order: - Complete blood count - Biochemistry (including renal function and HbA1c) - EKG (suspecting atrial fibrillation based on history and irregular pulse) - Transthoracic echocardiogram  - Thyroid function test  Possible Diagnoses: Based on his symptoms  history  and physical exam  the student should be led towards suspecting atrial fibrillation. Underlying causal factors such as hyperthyroidism  electrolyte imbalance  and pulmonary pathologies should be considered.  Management Plan: - Acute management for rate and rhythm control (Beta-blockers or Calcium channel blockers or Amiodarone) - Chronic management using anticoagulants for stroke prevention  considering the patient's age and comorbidities. - Lifestyle modifications addressing alcohol consumption  balanced nutritious diet  and regular moderate exercises.    Follow up/Continuity of Care: Regular follow-ups should be advised to monitor the treatment plan's efficacy and make necessary adjustments  if required. Regular monitoring of blood sugar  blood pressure  cholesterol  renal function  and INR (if started on Warfarin) should be emphasized. Also  stress the importance of adherence to medications and follow up appointments.   This case aims at teaching students about atrial fibrillation's presentation  interpretation of EKG  formulating differential diagnoses  prioritizing investigations  and appropriate management plans.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Mr. Edwin Barnes  a 68-year-old Caucasian male; retired teacher  widower  living independently.  Past Medical History: Mr. Barnes has history of long-standing hypertension for which he takes ramipril. There's also a history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus that's well-managed with metformin and lifestyle modifications. Smoked pack a day for 20 years but quit at age 50. No family history of cardiac disease. No prior diagnosis of heart disease. No previous surgical interventions.  Key Complaints: Mr. Barnes presented to the hospital's emergency unit with sudden onset palpitations  mild shortness of breath  and general fatigue that started about 6 hours prior to presentation. He denies chest pain  dizziness  syncope  fever  or productive cough. Noted that he was unable to carry out light activities which he was previously able to do  such as walking up the stairs to his apartment. He also reported unintentional weight loss over the past 2 months. He rated his symptoms as progressively worsening over the last few weeks.  The overall aim of the case is for the student to make comprehensive assessments of the symptoms presented  and through a guided learning process  diagnose the patient with atrial fibrillation. Additionally  the student should form a management plan  considering the patient's existing health conditions and lifestyle.

Case Report:   Patient Information:   Mr. John Doe  a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a significant history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2 and hyperlipidemia  presented to the clinic. He is a retired teacher  non-smoker and a moderate consumer of alcohol. Mr. Doe lives with his wife and they have two adult children.   Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension - diagnosed 8 years ago  remains fairly controlled on medication (losartan 50mg once daily).  2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus - diagnosed 10 years ago  glycosylated hemoglobin last recorded as 7.2%. Patient is under insulin regimen of 30 units per day.   3. Hyperlipidemia - diagnosed 5 years ago  adequately managed on statin-therapy (atorvastatin 20mg daily).   Additional Context:  The patient had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) about four years ago  with full recovery and no residual deficits. He has been on low dose aspirin since then.   Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Doe reports a 3-week history of symptoms including occasional palpitations  initial insomnia  fatigue  mild shortness of breath particularly on exertion and episodes of lightheadedness. He denies chest pain  nausea  sweating or fainting.   Evaluation:  On examination  his blood pressure is 142/85 mmHg  pulse - 130bpm and irregular  respiratory rate- 16 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation- 95% at room air.   Initial interpretation:  The irregular  rapid pulse may suggest atrial fibrillation. The next step should be an electrocardiogram to confirm the diagnosis. His previous TIA increases his risk  and the recent onset of symptoms indicate the urgent need to manage his unstable arrhythmia  control his ventricular rate  and potentially  prevent a stroke. His management must include addressing his modifiable risk factors as well.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. Robert Murdock  Caucasian  Male  Age 74  retired university professor living with wife in downtown suburb. No history of smoking or substance use. Balanced diet and maintained regular moderate physical activity.  Past Medical History: Hypertension for the past 20 years and Diabetes Mellitus Type II for the last 10 years  both treated with medication. Diagnosed with mild Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease five years ago  prescribed inhaler. His father and one brother had a history of coronary heart disease.  Key Complaints: Robert visited his GP two days back complaining of occasional chest discomfort  palpitations  mild lightheadedness that has been prolonged the last few weeks. He experienced episodes of breathlessness during his daily walking routine which is unusual for him. His wife reported an episode wherein Robert seemed confused for a while. No complaints of fever  cough  or swelling in the legs. Denies any trauma  significant stress  or recent changes in diet or medications.  Revision History: The patient shows well-controlled blood sugar and blood pressure levels. Pharmacologic therapy includes Metformin  Lisinopril  and Tiotropium bromide. Additionally  LDL cholesterol levels are marginally high. His influenza vaccine is up to date and received pneumococcal vaccine a year ago.  Examination and Investigations: On examination  he was afebrile  blood pressure was 130/85mmHg  respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute. There were irregular beats without any murmurs on cardiac auscultation. The chest was bilaterally clear on auscultation  though slightly reduced breath sounds. No peripheral edema was present. EKG findings confirmed the symptoms to be atrial fibrillation.  Consideration: Given his age  comorbidities  symptoms  and EKG findings  he was referred to a cardiologist for further management.  Teaching Objectives: Patient-centered management of atrial fibrillation involving rate control  rhythm control  and anticoagulation to prevent thromboembolic events. Recognize and address the potential underlying causes  risk stratification and modify the lifestyle factors contributing to atrial fibrillation. To understand the long-term consequences of the condition and to evaluate appropriate treatment protocols.

Case Report: Atrial Fibrillation   Patient Information: Name: Mr. James Allen Age: 65 years old Gender: Male  Occupation: Retired school teacher Ethnicity: Caucasian  Past Medical History: Mr. Allen has Type II diabetes and high blood pressure  which are controlled through medication. He has been a smoker for the past 30 years and admitted to occasional alcohol use. His father died at the age of 70 due to a myocardial infarction  and his mother  currently 89 years old  has chronic heart failure.   Chief Complaints: Mr. Allen visited the clinic complaining of increasing episodes of feeling a rapid and irregular heartbeat over the last few weeks  which he describes as 'fluttering' in his chest  and general fatigue. In the last week  he experienced occasional episodes of lightheadedness and shortness of breath  especially during mild physical activities like walking his dog. He denies any chest pain  fainting episodes  or fluid retention.   During the visit  an initial examination reveals a heart rate of 140 beats per minute and an irregular rhythm  while the remainder of the physical examination is within normal limits.   Instruction for Medical Students: The medical history and presenting symptoms suggest a diagnosis of Atrial Fibrillation (AF). AF is the most common type of irregular heart rhythm and it can lead to major health complications like stroke and heart failure if not properly managed. In this case  risk factors include the patient's age  hypertension  type II diabetes  smoking history  and family history of heart failure and myocardial infarction. Further diagnostic workup including an EKG  echocardiogram  and blood tests should be considered. Please develop a differential diagnosis and discuss the most effective management strategies for Mr. Allen.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:   Mr. Alfred  a 72-year-old retired school teacher of Caucasian descent  resides with his wife in their home in suburban Nashville. He was an active smoker until his mid-50s  having smoked about a pack a day for around 30 years. He occasionally drinks alcohol.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Alfred has been diagnosed with hypertension at the age of 60  for which he was prescribed hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily. He is also known to have Type 2 diabetes  well-controlled on metformin 500mg twice a day. He had a stroke 5 years ago and has made a good recovery; as a result  he has been placed on low-dose aspirin daily. His family history includes a father with ischemic heart disease who died from an acute myocardial infarction in his mid-seventies.   Key Complaints:   Mr. Alfred visits his doctor with complaints of occasional palpitations over the last few weeks  more noticeable in the past 2 days. He also mentions intermittent breathlessness while doing daily chores  difficulty sleeping and an episode of lightheadedness. Previously  he was able to walk around the block thrice a day without any noticeable symptoms. He denies any chest pain or discomfort  history of syncope  or any upper or lower limb weakness.   The training case thus focuses on the poignant issue of atrial fibrillation  a common arrhythmia  especially in the geriatric age group which could confer significant morbidity especially in the presence of other cardiovascular risk factors. It is also an opportunity to discuss the importance of stroke prevention and management in the setting of atrial fibrillation.

Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 67 years old Gender: Male Occupation: Retired Engineer Race: Caucasian  Insurance: Medicare  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension for 10 years 2. Type II Diabetes Mellitus  3. Mild Asthma 4. Occasional alcohol intake  Present History: Mr. John Doe presents to the clinic with complaints of intermittent palpitations for the past two weeks. He describes it as a sensation of his heart ""racing"" and ""fluttering"" within his chest. He also reports experiencing intermittent episodes of lightheadedness over the same time period. He denies any chest pain or discomfort  shortness of breath  or loss of consciousness. He has been adherent to his antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications. There are no known drug allergies.  Physical Examination: Mr. Doe is alert and oriented. His vitals are: BP: 140/90 mmHg  Heart rate varying between 80-140/min with irregular rhythm  Respiratory rate: 18/min  Temperature: 98.2°F  Oxygen saturation: 98% on room air. Cardiovascular examination reveals an irregularly irregular pulse and no murmurs.  The patient's risk factors  age  and clinical features are indicative of a possible atrial fibrillation. Education and training around this case can focus on diagnosis (including ECG)  treatment options  and management in the context of this patient's individual medical history and current symptoms.

Patient Demographics:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 68 Years Sex: Male  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired High School Math Teacher Location: Urban Suburb  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a history of Type-2 diabetes mellitus which has been controlled with Metformin (1000mg OD) for the past eight years. He also has hypertension  controlled with Lisinopril (20mg OD)  for the same duration. A history of smoking 1 pack/day for 30 years  although now quit for 10 years. No known drug allergies.  Key Complaints: Mr. Doe presented to the cardiology clinic with complaints of intermittent palpitations and unusual fatigue for the past two weeks  which are new symptoms. He denied chest pain  dyspnea but reports noticing an occasional irregular heartbeat. He has not experienced any syncope or pre-syncope  but reports concern due to his increased fatigue interfering with his daily walks in the park. He also noticed increased frequency of nocturia.   Vitals: BP: 150/90 mm Hg Pulse: Irregularly irregular  100 beats/min BMI: 30 kg/m2  Stay tuned for the physical examination  relevant investigations  preliminary diagnosis  and management plan.

Patient Case:   Name: Mr. John Peters Age: 65 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer  Past Medical History:  Mr. Peters has a medical history of hypertension for the past ten years  well-controlled on amlodipine 5mg daily and lisinopril 10mg daily. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago  treated with metformin 500mg twice daily and moderate lifestyle changes. He has no known history of cardiac diseases  stroke  or kidney diseases. He has a 20-pack year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. He denies any history of alcohol abuse or illicit substance use.   Key Complaints:  Upon presenting to the ER  Mr. Peters complained of sudden onset palpitations  which he describes as a rapid  irregular heartbeat that started six hours prior. He also reports feeling lightheadedness  mild breathlessness  and general weakness but denies angina  syncope  or any other symptoms. The symptoms persisted  which caused him to seek immediate medical attention.  He denies having experienced these symptoms before.   This is a simple  straightforward case that introduces clinical features that indicate atrial fibrillation  including palpitations  lightheadedness  and shortness of breath. The patient's medical history is useful for pointing out common risk factors  like hypertension and type 2 diabetes. This case helps promote discussion and learning around atrial fibrillation - its pathophysiology  diagnosis  acute and long term management.

Case Report: Atrial Fibrillation   Patient Information Patient Name: Smith  John Gender: Male Age: 72 years old Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer  Past Medical History -John has a past medical history significant for hypertension which is well-controlled on Losartan 50mg daily. -He has a moderate lifestyle  with limited physical activity  and is a non-smoker. -There’s a family history of cardiovascular diseases: father diagnosed with ischemic heart disease and mother with hypertension. -John has no allergies and takes no other medication at the moment.  Presenting Complaints John presents to the clinic complaining of feeling his heart racing occasionally over the past week. He describes these episodes as moments when he could ""feel his heart fluttering in his chest"". The episodes last for about 1-2 minutes and then subside on their own. He denies any associated chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncope.  Observations: Heart rate of 98 bpm and irregularly irregular rhythm  BP 128/80 mmHg  Body-mass index 25 kg/m2  cardiovascular examination shows no heart murmur  jugular venous pressure is not elevated and there is no pedal edema.  This training case focuses on atrial fibrillation  a common cardiac arrhythmia often identified by irregularly irregular rhythm  typically associated with heart rate changes  palpitations  dyspnea or fatigue  or identified incidentally. The case is designed to provide students with a basic understanding of the disease process  diagnostic procedures  treatment modalities  and the importance of patient history and physical exam. It should also elaborate on health promotion  patient education and disease management.

Case Report: Atrial Fibrillation   Patient Demographics: - Gender: Male - Age: 70 - Race: Caucasian  - Occupation: Retired engineer  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of mild hypertension  controlled with a daily dose of 5mg of Amlodipine. He is a non-smoker and maintains a balanced diet. The patient also possesses a family history of cardiovascular disease - his father had a stroke at an age of 75. No known allergies or other significant illnesses reported.  Chief Complaints: The patient came into the clinic with chief complaints of palpitations and occasional mild shortness of breath for the last two weeks. He highlights these symptoms get aggravated after mild physical activity such as short walks. The patient reports no chest pain  dizziness  or syncope. He also has not noticed any noticeable patterns to when the palpitations occur but says they come on suddenly without apparent triggers.  As the case is presented to the medical students  the key points to be clarified are risk factors and appreciating the irregularity of atrial fibrillation. Evaluating symptoms will help to direct treatment and assess the urgency for cardioversion. After understanding the case  students should be able to appreciate findings on physical examination and electrocardiogram in relation to atrial fibrillation. Following studies include thyroid function  transthoracic echocardiogram  among others  based on clinical stability. This case provides a foundation for the clinical approach to atrial fibrillation; every step must be focused on measurable outcomes  keeping in mind the patient's lifestyle factors and comorbid conditions.

Case Report  Patient Demographics:   - Name: Mr. John Miller - Age: 73 years old - Sex: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired engineer  Past Medical History:  - Hypertension for the last 15 years  managed by calcium channel blockers - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  managed with metformin - Had an ischemic stroke two years ago with good recovery - Ex-smoker and has a social history of occasional alcohol consumption   Chief Complaints:  Mr. Miller presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset palpitations which began approximately two hours prior to his arrival. He described the feeling akin to his ""heart racing"". He also admitted to feeling weakness and increased fatigue over the past 2-3 days. No chest pain  shortness of breath  dizziness or syncope was reported. No symptoms of a cold  flu  or any recent illness were reported.  Physical assessment showed slightly elevated blood pressure and an irregular  rapid pulse. EKG was performed confirming atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. His blood glucose was slightly elevated (215 mg/dL) and INR was 1.1.   This case provides an opportunity to discuss atrial fibrillation its symptoms  risk factors  and management strategies. It also emphasizes the importance of managing concomitant conditions such as hypertension and diabetes which themselves are risk factors for developing atrial fibrillation. The case also gives students a chance to consider the implications of atrial fibrillation in patients who have had a prior ischemic stroke  including the potential requirement for anticoagulation therapy.

Patient Details:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 72 Gender: Male Occupation: Retired Ethnicity: Caucasian  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a documented history of Hypertension controlled with medication (Lisinopril 20mg daily) for the past 10 years. He also has Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus managed with Metformin 1000mg twice daily for the last 5 years. He was diagnosed with Hyperlipidemia for which he takes Simvastatin 20mg once a day. No history of any cardiac disorders. He is a former smoker and quit 8 years ago.   Presenting Complaints: Mr. Doe visited his general practitioner's clinic complaining of frequent fatigue and palpitations which have been persisting for the last two weeks. He also mentioned episodes of breathlessness upon exertion  light headedness  and occasionally feeling like he is about to faint. His symptoms seem to come and go and can last for a few hours to a few days. He denied chest pain  cough  fever  or any gastrointestinal symptoms.   This case report suggests that these are the symptoms of atrial fibrillation  a common cardiac arrhythmia  particularly amongst the elderly population. The student's task would be to complete the patient evaluation and make the appropriate diagnosis and treatment plans. This would involve asking more about the characteristics and timing of symptoms  as well as triggers and relieving factors. The student should think about what physical examination procedures to perform  what investigations (such as cervical obliteration test  echocardiogram  EKG) are indicated  and how to interpret these. They would also need to take into account the patient's comorbidities when deciding on a management plan.

Patient Profile: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 68 years old Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Doe presented to the clinic with complaints of persistent palpitations  occasional shortness of breath especially after light physical activity  and fatigue over the past 3 weeks. He also mentioned experiencing light-headedness on a few occasions but denied any syncope.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe is known to have hypertension and hyperlipidemia over the past 10 years. He has been regularly taking his medications  which consist of amlodipine 5mg daily  lisinopril 20mg daily  and atorvastatin 10mg at night. Mr. Doe has quit smoking for the past 15 years  he was a 20 pack-year smoker before quitting. He rarely drinks alcohol  only during social events  and denies any illicit drug use.  Mr. Doe had a myocardial infarction 8 years ago which was managed with the placement of a drug-eluting stent. He completed cardiac rehabilitation and has been compliant with his dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel) and other medications without any cardiac issues since then.   Family History: Father passed away at the age of 74 due to a heart attack. Mother passed away at 80 due to stroke. He has a younger brother who is currently alive and has Type II diabetes.  Social History: He lives with his wife in the suburbs. He is a dog-owner and enjoys taking daily walks in the park. He is physically active and frequently volunteers at a local community center.  Review of systems was otherwise negative.   These synthesised patient complaints and histories should be useful in comprehending the case further.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mrs. Marcia Johnston Age: 72 Gender: Female Race: White Occupation: Retired Teacher Marital Status: Widowed  Past Medical History: Mrs. Johnston has a history of hypertension  controlled with medication (Lisinopril 10 mg once daily). She was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 5 years ago  managed with diet  exercise  and Metformin. The patient previously also reported occasional heartburn for which she self-medicates with a proton pump inhibitor.  Key Presenting Complaints:  Mrs. Johnston has been recently experiencing increasing episodes of palpitations with associated fatigue and breathlessness. These episodes have been associated with mild dizziness  but no syncope. She mentions the symptoms are more pronounced when she manually engages in activities like gardening or taking stairs. Recently  she also noted waking up at night due to difficulty in breathing.  Additional Note: She is a non-smoker  limits her alcohol intake to moderate consumption only on special occasions  and lives with her older daughter and her family. She has a family history of cardiac diseases; her father died due to a myocardial infarction and her younger brother has been diagnosed with ischemic heart disease.   This case should be designed to lead students into a discussion on atrial fibrillation- its causes  symptoms  diagnostic tests  complications  and treatment modalities. In Mrs. Johnston's case  her age  history of diabetes  hypertension  and family history of cardiac diseases are potential risk factors for atrial fibrillation.

Case Report: Atrial Fibrillation  Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe   Age: 76   Gender: Male   Race: Caucasian   Past Medical History: Hypertension  Type-2 Diabetes  previous Myocardial Infarction (5 years ago)   Family History: Mother diagnosed with Atrial Fibrillation at age 70  Chief Complaint:    The patient presents with a three-day history of palpitations with an irregular rhythm  occasional light-headedness  and fatigue. He also reports experiencing dyspnea on exertion. The patient denies chest pain  syncope  or presyncope. His symptoms have been growing progressively worse over the past three days. There have been no previous similar episodes.  Social History:   Mr. Doe is a former smoker; he quit 20 years ago. He consumes alcohol infrequently and has a diet controlled for his Type-2 Diabetes. He is retired and lives with his wife. He is physically active  taking part in regular walks and light gardening.  Medications:  1. Metformin 500mg twice a day (Type-2 Diabetes) 2. Lisinopril 10mg once a day (Hypertension) 3. Aspirin 81 mg daily (Post Myocardial Infarction) 4. Atorvastatin 20mg once a day (Hyperlipidemia)  Review of systems: The patient denies any symptoms of fever  cough  night sweats  GI symptoms  or any other significant discomfort. Physical Examination: BP - 130/85 mmHg  HR - irregular and ranging between 90-130 bpm  RR - 18/min  and Temp - 98.6°F.  This case can be used to discuss the background  pathophysiology  diagnosis  and management of atrial fibrillation  providing students the opportunity to gain a comprehensive understanding of this common cardiac condition.

Case Report:  Demographics: Mr. A  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired high school teacher  currently living alone in an urban area. He is a non-smoker with a history of moderate alcohol consumption.  Past Medical History: He has a known medical history of hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  both under control with medication - Metformin 1g BID for diabetes  and Amlodipine 5mg daily for hypertension. He also suffers from mild obesity (BMI 31). There is no documented history of hyperthyroidism  lung disease  or any genetic disorder. He experienced a mild ischemic stroke two years back with good recovery.  Key Complaints: Mr. A visited the clinic with chief complaints of irregular heartbeats  intermittent periods of breathlessness  and fatigue for the past few weeks. He mentioned occasional episodes of dizziness and chest discomfort. He says he feels vibrations or fluttering in his chest and this has been making him anxious. He has noticed his pulse skips a beat  and occasionally  there is rapid beating. He has also noticed these symptoms become worse during physical efforts or stressful situations.  This case is pointing towards the potential diagnosis of atrial fibrillation based on his symptoms of irregular heartbeats  palpitations  breathlessness  and his age  but further investigations like ECG  echocardiography  and blood tests would be needed to confirm.

Case Report: Atrial Fibrillation  Patient Demographics:  The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. J. He is a retired university professor and is currently residing with his wife in the suburban area. He is a non-smoker and does not drink alcohol. He has a known history of hypertension.  Past Medical History:  Mr. J has been on antihypertensive drugs for 20 years and has been able to manage his blood pressure relatively well. He had one episode of transient ischemic attack (TIA) 5 years back but recovered fully without any residual neurological deficits.  Five years ago  he was diagnosed with congestive heart failure  currently managed with ACE inhibitors and regular follow-ups. He also has Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which is generally controlled with metformin and a regular diet plan. There is no known personal or family history of hyperlipidemia  myocardial infarction  or stroke.  Key Complaints:  Mr. J presented to the clinic with complaints of palpitations  intermittent chest discomfort  and shortness of breath  especially during mild physical exertion. These symptoms started about two weeks back and have been gradually increasing in intensity. Additionally  he feels more fatigued than usual and the most distressing symptom for him is the irregular and rapid heartbeat which seems like fluttering in his chest. There has been no syncopal episode or history of sudden falls.  He also noticed an unexplained weight gain and often wakes up breathless at night. Despite medication  his blood pressure has been consistently high for the last couple of weeks.   In this case study  medical students need to understand the presenting complaints  relate them with Mr. J’s past medical history  and develop a diagnostic approach for his condition  which potentially looks like Atrial Fibrillation  a common cardiac rhythm disorder in adults. They will have to think about the investigations needed  and propose treatment options for managing his condition effectively  taking into account his comorbidities.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. Smith is a 67-year-old Caucasian male who works as a retired civil servant and is generally in good health.  Past Medical History: He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus (well-controlled with metformin)  mild hypertension (controlled with lisinopril)  and hyperlipidemia (treated with atorvastatin). He has a history of moderate alcohol consumption but quit drinking alcohol 10 years ago. He has no known drug allergies. His mother had a history of cardiovascular disease  but he has no history or symptoms suggestive of coronary heart disease. He is a non-smoker.  Key complaints: Mr. Smith went for a regular appointment with his GP (General Practitioner) when he mentioned experiencing occasional palpitations for the last few months. He does not report any chest pain  shortness of breath  or dizziness. However  he mentioned feeling fatigued more easily lately. The GP observed his pulse rate to be irregularly irregular and referred him for further assessment due to suspicion of atrial fibrillation.   Discussion: This case presents the clinical scenario of a patient with possible atrial fibrillation (AF)  which is the most common sustained cardiac arrhythmia. The fluctuating symptoms reported by the patient such as the palpitations and fatigue  coupled with an ""irregularly irregular"" rhythm felt on pulse examination  are classic signs of AF.  The medical history of diabetes  hypertension  and family history of cardiovascular disease put Mr. Smith at a higher risk of developing AF. Diagnosis depends on catching an episode on an EKG  which makes it challenging to diagnose if the episodes are brief or infrequent.  This case provides an excellent opportunity to discuss the clinical features  diagnostic methods  and subsequent management options of atrifact  including lifestyle changes  rate and rhythm management  and anticoagulation to mitigate stroke risk.  The patient does not exhibit symptoms of any acute complications such as a stroke or heart failure  suggesting it could be a case of non-valvular atrial fibrillation. Therefore  recognition and prompt referral for comprehensive management including stroke prevention is essential.

Case Report: Atrial Fibrillation  Patient Demographics:  Mr. Jackson  a 68-year-old African American male.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Jackson has been diagnosed with hypertension for the last 12 years  well-controlled with medications. Five years ago  he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus  which is also under control with oral hypoglycemic. He is a former smoker with a smoking history of 30 pack years but no alcohol or drug use. His family history reveals cardiovascular disease in his father and brother.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Jackson presents to the emergency department complaining about racing heartbeats for the last two days. He additionally reports feeling lightheaded and has experienced one episode of fainting. He also complains of intermittent chest discomfort and unusual fatigue even at rest. He denies any pain in other parts of his body  and there is no indication of difficulty breathing  nausea  vomiting  or sweating.

Case Report: Atrial Fibrillation  Patient Information: - 75-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer.  - Lives at home with wife  quit smoking 20 years ago  drinks socially  exercises moderately.  - Family history of cardiovascular diseases.   Past Medical History: - Diagnosed with Hypertension 10 years ago  managed by Lisinopril  - Hyperlipidemia for which he is on Atorvastatin  - Underwent Transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) for benign prostate hyperplasia (BPH) 3 years ago.  Key Complaints: - Sudden onset palpitations began 2 hours prior to presentation in the emergency department. Patient describes it as a ""fluttering"" in his chest.  - Associated with mild shortness of breath.  - Onset while walking his dog  not exertional.  - Negative for associated chest pain  dizziness  light-headedness or syncope. - Denied nausea  vomiting  or sweating.    By utilizing this case  medical students can learn about the patient history  clinical presentations  and healthcare management for atrial fibrillation. Factors such as age  significant notable lifestyle (e.g. smoking)  associated medical conditions (hypertension)  presence of cardiovascular diseases in family history can all contribute towards the development of this condition. Atrial fibrillation often presents with complaints like palpitations (described as a flutter) and it is essential that it be distinguished from other cardiovascular pathologies.

Patient Information:  Mr. Tom Wang  a 70-year-old Asian male  retired banker  lives with his wife in the city.  Presenting Concerns: Mr. Wang is brought to the emergency with complaints of palpitations  fatigue  dizziness  and occasional shortness of breath. His wife also adds that he seemed confused at times in the last week. The symptoms have been present for a week before becoming severe enough for him to seek medical attention.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Wang suffers from type-2 diabetes mellitus for which he takes Metformin  diagnosed 5 years back. He has also been hypertensive for the past decade and is on Losartan. He has a history of ischemic stroke 2 years ago with a subsequent full recovery. There is no significant family history of any cardiac disease. Mr. Wang had been a 30-pack-a-year smoker but quit smoking after the stroke. His alcohol intake is occasional and in moderation.   Reviews of body systems are negative for fever  loss of appetite  or weight loss. He reports no chest pain  nausea  or vomiting. His bowel and bladder habits have been consistent  with no recent changes.   Physical Examination: Mr. Wang appears slightly anxious. His BMI is 29. The pulse is irregularly irregular  with a rate of 110 bpm. Blood pressure readings are 145/90 mmHg. Respiratory rate and oxygen saturation are within normal limits. Chest auscultation reveals clear lung fields. On cardiac auscultation  no murmurs are detected. His neurological and other system examinations are unremarkable.   This case report should equip the students to develop their learning needs about atrial fibrillation which includes understanding the pathophysiology  precipitating factors  clinical features  complications  diagnosis  and management.

Patient Information:  Mr. Johnson  a 72-year-old Caucasian male   Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a confirmed history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He was a two-pack-a-day smoker for 35 years before quitting 10 years ago. Additionally  he has been diagnosed with obesity. He has been prescribed metformin for his diabetes  and amlodipine for his hypertension.  Key Complaints: Mr. Johnson presents to the clinic complaining of a sudden onset of occasional palpitations  feeling short of breath  and episodic dizziness over the past 3 days. He also reports a general feeling of weakness and fatigue. On further probing  he has also reported difficulty in performing his daily activities due to these complaints. The patient denies chest pain  syncope  or orthopnea.  Physical Examination Findings: Mr. Johnson is alert and oriented. His vital signs are stable except for an irregular pulse rate varying between 85 to 105 beats per minute. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable except for irregularly irregular heart sounds with no audible murmurs.  Investigations: Preliminary ECG shows irregularly irregular rhythm  absence of distinct P waves and a variable ventricular response suggestive of atrial fibrillation.  This case scenario provides a scope to medical students to study and understand the clinical manifestations of atrial fibrillation  its diagnosis  potential complications  and management. Including this case in the curriculum will enable the learners to associate the theoretical knowledge about AFib pathology with its practical implications  probe the causes  symptoms  perform physical examinations and interpret investigation results. Furthermore  understanding of the risk factors and the role of preventive measures could also be adequately conveyed through the case discussion.

Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 73-year-old Caucasian male.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol  for which he takes a daily regimen of Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  respectively. He quit smoking 10 years ago but smoked 1 pack/day for 30 years. He drinks alcohol moderately and has a sedentary lifestyle. There is also a family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father having died from a myocardial infarction at age 66.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Doe came to the clinic with recurrent palpitations and unexplained fatigue which have been ongoing for the last couple of months. Recently  he experienced a couple of episodes of shortness of breath and light-headedness. He has also noticed some swelling in his ankles and a slight weight gain over the last couple of weeks.  Mr. Doe denies chest pain  fevers  cough  or other respiratory symptoms. He mentioned he has been adhering to his medication regimen regularly and there haven't been any changes or additions to his usual medications.  Next steps will be a thorough clinical examination followed by appropriate investigations to determine the cause of Mr. Doe's symptoms  suspecting Atrial Fibrillation due to presenting complaints.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. Ronald  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer.  Presenting Complaints: The patient presents with a 4-day history of mild chest discomfort and palpitations. He also reports episodes of light-headedness but no syncope. There was no reported breathlessness  chest pain  or lower limb swelling.  Past Medical History: Mr. Ronald has a 5-year history of hypertension  dyslipidemia  and Stage 2 Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD). He has been treated with Ramipril 5mg  Amlodipine 10mg  and Atorvastatin 10mg. He has no known allergies but had a smoking history up until 10 years ago.  Previous Episodes: This is the first episode of these symptoms. He has never been diagnosed with heart disease before.  Family History: His father died at the age of 78 from a stroke  and his mother lived until 85 with diabetes and hypertension but no known heart disease.  Social History: Mr. Ronald was a smoker up to 10 years ago. He quit when he was diagnosed with CKD. He drinks alcohol occasionally  mostly on holidays and celebrations. He lives with his wife  and they have 3 grown-up children.  Current Medications: Mr. Ronald is regularly taking his antihypertensive medications  including Ramipril 5mg once daily and Amlodipine 10mg once daily. He also takes Atorvastatin 10mg once daily at night for cholesterol management.  Review of Systems: On general examination  he is afebrile with a pulse rate of 135 beats per minute and an irregularly irregular rhythm. His blood pressure is at 150/90mmHg. He has no jugular venous distension or lower limb edema.  Based on the patient's symptoms and physical exam  atrial fibrillation seems likely. Proceeding with an appropriate diagnostic and therapeutic approach for Mr. Ronald will prove beneficial in further learning.   *Please Note: This case has been created for educational purposes and does not represent a real patient.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: John Doe Age: 72 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer Smoker: No Alcohol: Occasional Family history: Heart disease (Father passed away from a heart attack at age 67)  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Doe presents with general complaints of intermittent palpitations and shortness of breath over past few months. What started as just “fluttering” sensation in the chest has now turned into feeling of rapid and irregular heartbeats  especially noted when he tries to climb stairs or does some physical exertion. He also complained of occasional lightheadedness and fatigue  but no chest pain  syncope or presyncope. He reports no lower extremity swelling  no color changes in fingers or toes and no recent drastic weight changes.  Past Medical History: Patient has a history of hypertension which is well controlled on ACE inhibitors. There is also a 5-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus being managed by Metformin and regular diet control. A recent annual health check-up revealed no cardio-metabolic derangements except for slightly elevated LDL cholesterol levels.  Patient uses aspirin daily and he denies any history of allergy. No past hospitalizations or surgeries are reported.  Concluding Statement: Considering the patient's age  present complaints  and medical history  it is important to evaluate the likelihood of atrial fibrillation. The next step should be a physical examination and diagnostic tests including ECG  echocardiography  and blood tests to confirm diagnosis and guide the future course of treatment.

Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 67-year-old Caucasian male.  Background: Mr. Doe is a retired engineer now working part-time as a consultant. He is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially.   Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension  which has been well-managed through medication for the past 15 years. He has experienced one episode of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) 8 years ago. His family history shows his father passed away from myocardial infarction at the age of 72. He has been under regular medical check-ups and his BMI within normal range.  Key Complaints: Mr. Doe contacted the surgery for a same-day appointment  presenting with complaints of palpitations and intermittent dizziness for the past two days. The palpitations felt irregular and were accompanied by mild shortness of breath. The symptoms were initially intermittent but had become constant since the day of presenting to the clinic. He denied any chest pain  nausea  vomiting  or syncope. He also reported a mild increase in fatigue over the last few days.  On Examination: On examination  his blood pressure was reported as 140/95 mmHg  pulse – irregularly irregular at 130/min  respiratory rate – 18/min and temperature was 98.6 F. His cardiovascular examination revealed an irregularly irregular rhythm. His lungs were clear to auscultation and abdomen was soft and non-tender without any distension or organomegaly.  This would be a good case for students to understand the presentation  workup  and management of atrial fibrillation. The discussion should include the importance of taking a thorough history  looking for risk factors  understanding the pathophysiology behind the symptoms  importance of appropriate investigations  consequences of untreated AF and its acute and long-term management.

Patient Report: ---------------------- Demographics: Name: Mr. John Smith Age: 68 years old Gender: Male Occupation: Retired Engineer Ethnicity: Caucasian Marital Status: Married  Past medical history: 1) Hypertension 2) Type II Diabetes Mellitus 3) Dyslipidemia 4) Mild Obesity  Presenting complaints: 1) Irregular heartbeat 2) Shortness of breath 3) Fatigue 4) Mild chest discomfort  History of Present Illness: Mr. Smith  a 68-year-old retired engineer  holds a known history of hypertension  type II diabetes  and dyslipidemia. He recently began experiencing a sensation of irregular and occasionally fast heartbeat  accompanied by episodes of shortness of breath that has noticeably increased in the past week. He also reports an increasing fatigueness over this same period  with a mild amount of chest discomfort that lasts for some minutes but then resolves. Notably  his symptoms are worsening with exertion. The patient denies any diaphoresis  syncope  or pre-syncope. There has been no recent fever  cough  or other respiratory or systemic symptoms. He does not recall any history of rheumatic fever as a child. He has been compliant with his medications: metformin  lisinopril  and simvastatin.  As an educator  you can discuss this case with your students focusing on the diagnosis and management of atrial fibrillation  the importance of treating underlying conditions  and prevention of complications such as stroke and heart failure.

Case Report:  Chief Complaint: The patient presents with palpitations  fatigue  and dyspnea.   Demographics: 68-year-old African American male.  Past Medical History:  The patient's pertinent medical history consists of controlled hypertension  moderate Obesity  smoking history of 1 pack per day for the last 30 years  and Type II Diabetes Mellitus controlled with oral hypoglycemics.  Presenting Symptoms:  The patient initially reported to the primary care clinic with a conscious sensation of rapid  irregular palpitations lasting for several hours  predominantly noticed in the night. The episodes are sporadic in nature making it hard for the patient to quantify the symptoms' frequency. In addition  the patient has been feeling fatigued after doing routine work and has also noticed an increase in shortness of breath especially in the last couple of weeks. No history of chest pain  syncope  vertigo  or peripheral edema is noted.   The above case provides students with enough information to suspect atrial fibrillation as a probable diagnosis and plan the next diagnostic tests accordingly. The patient's demographic  past medical history  and complaint characteristics all point toward atrial fibrillation. With additional clinical data  medical students can begin to disentangle this case.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. James Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  Past Medical History: He has a documented history of hypertension for the past ten years  controlled with Lisinopril. He also has type 2 diabetes mellitus  controlled through Metformin. He has previously been a smoker  but quit five years ago. He does not have any known allergies.  Current Complaint:  Mr. Smith reports that for the past four days  he's been experiencing episodes of rapid  irregular heartbeats  which seem to come and go without any specific trigger. He also reports feelings of fatigue and mild shortness of breath during these episodes. He has not experienced any chest pain  or fainting. The symptoms have caused him significant distress which prompted his visit to the hospital.  Family History: His father had a history of cardiac arrhythmias and died of congestive heart failure at age 73. His mother had type 2 diabetes and died of a stroke at age 78. His sister has hypertension.  Physical examination: Mr. Smith is alert and oriented. He appears slightly anxious. His blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg  pulse rate is irregular at 110/min  temperature is 98.6°F/37°C  and respiratory rate is 16/min. Cardiac exam reveals an irregular rhythm  no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Lungs are clear to auscultation. The remaining physical exam is normal.  Objective: By evaluating this case  the medical students should be able to develop an understanding of potential diagnoses (with a focus on atrial fibrillation)  appropriate diagnostic investigations  and management options for such a case. Tasks: - Elicit further relevant medical history from the patient - Describe the various potential diagnoses and justify why atrial fibrillation should be considered - Propose an effective diagnostic strategy  - Discuss the potential management options and plan for the patient.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 79 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer Location: Urban Midwest  Past Medical History:  -Hypertension managed with Lisinopril 20mg daily -Non-insulin dependent Type 2 diabetes managed with Metformin 1000mg twice daily -History of smoking (1 pack/day) quit 5 years prior -Osteoarthritis managed with occasional NSAIDs -Cataract surgery in right eye 2 years ago  Presenting Complaint: Over the past week  Mr. Doe has noticed several episodes of palpitations  occasional shortness of breath on exertion that he hasn't experienced before  and mild fatigue. He also mentioned a recent episode of breaking out in cold sweats while at rest but denies any chest pain.  He maintains a fairly active lifestyle for his age  including regular walks and gardening  but has noted a decline in his endurance for these activities recently. He denies any recent changes in his weight  appetite  or disturbances in sleep. He also denies dizziness  syncope  chest pain or discomfort.  On routine check-up  his blood pressure was 140/85 mmHg  heart rate was irregular at 90 beats per minute. A 12-lead EKG showed atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.  He was advised to visit the emergency department given his new onset palpitations and shortness of breath.   This case is designed to reflect a typical presentation of atrial fibrillation. The associated symptoms elucidate the common clinical features of this condition. The objective of this case study is to aid medical students in identifying and managing atrial fibrillation early in its course. The case also draws attention to the importance of considering atrial fibrillation as a differential when a patient presents with vague symptoms especially in those with associated risk factors such as age  hypertension  diabetes  and smoking history. As a result  they can be guided to choose appropriate diagnostic tests and apply the right therapeutic strategies.

Case Report:   Patient Demographics:  Mr. James Hendrickson is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired teacher  hailing from a suburban neighborhood. He is married  father of two  and a current smoker with a 25-pack-year smoking history. He is an occasional drinker. He denies any illicit drug history.  Past medical history: Mr. Hendrickson has a known past medical history of Hypertension for five years  managed with Lisinopril. He was also diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus three years ago  controlled with Metformin. There is no known family history of any heart disease.   Key complaints: James visited the outpatient department with chief complaints of a rapid and irregular heart rate and unexplained fatigue that has been persistent for the past two weeks. He reported feeling episodic 'heart flutters'  associated with shortness of breath. He has noticed that these episodes occur more frequently during physical exertion.   He denies any chest pain  syncope  orthopnea or weight gain but does indicate experiencing mild bouts of anxiety lately. He emphasized having a poor exercise tolerance in recent weeks which he initially assumed to be linked to ageing. However  recurring episodes of unusual heart rhythms have been a cause of concern  compelling him to seek medical attention.   This case should be followed up with a clinical examination  appropriate investigations  differential diagnosis  followed by the management of the patient's condition according to the findings.

Patient Profile:  1. Patient Demographics:    Name: Mr. X    Age: 70 Years    Gender: Male    Occupation: Retired  2. Past Medical History:    Mr. X is a 70-year-old male who had controlled hypertension for 10 years. He had been diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus five years ago  managed with diet modifications  and oral hypoglycemic agents. He also suffered from hyperlipidemia  being maintained with statins for the last six years.  3. Key Complaints:    Mr. X presented himself at the outpatient department (OPD) with persistent palpitations for the past two weeks. He also expressed occasional episodes of breathlessness  especially exertional. He described the palpitations as a ""rapid  irregular heartbeat that seems to flutter."" He noted that these symptoms were more bothersome during physical activities and at night  occasionally waking him from sleep. He denies chest pain  syncope  nausea  or recent weight loss.  Physical Assessment:    Mr. X appeared generally well but slightly anxious. His vital signs were: B.P 150/90 mm Hg; Pulse rate: irregularly irregular with a rate of 110 beats/min; respiratory rate: 16 breaths/min; and SpO2: 96% on room air. Cardiac examination revealed an irregularly irregular heart rhythm. Lung fields are clear to auscultation bilaterally.  This case for atrial fibrillation includes primary input for the patient's presentation and history. Medical students should weigh further diagnostic procedures such as ECG  echocardiography  and possibly thyroid function tests. The management plan should be tailored to this patient's AF  whether it's rate or rhythm control  anticoagulation therapy  and treat the underlying cause  if any. It would be beneficial to discuss the risk factors and complications related to AF and the prophylactic measures that could be undertaken.

Patient Profile:   - Name: Mr. John Smith  - Age: 65 years old - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired school teacher - Marital Status: Married with 3 grown-up children - Race: Caucasian  - Insurance: Medicare  Past Medical History (PMH):  - 3 years ago  diagnosed with type 2 diabetes  currently controlled with metformin and lifestyle modifications - 5 years ago  diagnosed with stage 2 hypertension - Cholesterol levels slightly above normal for his age - Non-smoker  occasional drinker - No known allergies - Father had a heart attack at age 75; mother had a stroke at age 82  brother (age 68) has CAD (coronary artery disease)  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Smith attended the clinic for a routine check-up. He mentioned that recently he's been feeling fatigue  intermittent rapid heartbeat  and a sensation of fluttering in the chest. He's also been experiencing episodes of dizziness and shortness of breath which have been occurring more frequently in the past few weeks  sometimes waking him up at night. He denied any chest pain  vision changes  slurring of speech  confusion  or coordination problems.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  Mr. Smith's BP is 155/90 mm Hg  HR 110 bpm irregularly irregular  RR 18 breaths per minute  and BMI of 28 kg/m2. His S1 and S2 were normal without murmurs  rubs  or gallops. His lungs are clear bilaterally  and abdomen is soft and non-tender. A 12-lead ECG is ordered due to his complaints of palpitations and irregular heart rate.   This case highlights atrial fibrillation (Afib) in a patient with multiple risk factors including age  hypertension  and family history of heart disease. The case is designed to reinforce understanding of Afib symptomatology  risk factor evaluation  and required diagnostic work-up. The students will benefit by recognizing the signs of Afib  understanding its potential complications  and initiating applicable treatment plans.

Patient Information:  - Age: 69 - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired high school teacher  Past Medical History:  - Hypertension - Type II Diabetes Mellitus - Past smoker  quit five years ago - No known drug allergies  Key Complaints:  The patient presents with chief complaints of intermittent palpitations  fatigue and shortness of breath particularly upon exertion for the past 2 weeks. He reports that he feels like his heart is racing off and on. He states that occasionally  he also experiences lightheadedness. He denies chest pain  excessive sweating  nausea  vomiting  and syncope. He has noticed a significant decrease in his exercise tolerance while walking his dog over the past two weeks.  He is compliant with his antihypertensive and glucose-lowering medications. He has no history of cardiac disease in the family. His other vitals - BP: 140/85 mmHg  HR: irregularly irregular  RR: 16 bpm  T: 98.6°F are stable. Due to COVID-19  he is currently avoiding seeking physical medical support  but his symptoms are concerning and he wishes to seek medical advice.   This case could give medical students a chance to learn about the diagnostic approach of atrial fibrillation including physical examination  ECG interpretation  and management strategies for such patients.

Case Report  Patient Information:   Mr. Allan Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired lawyer  non-smoker  average built  presented to the emergency department.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a known history of hypertension and controlled Type-2 diabetes. He has been regularly taking Metformin 500mg BD for his diabetes and Amlodipine 5mg OD for hypertension. There is no known allergy  and his immunizations  including an annual influenza and pneumococcal due to his age and diabetic status  are up to date. He has no previous record of a similar incident. He has no recent travel or surgery history.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Smith reported that he had been experiencing intermittent palpitations in the chest for the past one week  along with occasional episodes of lightheadedness and shortness of breath  especially on climbing the stairs. The palpitations were described as a 'quick  fluttery sensation' and lasted several minutes to hours  spontaneously reverting to normal. He denied any associated chest pain  clamminess  loss of consciousness  angina  or swelling in the extremities.   He also reported decreased tolerance for his regular exercise routine  and a vague ongoing sense of fatigue and malaise. He affirmed that he had been regular with his blood pressure and diabetes medications and still had an optimal control over them.   His family history was unremarkable  except his father suffered from congestive cardiac failure and died at the age of 75. His daily routine included a balanced diet with regular morning walks  occasional alcohol during social events  and quality sleep. He was quite concerned about his irregular heartbeat  thus warranting the visit to the ER.   In this case  the initial differential diagnosis should focus on disorders causing palpitations  including but not limited to: Atrial Fibrillation  Supraventricular Tachycardia  and Ventricular Tachycardia. However  the age  history and nature of the symptoms lean more towards a likely diagnosis of arrhythmia  possibly Atrial Fibrillation.

Case Report:  Patient Profile: Patient Name: Mr. Joseph Morris Age: 72 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Weight: 78 kg Height: 5 feet 9 inches Occupation: Retired Engineer  Past Medical History: - History of Hypertension for the past 15 years  well-controlled on medications (Losartan 50mg daily). - Hypercholesterolemia managed with diet and exercise. - T2DM diagnosed 5 years ago  currently maintained on oral hypoglycemics (Metformin 1000mg twice daily).  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Morris visited the outpatient cardiology clinic complaining of intermittent palpitations that have become progressively frequent over the past 6 months. These episodes are frequently associated with shortness of breath  occasional light-headedness  and fatigue. He also reported difficulty in sleeping on his left side due to discomfort in the chest. No complaint of syncope or dizziness.  There have been no changes in the dietary habits  stress levels  or energy levels. He denies any chest pain  fever  cough  or weight loss.   Family History: One younger brother died at 58 due to myocardial infarction. His father had a history of stroke at age 67  while the cause of his mother's death at age 75 was breast cancer. No known family history of atrial fibrillation or other genetic diseases.  Social History: Mr. Morris is a nonsmoker and nonalcoholic. He lives with his wife in their two-story house. Engages in light exercise such as walking his dog in the morning.  This case study is intended to hone the medical students' ability to diagnose and manage atrial fibrillation through history taking  physical examination  identification of risk factors  interpretation of diagnostic test results  and determination of appropriate interventions  and follow-up strategies.

Patient Case Report  Patient Information: - Patient Name: Mr. John Doe - Gender: Male - Age: 68 years old - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired Engineer  Past Medical History: - Hypertension for 10 years managed with Atenolol - Type II Diabetes Mellitus for 6 years managed with Metformin - Moderate Drinkers (2 drinks/day for last 20 years) - Non-smoker - Family history of cardiac diseases (Father had myocardial infarction at age 72)  Presenting Complaints: - Intermittent palpitations in the last 3 months - Occasional chest discomfort - Increasing fatigue and shortness of breath  particularly on exertion - Reduced exercise tolerance - Occasionally feeling faints  Specific Histories: - The palpitations are irregularly irregular and have no apparent trigger. They may happen at rest or during activity. - The chest discomfort is not linked to the palpitations and does not radiate to other regions. - Faint spells do not lead to loss of consciousness and have no particular trigger. - No symptoms of thyrotoxicosis - No history of rheumatic heart disease - No recent infection or change in weight - Regular medications  no allergies or over-the-counter drug use - No recent travel or surgeries.  Observation: - The patient does not look in acute distress - Speaking in complete sentences with no noticeable shortness of breath - No ankle swelling or visible cyanosis   This case report sets the stage for the diagnosis of Atrial Fibrillation  considering the patient's cardiovascular risk factors  age  medical history and the symptoms described. Next steps would be confirmation through physical examination  ECG/EKG  and consequent management.   End of the case report.

Patient Case  DEMOGRAPHICS Patient: Mr. Philip Turner Age: 73-year-old Sex: Male Occupation: Retired teacher Residency: Urban Smoking status: Non-smoker Alcohol consumption: Mild  PAST MEDICAL HISTORY Mr. Turner has a history of treated hypertension for the past 10 years and diagnosed Type II Diabetes Mellitus for the past 5 years. Regular medications include Metformin 500mg BD and Losartan 50 mg OD. He has no known drug allergies. His lifestyle is marked by mild physical activity  with usual walking and gardening being his primary exercise. No history of heart disease in the family. He has never been hospitalized and maintains up-to-date immunizations.  KEY COMPLAINTS Mr. Turner visited his general practitioner complaining of recent episodes of palpitations and occasional bouts of breathlessness  mainly in the evenings  during the past month. He denied experiencing chest pain  lightheadedness  syncope  or any recent infections/illnesses. Due to COVID-19  he hasn't been much active recently. His appetite is a little down and he feels tired more than usual. His blood sugars have been relatively controlled between the range 130-180 mg/dl. His blood pressure has been around 130/85 mmHg in readings taken over the week at home.   This medical case can be utilized for students to explore and discuss possible causes and the necessary next steps in the diagnosis and treatment of Mr. Turner's symptoms  with emphasis on Atrial Fibrillation. Students can weigh on ECG  blood tests  physical examinations  and history taking strategy to discern the cause of Mr. Turner's complaints.

Patient Information: Mr. Henry Jones  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired teacher  residing in New York City.   Medical History: Patient has a medical history of uncontrolled hypertension for 10 years  dyslipidemia for 8 years  and diabetes mellitus type 2 for 6 years. He is a former smoker and quit smoking 15 years ago. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father having suffered from a myocardial infarction at 60 years of age.   Current Medications: He is on metformin for diabetes  lisinopril for hypertension  and statins for dyslipidemia.  Key Complaints: Reports experiencing intermittent palpitations that last anywhere from a few minutes to a few hours for the past 3 days. Describes the feeling as his heart ""racing"" and several times he’s felt lightheaded. He also reports occasional bouts of fatigue and shortness of breath in the past week. There has been no chest pain  fainting  or orthopnea. His sleep is unaffected and he has had no recent weight loss or weight gain. He denies smoking  alcohol use  and recreational drug use.   Exposure: He travels infrequently. His last travel was six months ago. No known drug allergies. He is up to date with his vaccinations.   Social History: He lives with his wife  is a retired teacher and enjoys reading  gardening  and walking their dog. He quit smoking 15 years ago  drinks alcohol occasionally  and has no known drug abuse history.   Occupational History: Past occupational exposure to second-hand smoke as a teacher.   This case aligns with the demographic most commonly affected by atrial fibrillation - older adults with a history of cardiovascular disease or hypertension. The most typical symptoms such as palpitations  unexplained tiredness  and shortness of breath are present in this case  providing a good framework for students to formulate a likely diagnosis and management plan.

Case Report: Atrial Fibrillation  Patient Demographics: Name: Harold Schneider Age: 67 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired School Teacher Location: Chicago  IL  Past Medical History: Harold Schneider is a 67-year-old male with a past medical history of hypertension and notice of occasional heart palpitations over the last couple of years. He has not been consistent with his blood pressure medication (Lisinopril)  often citing forgetfulness as the reason. He is a former smoker (quit 15 years ago) and moderately consumes alcohol (1-2 units every few evenings)  Key Complaints: Mr. Harold visited his primary care provider complaining of more persistent palpitations he’s been having for about 2 weeks. These palpitations have been accompanied by light-headedness  shortness of breath while performing routine home chores  and a sense of generalized fatigue. He denied angina  syncope or pre-syncope. He noticed an irregular pulse pattern while taking his blood pressure at home. Upon review  there was no clear reason identified for the increased frequency of his symptoms  with his usual stressors and physical routines remaining unchanged. His irregular pulse suggests the possibility of arrhythmia.   The objectives of this case are to know the diagnostic approach for a patient presenting with symptoms suggestive of atrhythmia  understand the management options for atrial fibrillation  and educate about lifestyle modifications for better healthcare outcomes in patients with atrial fibrillation.

Patient Information:   Mr. Franklin Marshall  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  retired automobile factory worker  smoker of 20 years  currently a resident of Queens  New York. He lives with his wife and enjoys playing golf as a hobby.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Marshall was diagnosed with hypertension around ten years ago and has been on medication since then. He also has hyperlipidemia and a family history of cardiovascular diseases. In 2008  he underwent a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) following a heart attack. His most recent vitals show blood pressure maintained within an average range (130/85 mm Hg) because of the antihypertensive medication. His blood cholesterol is slightly on the higher side despite lipid-lowering medications. He also experiences chronic episodes of acid reflux.   Key Complaints:  Over the past couple of weeks  Mr. Marshall has noticed an irregular heartbeat that is sometimes so fast that it takes his breath away  especially during his golf sessions. He also often experiences fatigue  lightheadedness  and shortness of breath.   Initially  he thought it was due to his age and the physical exertion from the game. However  he got worried when he fainted once at home after experiencing a rapid fluttering in his chest. His wife also noticed him losing color (pallor) during such episodes. Since then  he has decreased his physical activity due to fear of these episodes  but the irregular heartbeats (palpitations) continue. He denies any chest pain  edema  or recent weight gain.  On the basis of the provided information  the students are expected to consider the symptoms  Mr. Marshall's age  his past medical history  and risk factors to determine the likelihood of atrial fibrillation as a possible diagnosis. The case will guide a thorough exploration of the disease  its management  potential treatments  and applicable precautions.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 62 years old Sex: Male Occupation: Retired teacher Ethnicity: Caucasian Living Situation: Living with wife  non-smoker  moderate drinker  Past Medical History:   1. Hypertension  diagnosed aged 52  managed with Losartan 50 mg 2. Dyslipidemia  diagnosed aged 55  controlled with Atorvastatin 20 mg 3. No known allergies 4. No previous surgeries 5. Family history of heart disease (Father died of a heart attack at 70)  Key Complaints:  The patient presented to the clinic with a chief complaint of intermittent palpitations and feelings of unease that had been increasing in frequency over the past 6 months. He described the palpitations as a rapid  irregular beating in his chest that might last for several minutes to hours. He stated that these episodes are also associated with feeling light-headed and tired.  He also reported episodes of breathlessness and decreased exercise tolerance; he used to be able to walk his dog for around 30 minutes without rest  now he feels winded after 15 minutes.  In the last week  he's noted two episodes of dizziness. He denied chest pain  syncope or presyncope  but he has been concerned about these new symptoms. His wife noted he appeared to be less focused and seemed to forget things easily.  Preliminary Diagnosis:  The patient's presentation and medical history suggest a possible case of atrial fibrillation. Further examinations and EKG to confirm the diagnosis would be necessary.

Patient Information: Mr. James Anderson  a 68-year-old male  retired teacher  lives in suburban area with his wife  non-smoker  with moderate alcohol consumption (social drinking).  Past Medical History: Mr. Anderson has a history of hypertension for 15 years  controlled with medication  hypercholesterolemia for 10 years requires statins  and diabetes type II for the last 3 years managed with oral medication. There is a family history of cardiovascular diseases  his father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 70. No known drug allergies.  Key Complaints: The patient has reported experiencing recurring episodes of palpitations  occasional shortness of breath  fatigue  and light-headedness for the past two months. The symptoms are not severely impacting his daily life but are causing him some concern due to their increasing frequency. He denies chest pain  syncope  or any other severe event. No significant weight loss or weight gain  fever  or any other systemic symptoms.  Vital Signs:  - Blood Pressure: 150/85 mmHg  - Pulse: Irregularly irregular and fast in low 100s. - Respiratory Rate: 18 breaths/min - Temperature: 98.6 F - Oxygen saturation: 97% on room air  Physical Examination: On physical examination  the patient appears comfortable. He is alert and oriented to person  place  and time. The cardiac examination reveals irregularly irregular rhythm without murmurs. Other systems are unremarkable.  Summary: This is a case of a 68-year-old male with a past medical history of long-term hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and type II diabetes mellitus. He complains of intermittent palpitations  light-headedness  shortness of breath  and fatigue of two months duration. Considering his symptoms  age  and medical history  this case would be a good opportunity for medical students to discuss and learn more about the diagnostic approach and management of atrial fibrillation.

Patient Case: Atrial Fibrillation  Patient Demographics  Surname: Jones First Name: John Age: 67 Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension 2. Diabetes type 2 3. History of smoking (15 years  quit ten years ago) 4. Hyperlipidemia 5. He also mentions occasional mild chest tightness but it doesn’t last for long and is not very severe.
